text: I really love this place and have been coming for years. They are personal, they remember you, and on a Sunday they are the only ones in town who still have seating! I think the 2nd floor gives them a cool &#34;hidden&#34; factor but I also really appreciate that they have a mix of table and cushy-sofa seating, and offer &#34;deluxe&#34; brunch items like avocado and smoked salmon. I will definitely keep coming back!
Was there for a Sunday afternoon coffee. Chai latte is not at all it should be,  ice mocha even worse, terrible in terms of coffee. two stars for the ambient only.

text: Love the ambience and food at this place. Their eggs benedict, while untraditional, is amazing! Best hollandaise sauce I&#39;ve tasted. Compared to many other cafes, this place is definitely in my top three. The staff is very friendly as well.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=zWvA1Zc4sRv0DuDJb9g32Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'R C.', 'displayLocation': 'Washington, DC', 'altText': 'R C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=zWvA1Zc4sRv0DuDJb9g32Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 5, 'photoCount': 2, 'reviewCount': 25, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I don&#39;t even want to talk about anything but their poached eggs on toast. Some of the best I&#39;ve had anywhere, ever. <br><br>On the menu this dish listed with salmon, but they swapped out the salmon with sauteed mushrooms for me with no problems. And they did not skimp on the mushrooms. Enormous doorstop of bread. Drowning in hot hollandaise. Yum. Not to mention that at $15 it&#39;s one of the lower priced versions of eggs benedict I&#39;ve seen in Singapore. <br><br>Another favorite is the minty mango passionfruit smoothie -- the mint is the &#39;twist&#39; on the menu. <br><br>I also love the rustic chic vibe of this shop house cafe, with lots of different types of seating areas. The very competent women who run Group Therapy are always pleasant. Great for a brunch spot, or a lunch spot if you want eggs benedict in the afternoon (I do) but I would totally fill up the place with friends for an evening do if I could.

We got here on a Sunday afternoon and it was packed. The noise level was significantly loud with no music, so if you would like peace and quiet, you could try this place on a weekday. I got the poached eggs with smoked salmon that everyone is raving about and it was good, but I wouldn&#39;t say that the eggs weren&#39;t beautifully poached. They were just....poached eggs. BUT, coupled with the smoked salmon on the thick slab of toast, and with the delish hollandaise sauce, the flavor combination really hit the spot. A great dish to have if you wanted something relatively light but still flavorful. The shepard&#39;s pie was tasty to me, but I do have a penchant for sweet and savory food. For those who does not appreciate sweetness in your salty foods, do not get it. The portions are pretty okay, but on the small side for a typical brunch. Worth a visit if you are around in the area craving some brunch, but not super delicious to go out of the way for.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=D_LiWAzR0ZCqb1eF5LyiPQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Sk3iW-m3Esoqu1tUG9mWMA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jay H.', 'displayLocation': 'Ang Mo Kio, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Jay H.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=D_LiWAzR0ZCqb1eF5LyiPQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 53, 'photoCount': 2, 'reviewCount': 7, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Best coffee in Sentosa . I&#39;m sure there are people who prefer their Kopi-O&#39;s and hawker Center hot drinks, but as far as frothy milk coffees go, this places smashes them. If you&#39;re in Sentosa Cove regularly It&#39;s totally worth getting one of the pay in advance loyalty cards, which they have various versions of depending on your tipple of choice.

text: This branch of Joe the Juice is absolutely shocking. Their equipment is constantly broken, which means you either get sour milk or no coffee at all. The staff here also open and close the store when it suits them. This morning, an hour late. Whoever owns this franchise needs to wake up.

text: A relaxing place to rest and enjoy the atmosphere at Quayside Isle. They have a selection of juices (think Boost Juice), coffee and sandwiches. Definitely coming back next time I&#39;m in thr neighborhood.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8hRfKR35ieZwVGEHEyF-XA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-bean-and-tea-leaf-singapore-21?reviewid=-xbRg-CLZAmz-IuKrOxQ4g&select=8hRfKR35ieZwVGEHEyF-XA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf - Singapore, Singapore. Black Forest', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Black Forest'}]
text: I decided to pick up a drink as my breakfast one morning before heading to Gleneagles. It was around 8.40am and the place was already busy and rather packed. <br><br>Honestly, since my last visit to a Coffee Bean last year at Ion Orchard, this coffee &amp; tea chain has fallen off my list of places I should visit. However, seemed like this Coffee Bean is the only one nearest to where I was. I was not prepared to walk over to the Starbucks at Wheelock Place and risk getting late for my appointment. So that day, Coffee Bean would do. <br><br>My unhealthy breakfast (4/5)<br>I ordered the Black Forest. I know this is not a Black Forest Cake. Unknown to many, I do enjoy a good Black Forest cake and it is one of my fav. Anyhow, when I looked at the menu board to decide what to order, that Black Forest was calling for me. I told the barista a little whipped cream please. The drink turned out to be good, there was even a cherry on the top of the drink. It tasted nothing like a Black Forest cake though.<br><br>AMBIENCE (4/5)<br>There was an outdoor seating here. The place seemed nice but was rather crowded on a weekday morning. <br><br>SERVICE 4/5<br>Staff was fine. This place seemed to be understaffed. The barista seemed to be working alone behind the counter. I almost jumped when he announced &#34;Black Forest&#34;. It was kind of too loud and I was not sure if I like everyone in there to know I ordered a Black Forest that early in the morning :P

text: The Americano here isn&#39;t as good as Starbucks and is more expensive.<br><br>But I love the fast wi-Fi here and the lounge seats are very cozy.

Black forest :)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Black forest :)'}]
text: Love the red velvet cheesecake :) and black forest  ice blended. The place is not crowded and good for hanging-out with friends. <br>I initially given it a higher rate but staffs gets into a fight and shouting match. Good thing the manager step in and asked his staff to go out but the reactions a bit slow..

same old question?<br><br>me: can i have an ice chocolate?<br>he: blended?<br>me: why do you keep asking me that? last week was the same.<br>he: because we have ice blended.<br>me: if i wanted that, i would say ice blended, right?<br><br>to his credit he didn&#39;t ask me if i wanted it with coffee.<br><br>the ultimate breakfast was sold out at 9am in the morning???<br>so was the pancakes!<br>i know they are opened 24hrs but being so, they must have a better replenishment strategy.<br><br>they were not as crowded nor dirty today though.<br><br>so why am i back here again?<br>sigh......free wifi!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/h2dOT2ksrMKT3EBAXDtTBQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-bean-and-tea-leaf-singapore-21?reviewid=32JigBW_tqLOXA4C-6A0aA&select=h2dOT2ksrMKT3EBAXDtTBQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Every single student seems to go to the extremely cramped Liat Starbucks to study. Why? It confuses me because down the road is The Coffee Bean &amp; Tea Leaf at Forum. I really prefer CBTL&#39;s coffee and tea... Starbucks sucks. CBTL&#39;s earl grey tastes so much better... <br><br>Also, it&#39;s empty - I was at Liat earlier and it was packed. Now I&#39;m here at CBTL and it&#39;s empty! It&#39;s 24hours, no people, complimentary wifi and comfy couches - what&#39;s not to love?<br><br>It can get crowded on the weekends though, but if you&#39;re looking for a late-night weekday studying spot - this is it. There&#39;s also hot food and pasta dishes which are quite nice. <br><br>I&#39;m not a big fan of their desserts however. I&#39;ve tried their chocolate brownie (too dry!) and red velvet cake... neither of them are appealing. The carrot cake is passable.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/r3DbRtvrTHnGpZbcUOCpfA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-bean-and-tea-leaf-singapore-21?reviewid=8merUSAUEGfk-MW2dS2xTg&select=r3DbRtvrTHnGpZbcUOCpfA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Have been coming here to do my work since I was in college and I am surprised that till this day, it is still significantly less crowded than all the other coffee joints in the Orchard area. What I like about this place is that  it is always relatively quiet so you can concentrate on doing your work or having a chat with your friends. There is free wi-fi that can get a little slow but is still much stabler compared to the nonsense you get with wireless@sg. Expect their usual selection of teas, coffees, cakes and dishes -basic enough to satisfy your hunger/thirst woes but I must add that most of the cakes are little too dry for my liking.

This CBTL is in a pretty nice location and is 24 hours. A good option for students looking for a place to hit the books. Somewhat away from the busy parts of Orchard Road, it&#39;s considerably quieter at certain times of the day. In contrast, the Starbucks at Liat is crowded ALL THE TIME. However, this CBTL can still get crowded at the usual peak hours and on weekends. <br><br>Coffee wise, I&#39;ve always quite liked CBTL coffee. It&#39;s rarely ever burnt, in contrast to Starbucks coffee that is very often burnt. I&#39;m referring to the brewed coffee, mainly. CBTL also has a better food menu, in my opinion. The caesar salad is really quite good.

First customer in at 7:30am and was greeted and ushered to a nice big booth.  Ordered the pancake, granola and the veggie wonderland.  To my disappointment the two sunny side eggs came in way too done.  The waiter promptly suggest replacing the eggs and it came back exactly what it should - runny.  Once again all in all good food most importantly excellent coffee.

text: Avocado milkshake ($12) - 4 stars<br>Solid. Bit too sweet for me and couldn&#39;t reduce the sweetness as it&#39;s pre-mixed.

Table seating inside and out and also high top seating at the bar area', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Table seating inside and out and also high top seating at the bar area'}]
text: Although I have only been here once with my husband for a late Sunday brunch, I will be back.  <br><br>The place is large and has seating indoors and outside.  You can make a reservation if need be (which I really like!).  The menu is interesting and made with as many locally grown foods as possible.  There is a bar top counter where a solo person could drink coffee, linger and read a book (this is me!).  <br><br>But the coffee...the aroma of those beans is such a beautiful thing from the moment you walk through the front door.  It is intoxicating in a way that only a coffee lover would truly appreciate.  The cup I had was really delicious and I look forward to going back and enjoying more real soon.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=YziRZOh5MrqN5b84dQ9AIQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/z9T19wxmS8cpyCrXdiPs7w/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Dan P.', 'displayLocation': 'Katong, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Dan P.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=YziRZOh5MrqN5b84dQ9AIQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 4194, 'photoCount': 1585, 'reviewCount': 376, 'eliteYear': None}
text: *Coffee Snob Intro*<br>When you&#39;re let go from a company the locations you frequent many many coffee shops.<br><br>These wonderful roasteries provide the perfect balance of professional attitude, casual attire, and passionate delivery to aid you in your job search.<br><br>I&#39;m going to rate a bunch of coffee shops based on this metric and a few others and provide an overall rating for the experience.<br><br>----------------------------------<br>OVERALL: 4 stars<br><br>Ambience: 4<br>Coffee: 5<br>Food: 4<br>Meeting Place: 4<br>Working Space: 3<br>----------------------------------<br><br>*Coffee Review*<br>Common Man Stan is aptly named as it caters to the common person and is located on Stanley street. The coffee is amazing as you would expect from Common Man roasters, and yes they will even do a &#34;magic&#34; should you request it you pretentious snob!<br><br>What I also find ideal about CMS is the meet &#39;n&#39; greet functionality of the layout. It&#39;s very 1-on-1 oriented and it allows you to have that quick catch-up with friend/colleague/recruiter/potential-hire/etc in a bubble environment. <br><br>The downside there is that if you want to do focus work it&#39;s not a great working space, as there is a non-stop buzz of activity seeking to distract you at all times.<br><br>I&#39;ve had the food here and it&#39;s also very good, with wonderful brunch options that allow you to tackle breakfast and lunch in one sitting! Kaboom!<br><br>I can totally recommend the space for meetings, a quick bite, and that all important top-shelf coffee.

text: 3.5 stars. Brunch spot on Stanley Street - decent food, quite vegetarian friendly (went with vegetarian friend). Nothing too special though - tastes quite average though a slight plus for erring on the healthy side.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9xNCemyxtdVb5EgLWj83uA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/common-man-stan-singapore?reviewid=jW-rrwQwVHSGBidY3m9heQ&select=9xNCemyxtdVb5EgLWj83uA', 'altText': 'Photo of Common Man Stan - Singapore, Singapore. CMCR Full breakfast. Umami fries too', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'CMCR Full breakfast. Umami fries too'}]
text: My local friends brought me here for brunch. The food was not the typical brunch selection. I hada  serious case of food envy when their orders came. The turkish breakfast, the potato and leek rosti... I had the veggie wonderland, the halloumi had nice spicy kick to it. You could choose sour dough, whole wheat or gluten free for their toast, any style of eggs, i chose poached eggs which was a good call, the eggs were done just right, not overcooked.  My friend ordered a nitro ice tea and when it was a delightful suprise, looked like a cocktail and it was mixed with orange juice. My only regret was not taking photos of all the food..

The espresso is awesome!<br>It&#39;s one of those low profile local places where people actually care of what they do and they&#39;re doing it very well.<br><br>You get a shot of sparkling water with each espresso and (sparkling) water and a few other drinks are available as well.<br>There are a few food options - cakes, croissants and a couple of sandwich options.<br><br>A bit disappointing is the fact that they only accept cash or NETS but given the size of their business, that&#39;s perfectly understandable and I&#39;m still giving them 5 stars.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/KQWw0k-FXtZC94S7A8U0dQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/percolate-singapore?reviewid=67KfJZBQcvAsHXPeZ8pt8A&select=KQWw0k-FXtZC94S7A8U0dQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Percolate - Singapore, Singapore. Doughnut dessert with pistachio butter ($13)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Doughnut dessert with pistachio butter ($13)'}]
text: Donut dessert ($13 for pistachio butter) - 2.5 stars<br>The best part about the dessert was getting to try The Hunter&#39;s Kitchenette&#39;s pistachio butter, which I&#39;ve been meaning to try. Other than that, it tasted like one of those Four Leaves/Prima Deli/generic HDB bakery doughnuts topped with pistachio butter and a scoop of vanilla ice cream (+$1 for the matcha ice cream). They use Meiji ice cream, which is too sweet and icy for my liking. The toppings were rather unimpressive - sorry tiny marshmallows are never a good sign for me.<br><br>Service was great though and there&#39;s wifi. Not many seats and it&#39;s fairly small - I was in several people&#39;s ways when I was deliberating over what to order. I imagine it gets crowded on weekends.<br><br>I was excited to see they serve oat milk! (+$1) Definitely trying it the next time!

Iced latte - $5', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Iced latte - $5'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/7CW66uMc454OK8LmfdyfIw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/percolate-singapore?reviewid=HcmHcH2eed8zm2dcftQunQ&select=7CW66uMc454OK8LmfdyfIw', 'altText': 'Photo of Percolate - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: One of the best neighborhood cafes in Singapore. Percolate is located just a stone throw from Bedok Interchange - take bus no 222 or 14 and stop at the second bus stop from the interchange. Turn right towards Bedok Avenue 3 (just a short walk, merely 30 meter) and you&#39;ll see the shop right in front of you at the junction. <br><br>As mentioned, it&#39;s a neighborhood cafe, meaning it&#39;s located on the ground floor of a HDB flat.  Small, intimate and customers seem to be more of a regular type although hipster wannabes do drop by over the weekend. Percolate definitely reminds me of Nylon coffee at Everton Park where it&#39;s not just about getting your business but the owner actually takes the interest to talk and get to know you more. It&#39;s like dropping at a friend&#39;s place for coffee after meal. No pressure at all. <br><br>Alvin, the owner is friendly and will never fail to greet you as you enter. I&#39;ve never browsed through the food menu but the croissant with savory filling seems like a crowd favorite so do try that if you&#39;re here for proper meal. Cakes and pies are stellar. I&#39;ve tried the honey lavender cake and it was really good. Now, the coffee. They 2 regular blends are from Papa Palheta and Nylon roasters and while I dislike coffee from Chye Seng Huat hardware (they&#39;re just horrible), the blend used here (sorry forgot the name) is pretty good. Four Chairs by Nylon is my to-go coffee all the time but occasionally i&#39;ll go for the former. Besides these two, there&#39;s always &#34;guest&#34; beans for you to try. Right now, there&#39;s Common Ground (one of the best roasters based in Jakarta), so if you&#39;re bored with the local blend, do give it a try! <br><br>Service is always prompt and friendly, Percolate is the best you can get in the east, hands down.

Exterior, with some outdoor seating', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Exterior, with some outdoor seating'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/TGKlzNzLmzRUgu2arpjiaA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/percolate-singapore?reviewid=J93zegAkbtfROh0qutotqw&select=TGKlzNzLmzRUgu2arpjiaA', 'altText': 'Photo of Percolate - Singapore, Singapore. Macchiato (served as an espresso shot)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Macchiato (served as an espresso shot)'}]
text: I find Bedok a very sleepy neighbourhood (not a bad thing!) and I think it&#39;s nice that they have a cafe like Percolate nestled in one of their HDB areas.<br><br>As it&#39;s the only &#34;hipster&#34; cafe in this block, it sticks out, but not like a sore thumb. Walking in on a Sunday during the late afternoon, it was packed and we actually had to wait a few minutes for a seat. The crowd was mostly locals, surprisingly no ang mos around.<br><br>I ordered their macchiato while Migs had a kaya pandan croissant (or something along those lines.) The barista was upfront with me and told me that their macchiato is not like the Starbucks version and it&#39;s served as an espresso shot. I&#39;m thankful for his heads up because I would&#39;ve been one of those who&#39;d think the former!<br><br>The shot was really strong for me. I think it&#39;s what kept me up that night, forcing me to research buying a bike in Singapore (oh God, I think I&#39;m slowly turning into a hipster!) I tried a little of the croissant and it was good. Not mind blowing, but simply the perfect afternoon snack.<br><br>Very chill, local spot with strong coffee. I&#39;d come back again.

The perfect croissant.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The perfect croissant.'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/jKl9ESIkRRYWDsGQsaomcw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/percolate-singapore?reviewid=cGHYeLrL8jbF7TKLnOQ2lw&select=jKl9ESIkRRYWDsGQsaomcw', 'altText': 'Photo of Percolate - Singapore, Singapore. My coffee cravings are realised', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'My coffee cravings are realised'}]
text: Great coffee, Friendly staff. What more can you ask from a cafe. Coffee is always good and they have a nice range to choose from. From the ordinary Americano, mocha, to a flat white to a latte. And they even have drinks for the peeps that don&#39;t take caffeine. They have sodas and coolers. <br><br>They have nice snacks as well. Would really recommend their croissants. The curry egg mayo one is my favourite. Fresh, flaky croissant stuffed to the Brim with egg mayo. Certainly a meal in its own. The cakes they bring in are also fresh and tasty. And did I mention it&#39;s always a big piece. Goes very well with that subtle cup of coffee.<br><br>And if you need a place to get some work done, it&#39;s a great place as well. With good wifi, and comfortable seating. But please practice some basic courtesy, come in and do these when they are not so busy, and don&#39;t hog the tables for too Long as well. It&#39;s a cafe and seatings are limited. <br><br>All in all, it&#39;s a great cafe. And it&#39;s one I can call home. Great job guys.

text: I was surprised to learn there is a cafe in my neighbourhood. Boo-yah!! The place is easily accessible if you come here by car, bus or even by foot. The carpark is so big that I envy those HDB residents living there.<br><br>Staff service was tip-top; friendly bunch of blokes. The cafe was just of the right ambience. It may look small from the outside, but I felt the place was cleverly and nicely put together that you don&#39;t feel cram like some cafes I&#39;ve been to.<br><br>Coming to the edibles, I had their chocolate tart, ice-cream topped brownie and white iced coffee... Nice! All nice! No complaints. Will definitely come back.

Mocha', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Mocha'}]
text: I like here! <br>Nice coffee, quiet, lovely environment, friendly staff..<br>Perfect for working alone with laptop..  <br>Good..  Really loving it..  Recommend to try the Mocha! Just $5..  Better than Starbucks<br>Fresh flower on every table..

Percolate Coffee has been around in the East for a bit but the location at the fringe of the Bedok heartland was and still is a deterrence to repeated visits. But upon word that they make a mean cuppa with the Nylon coffee beans in the east, i dragged myself out to this sleepy corner of Singapore for a couple of shots to regain my sanity. <br><br>The cozy shop accommodates about 30 pax, which would actually be a squeeze already. It&#39;s not a place to linger for long over brunch, since they also don&#39;t do large plates. So far i&#39;ve been lucky to be able to hang around for a bit over coffee and some bites.<br><br>I had Nylon&#39;s Four Chairs blend here the last time and it was well balanced and smooth with a nutty and fruity note ($4.50 for 5oz). On my second visit, it was changed to the Lucky Stars blend (for CNY), which was milder and lighter. I always go for Nylon over Papa Palheta (also offered here), as the latter tends to be too acidic for me. Filter coffee is also available here. <br><br>If you like croissants, then you cannot miss these from B.A.O. Christophe makes one of the best flaky and buttery French croissants in Singapore (from $3.50). Go with the classic Butter ones on its own or have it as a sandwich (from $7). And if you see the Chocolate Almond ($4.50), JUST GRAB IT. The localized Pandan Kaya Gula Melaka one didn&#39;t rock my socks though. <br><br>Percolate also has one of the most amazing Banana Date bread that i&#39;ve tasted. I have a feeling it&#39;s from the Muffinry (Drury Lane gets it from there too). For something fancier, get the breakfast loaf version shown above ($8) with mascarpone, berries, crushed almond and Hunters&#39; Kitchenette Almond Nut Butter. <br><br>For something slightly bigger, the Tom Yum Grilled Chicken on Ciabatta ($10) isn&#39;t a bad option with tender chicken chunks coated in a punchy  and salty tom yum mayonnaise sauce sandwiched in a fluffy ciabatta. It&#39;s a little salty and i found myself reaching for more water than I usually do after.<br><br>Percolate is a lovely spot that I&#39;d go back to again and again, if I&#39;m in the East that is. Worth a visit if you&#39;re around.

text: I was surprised to learn there is a cafe in my neighbourhood. Boo-yah!! The place is easily accessible if you come here by car, bus or even by foot. The carpark is so big that I envy those HDB residents living there.<br><br>Staff service was tip-top; friendly bunch of blokes. The cafe was just of the right ambience. It may look small from the outside, but I felt the place was cleverly and nicely put together that you don&#39;t feel cram like some cafes I&#39;ve been to.<br><br>Coming to the edibles, I had their chocolate tart, ice-cream topped brownie and white iced coffee... Nice! All nice! No complaints. Will definitely come back.

Excellent coffee. Stopped by for a takeaway, hence I didn&#39;t get to try the food. From I saw seating is a little cramp and cakes are slightly higher than normal pricing. A red velvet is $6? Was eyeing the chocolate coffee tart which is $4.50. I ordered a 5oz flat white that came with one shot of espresso. Added one more shot for 50¢ which was decent. Think that cup sizes should be bigger. 5oz was slightly bigger than a vending machines Milo cup so I finished that in like 5mins. Sizes there only come in 3 or 5oz. Compared to Starbucks, 8oz (tall size) this was really tiny. Latte art is good. Service is really good too. They should ask though if you&#39;d like sugar or something while ordering. Guess I&#39;m used to that in the cbd area. Coffee was smooth and I find worth the money but like I said, bigger portions please.

Opened about a few weeks back by a barista who worked previously in Loysel&#39;s Toy, Percolate has already gained a name for itself. Selling sandwiches, cakes and coffee, this place is flooded with people during the weekends (which is why I chose to go there on a weekday!)<br><br>It is interesting to note that the bakes and drinks here comes from various sources. The bakes and cakes here comes from Cakestand, a bakery located at Katong Shopping Centre that also operates an online order system. The pastries are from French bakery BAO. The tea comes from local tea company Amuse Projects, and the coffee? Papa Palheta&#39;s Terra Firma blend (of course!)<br><br>The drinks and sandwich menu is rather simple.<br><br>There is a high tea set which cost $8.50, consisting of any cakes + coffee/tea. The Chocolate Cake ($6) here feels firm and tasted great. Chocolate lovers will definitely like this.<br><br>The 5oz White ($4) tasted strong and smooth, but may not suit those who don&#39;t want their coffee to taste too acidic as this one can be slightly stronger.<br><br>Given their location (near the Bedok Town Centre), it is easy to visit the place especially since other cafes around Bedok are further inwards in Fengshan and doesn&#39;t really specialize in coffee.

text: Its about time Bedok has a niche cafe.. the staff are friendly.. the cupcakes is nice and i simply loved the 5oz coffee.. will definitely hang out here again.

3.5 stars. Food truck coffee - moves around the city so need to check when they are gonna be in a certain location<br><br>Coffee here is decent though their latte is a bit too milky / the espresso is not strong enough.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/IjiYJQ_met0scwtdHkT3Ng/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/coffee-bandits-singapore?reviewid=ZIDBkrQuIJKoKNZtCfCJgQ&select=IjiYJQ_met0scwtdHkT3Ng', 'altText': 'Photo of Coffee Bandits - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/w6XgUGfH85PVaGvBH2eiEQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/coffee-bandits-singapore?reviewid=ZIDBkrQuIJKoKNZtCfCJgQ&select=w6XgUGfH85PVaGvBH2eiEQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Coffee Bandits - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Vwtn7C45n0yoP0irwuqzjQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/coffee-bandits-singapore?reviewid=ZIDBkrQuIJKoKNZtCfCJgQ&select=Vwtn7C45n0yoP0irwuqzjQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Coffee Bandits - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/YCo52ftLTWZe0rO08zhfRA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/coffee-bandits-singapore?reviewid=ZIDBkrQuIJKoKNZtCfCJgQ&select=YCo52ftLTWZe0rO08zhfRA', 'altText': 'Photo of Coffee Bandits - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: This is a food truck that moves around.<br><br> Monday at SGH Blk 7<br>Tuesday at Fusionopolis @ one North <br>Wednesday at Singapore General Hospital Blk 7<br>Thursday at Slf Building, 510 Thomson Road<br> Friday at Fusionopolis @ One-North<br><br>And on weekends, this food truck will go to locations with events going on.<br><br>They sell sandwiches that changes weekly, muffins, cookies and ice cream.<br><br>But the main item that they sell is coffee. Their coffee from is liberty coffee. So it&#39;s so-so, it&#39;s not like a fantastic type of coffee bean. Alot of cafes these days are serving liberty coffee. <br><br>They have also started up a shop with a physical location in bukit merah that sells more main stream hipster cafe food.<br><br>But all in all, I still head to coffee bandits on tuesday and fridays, on my way to work from one-north mrt and I will grab a cup of coffee from them. Hot or iced mocha is what I normally grab. I miss their chendol affogato.

They&#39;re located outside Kopitiam at SGH near Outram Mondays and Wednesdays 8am-3pm from now till about August (2016) while Kopitiam is closed for renovations.<br><br>Soy latte ($4.50+$1 for the soy) - 3.5 stars<br>Thank you for the soy! Nothing special but it&#39;s nice to be able to get a soy latte here.<br><br>Apple cinnamon muffin ($3.50) - 3 stars<br>It&#39;s a good muffin - it&#39;s moist with an apple jam centre, and it&#39;s pretty big - but I&#39;m not a fan of crumble that isn&#39;t made on the spot and it was a bit sweet for me.<br><br>The best part was the service! They&#39;re really friendly. And the prices for the sandwiches are pretty good so I&#39;d try them another time. I&#39;d support them.

Incredible respite from the Singapore heat as well as the carb/oil heavy meals you will found around the city. I stopped here after seeing it featured on some websites; I ordered an acai bowl to go, it was absolutely refreshing, not too sweet, and it topped with fantastic granola, fresh peanut butter (worth the extra charge), and other fresh fruit. <br><br>Located in scenic Haji Lane, Limaa offers all you could want from full meals to quick juices. They have wifi, nice interior seating (yet a bit small), and the staff makes the experience even better as they&#39;re beyond kind and helpful.

text: Nice refreshing juices - fresh juice.  Friendly staff.  I had a delicious smoothie - strawberry, banana and yogurt.  Mmmm

Kopi C Siu Dai - 4 stars<br>Rich bittersweet flavor. One of the best kopis I&#39;ve had!<br><br>Kaya bun - 2.5 stars<br>Average. Not well toasted. Couldn&#39;t quite taste the kaya and the butter was unremarkable - overall the bun wasn&#39;t very fragrant or flavorful.

text: There are two areas to place your order. Apparently I queued at the wrong area. I stood behind a lady who placed her order at a small window facing the stairs. The lady stood there at the window to wait for her order. The staff did not ask for my order and another person just went right up to the window and placed her order effectively jumping the queue. I was only asked for my order after the 1st lady left with her food. I was told to sit down and only when I rounded the stall then I realized the actual stall front faced the side road and customers dining in could place their order there.<br><br>Yup. I was the blur one joining the wrong line for the takeaway orders. <br><br>I read about the french toast and how good it was. I had that and thought it was nothing special. The french toast with cold butter (yes!) and kaya was quite ordinary. <br><br>The coffee was ok, though I should probably have ordered the kopi-c version (with evaporated milk). The coffee was siew dai by default so I did not like it all that much. I like my local coffee the traditional way, thick and sweet. <br><br>The set at $4.40 for just coffee and french toast was not exactly cheap, considering the location. The pricing would be similar to the various coffee chains. The only reason to support it would be to keep local small F&amp;B alive.

Berseh Food Centre is really a gem hidden from yelp for some time. The coffee here is 5 stars makan sutra. It&#39;s kopi O is silky smooth, no sour coffee after taste. The guy inside made it that way. It&#39;s not heavy in the sense of taste but sure as good in perkin you up as any kopi O. Kopi Siew Tai (coffee with milk less sugar) is just as marvelous but it&#39;s probably not as distinct as other Kopi Siew Tai.<br><br>Kopi is as good as it gets and I suspect the &#34;kopi o&#34; song is composed here.

text: This place is inside Jl Bersih Food Center. Came at 10 and tried to order the French toast, but the only thing left from the bread selection is the baguette - so I ordered it along with a cup of iced coffee. The baguette is layered with egg and came with kaya sauce for dipping - never had this before and it tasted almost like a French toast. Nothing special on the coffee for me, it&#39;s just like any other kopitiam Kopi Peng.

text: As an out-of-country visitor, my Singapore coffee palette probably isn&#39;t very refined. That said, I was quickly addicted to the kopi experience and found the kopi and kaya toast here at Coffee Hut to be among my favorites. We had to come twice during our stay.

Dropped by around 11am on a weekday so I think I got these shortly after they were baked.<br><br>Matcha burnt cheese cruffin - 4.5 stars<br>Didn&#39;t toast this - the inside was gooey and delicious - and the cruffin was flaky and moist. I&#39;m not even a puff pastry fan.<br><br>Matcha burnt cheesecake - <br><br>Matcha almond croissant - 4.5<br>I figured Tiong Bahru bakery&#39;s matcha almond croissant would be hard to beat, but this didn&#39;t come in far behind! I had a 1/4 of this so I don&#39;t feel it&#39;s a fair review. But the bit I had was delicious. I&#39;ll have to get it again ;)<br><br>Wifi available, only cash and NETS.

text: One of my favorite bakeries in Singapore! Love how local flavors are incorporated into western-originated pastries &amp; cakes. Highly recommend the MSW cruffin and the atap chee rose cheesecake.

text: A tiny bakery with limited dine in area. The choices available were limited but fanciful. The coffee was made with cafe type of machine, although priced reasonable at $1.50 for a Kopi-O. Only cash and NETS are accepted for payments. Made your order and payments and collected food later when pager lighted up. Service maybe be a tab slow as there was only 2 to 3 staffs around.<br><br>Gula Jawa Sticky Rice (S$6)<br>Gula jawa glutinous rice, gula jawa genoise, coconut mousse<br>Such an interesting cake  which packed a layer of soft moist chewy glutinous rice between the soft fluffy sponge, topped with juicy nata de coco. <br><br>Just nice to pair with a cup of Teh-O (S$1.50) for tea. The tea was sweeten slightly when served.

text: Finally got an excuse to visit Keong Saik Bakery. Their signature products Sor Hei and green egg bun is gone by 5pm on a Saturday, so I went for a savory option - XO Lap Cheong Bun ($2.30). <br><br>The owner kindly offered to heat it up and yes, there is no other way you should have the XOLCB. The outside of the bun was crispy with the cheese and caramelized edges and the inside was soft and chewy. The lap cheong gave amazing umami flavor and I really liked that the dough wasn&#39;t sweet. <br><br>The owner kindly explained that the coffee was roasted rustica beans (didn&#39;t mean much to the non coffee connoisseur) and prepared in shots. Milk were frothed the western way and su su meant condensed milk was added. <br><br>The Kopi milo iced($3.80), less sweet, was perfect on a late afternoon. The ice didn&#39;t dilute my coffee but cooled it enough I didn&#39;t feel like I was boiling in the hot weather. I liked the coffee flavor, not too dark but not too milky. I didn&#39;t really taste milo though, but i still really enjoyed the taste. I was very pleased that the coffee wasn&#39;t too acidic and I&#39;m not suffering gastric discomfort (that I often do when I drink non cold brew coffee). <br><br>The cafe was quite quiet at 5-6pm but started to pick up as I was leaving. Good time for a nice catch up with friends! But I felt I was probably too loud for the peace. Most people had take outs when I visited. You can also try samples of their bread as you pay at the cashier. Longan bread was surprisingly tasty. <br><br>Need a pick me up in the middle of the day? Drop by Keong Saik bakery for a snack and ang moh coffee done local style with local prices. Very nice coffee and I&#39;ll be back for more!

text: One of the most delightful streets in Chinatown with its typical mix of old style houses and buildings from the thirties, and its Singaporean palette of fantastic bright colors. The beginning of the street - off South Bridge Road - is rather prozaic, but there is a flee market in a left side street that is described elsewhere. The nicest part is after the Indian Ganesh temple. Do also explore the side streets and look up...

text: We stopped for a quick lunch - very nice ambience next to the riverside. While the chicken Milanese wrap was good, the pan seared salmon was just average..if you want a late lunch/brunch with a good view, you may consider this..

Robertson Quay is undergoing some serious revival with new hotels and changes in the food scene along the river. A homegrown favorite SPRMRKT has expanded and set up shop at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute (STPI) Creative Workshop &amp; Gallery. I&#39;ve walked past several times but only noticed their bistro concept SPRMRKT Daily. Little did i know that their Kitchen &amp; Bar, which serves refined European food, is tucked away upstairs through a side stairway.<br><br>The spot is absolutely gorgeous in the day with expansive views of the idyllic riverside. Lunch sets are offered, starting from $30, served with coffee or tea. They have also started their weekend brunches and we say grab a table now!<br><br>For lunch, start with a simple but wholesome Brussels &amp; Roots with a honey clove dressing. The vegetables are simply steamed- golden baby beetroots and baby turnips along with the Australian Brussels sprouts. The garden of greens is flavored with pops of umami from the slow-baked tomatoes seasoned with thyme, garlic, sea salt and olive oil.<br><br>For lunch, go for a lighter Pan-Roasted Chilean Sea Bass. The fish is seared and basted with butter, then finished in the oven with a simple touch of salt, pepper, and lemon juice. A refreshing ratatouille adds a juicy crunch to the mix. We agreed with the chicken stock flavored polenta which was rich and velvety with some Parmesan sharpness.<br><br>For dinner, the Firefly Squid ($24) surprised us with a bacon-like smokiness in the meatless cauliflower puree. I have no idea how but i&#39;d take all the cauliflower puree as a guiltless replacement. The special firefly squid from Japan is intensely flavored, having been marinated overnight in soya sauce, sake, mirin and brown sugar. <br><br>Definitely order the Octopus &amp; Prawn ($24). This has to be one of the best (if not the best) Spanish octopus i&#39;ve eaten this year. The octopus is simmered whole with mirepoix and other spices and white wine for 2 - 3 hours before grilling on a plancha. The crispy skin and that tender flesh were unforgettable.<br><br>I didn&#39;t like the Fjord Trout ($19). I&#39;m not sure if it&#39;s due to the way it&#39;s cooked- mi cuit style, sous vide with salt, but the flesh was mushy and powdery. The flavor was great, just not the texture. <br><br>Fresh pasta are a must these days. If you like something really meaty, the Malbec Oxtail Pasta ($32) with a smoky Scamorza will satisfy. The oxtail is braised with Malbec (my favorite wine) to impart that berries, plum, and chocolate flavor. Perfect comfort food. Can i have another glass of Malbec to go with this please?<br><br>A favorite at SPRMKT is the Smoked Lobster Tail ($42) which features a cold smoked and then seared Maine lobster with toasted garlic panko bread crumbs and a Mac n Cheese. The cheese sauce is a lot lighter than usual as they have added pumpkin puree to the Emmental, aged Parmesan, and Mozzarella mix. <br><br>I absolutely love the Twice Cooked Chicken Roulade ($28). I&#39;ve not had a chicken so good in a while. The juicy chicken thigh is brined overnight and then rolled with a creamy spinach and mushroom duxelle, before being cooked sous vide and then shallow fried for that amazing Peking-duck-like crispy skin. It&#39;s great on its own, with its own jus, or with the amazing curry cauliflower puree (seriously they are so good with their cauliflowers). <br><br>I can go on forever about the other tender juicy red that is the Stockyard Côte de Boeuf ($94). This 200 days grain-fed 600g Australian bone-in beef ribs is good for 2. The ribs are first coated with a house made Creole spice rub before being seared and roasted. Drizzle a little of that beef jus made with roasted bones, red wine, tomatoes, and veal jus for some tart umami. The meat is served with mixed mushrooms, roasted rosemary tomatoes and vine-ripened tomatoes. Perfect date meal!<br><br>End your meal with a fragrant and light Earl Grey Creme Brûlée ($16) scented with a lemon lavender streusel base and fresh seasonal fruits.<br><br>For something rich and earthy, the Three Beet Chocolate Lava Cake ($18) delighted us with the medley of textures created with the versatile root. Of course, we cannot resist a 70% Valrhona dark chocolate lava cake. I wouldn&#39;t be surprised to see more of this beetroot and raspberry sorbet on the market. I&#39;m already seeing a lot of beetroot on the menu of many noteworthy restaurants.

text: This place is at one of the locales in the Tyler Print Institute building at Robertson Quay. At first is a bit confusing, the name suggests a market, and they do sell a few (overpriced) fruits and vegetables, but it can also appear as a bakery, cafe, restaurant, takeaway or souvenir store. They seem to have a bit of everything.<br><br>As a restaurant they have few tables outside where they serve an interesting menu. Ambitious might be the proper word to describe it. They have common dishes, mostly Western, but made with a slight, almost imperceptible, twist, mainly done by adding a touch of a different flavour, which lifts the plate. For example, the sweet potato fries come with a well-balanced curry mayonnaise. More importantly, the food I&#39;ve had there a couple of times is done with care and precision. Prices seem rather high, but portions are on the generous side, so I think they&#39;re fair (it&#39;s Robertson Quay anyway). Burgers are big and delicious, and pasta is served in more than enough amounts. Mainstream beers are expensive at 10++ for a miserable half pint, but they have good craft beers at the same price for a bottle. Coffee is not bad, but nothing to rave about. Cakes are tasty, worth trying. An important thing is they make an effort in offering more local products rather than imports, maybe they could make that more explicit.<br><br>Inside the shop, there are three tables that serve as a cafe, and there&#39;s a shelf that showcases souvenirs of the interesting kind, I&#39;m talking about Singlish &#34;dictionaries&#34; and Teochew recipe books instead of Merlion keychains. While these quirky souvenirs are quickly becoming mainstream, they also sell books by Math Paper Press, which are truly good local gifts.<br><br>SPRMKT has a little bit of many different things and, sometimes, it&#39;s not quite clear what to expect. It is, after all, a place to have a nice dining experience and find some amusing local products. It is worth a try, the food is better than it would seem.

text: Was there for breakfast. Good food, nice variety. Great attentive service. First time, since they just opened. But will def be back for more.

Jewel&#39;s Red Velvet latte - not to be missed', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Jewel's Red Velvet latte - not to be missed"}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/U9Bmgh4YXSMycxgRa2chtg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=5eqMoKKWLZCPGDsenJmGvQ&select=U9Bmgh4YXSMycxgRa2chtg', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: My daily coffee fix - I cannot believe that I waited so long to tell the world about their amazing coffee and service :)<br><br>Thanks to Jewel, I became an absolute coffee snob. Their baristas are true experts, their coffee beans carefully selected - and you can pick from two coffee bean choices every day - with the coffee itself being pure velvety, strong goodness.<br><br>Ask for the stamp card if it is not automatically given to you, as you&#39;ll get a free coffee once your card is full.<br><br>The staff is cheerful and seems to love what they&#39;re doing. Food is quite good - I&#39;ve had pasta, bacon &amp; egg muffin and a ham &amp; cheese melt before.<br><br>My current crush is their Red Velvet latte, which is an absolute revelation that I don&#39;t know how to live without anymore. Good for them, tricky for me ;)

Choose your beans', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Choose your beans'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/UnvQnQrV7jFC7VcuOzjvOQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=aMohnkWrcBQMLB_Mbsz9xQ&select=UnvQnQrV7jFC7VcuOzjvOQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Excellent single origin coffee spot. Jewel offers a couple of bean choices for your coffee order. Today I enjoyed a flat white with beans from Las Brumas El Salvador&#39;s 60 hectare fertile farm located on the Santa Ana Volcano. If you need something to pad your coffee, there is also a good selection of pastries, pasta and sandwiches. <br><br>Also, if you want to learn more about the art and passion of &#34;cupping&#34; (coffee tasting), sign up for one if their free coffee cupping sessions.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/e0EyjSJfWjOyZE1-ubjZ0w/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=BPDZK22zNxc5w5OuH6aIWA&select=e0EyjSJfWjOyZE1-ubjZ0w', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Toast, scrambled eggs and sausages', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Toast, scrambled eggs and sausages'}]
text: Coffee - I&#39;d recommend the Gibraltar. I&#39;m a personal fan of their Sumatran beans.<br><br>Food - I thought maybe I was hungry the first time I went hence it tasted so good. Made a return journey, just as pleased. Sausages and tomatoes hit the spot.<br><br>Service - friendly and unobtrusive. Both times I was there working on my laptop and never made to feel that I was &#34;taking up space&#34;. Seating was adequate, the al fresco area is always nice to people watch.

Nice little coffee place right in the heart of CBD. Good place to grab a coffee and work, there is quite a crowd around so seating might be a bit tricky. I liked the coffee they used for the latte, very strong chocolaty flavors.

I hardly return to cafes in Singapore but I have been a huuuggee fan of Jewel Coffee since I join my gym. I&#39;d like to say that our cafe scene in Singapore is good, but in all honesty it&#39;s only cafes like Jewel that make it good. <br><br>Their coffee and the standard of their coffee is a benchmark. I&#39;ve been to both their outlets and not only is the coffee good but the food at Rangoon Rd is pretty awesome as well. <br><br>Forgive their small outlet in CBD, it&#39;s obviously catered for take &amp; go but I&#39;m guessing that it&#39;s the only way they can sustain the high rental in the area. <br><br>When somebody ask me which is my favorite cafe in Singapore, Jewel is usually the first name that pops into my head.

This is one of two Jewel outlets in Singapore. The other one is on Rangoon Road and this smaller one is on Shenton Way in the CBD. Not surprisingly the guests and feel of the places differ a lot. This is more the go to place for a caffeine fix or a quick lunch for all the people slaving away in the CBD and unfortunately that also impacts the service here as it often feels rushed, not that friendly and occasionally the quality of the coffee is not at the level I am expecting here. <br><br>That said the coffee is usually good and there is at least two beans to choose from and several different brew methods. I try to come after morning rush but before the lunch rush as the quality of the coffee is usually better when they have more time for it. The seating is limited indoors but there are some tables outside where it is fine to hang out for longer periods of time. <br><br>The food is very much something that can be skipped. There are so many better options to get your stomach filled around here. Still it is a pretty safe bet for a cup of coffee when in the CBD although I would personally rather head to the New Black for filter coffee and 6 oz Espresso for espresso based beverages but this is also good.

I like Jewel, it&#39;s around the corner from my office, the people are friendly, and the coffee is STRONG!  The only downside is that they don&#39;t make flavored lattees, only the regular kind.  The muffins are excellent and the prices are decent!  I also like the outdoor tables, which are perfect for a client meeting, or quick catch up.  Or in my case, provides a quick escape from the office in the middle of the day.  Great choice!

text: I just stumbled across Jewel on my lunch break. I&#39;m always on the lookout for a great cup of coffee, so even though I wasn&#39;t planning to get coffee, I obviously took my discovery as a sign from the universe that I should get a cup. <br><br>Since Jewel is located directly across from Dimbulah, I turned to my fellow Yelpers for guidance on which joint to try &amp; I&#39;m so glad I went with the Jewel reviewers (Jewelers?).<br><br>I got a basic mocha &amp; it is phenomenal. I am drinking it as-is, no milk or sugar or whatever added, &amp; it&#39;s delish - smooth, mellow, nutty, with slight citrus undertones. I could drink this for days!<br><br>Another reviewer mentioned that Jewel&#39;s coffees are strong &amp; can be bitter; I don&#39;t find mine bitter at all, but I should mention that I normally don&#39;t add sugar to flavored coffees as I find the syrup more than sweet enough. <br><br>This is def the best coffee I&#39;ve had in Singapore &amp; my only regret is that I&#39;ve lived across the street from Jewel for 4+ months &amp; only discovered it today.

Cappuccino @ Jewel', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cappuccino @ Jewel'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QM4nSC50WzBLzoCODeJNJQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=s5o4MkuCTQSN50PQ92xWFw&select=QM4nSC50WzBLzoCODeJNJQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fWT2l95d9zuuczaRt0CyvA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=s5o4MkuCTQSN50PQ92xWFw&select=fWT2l95d9zuuczaRt0CyvA', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Single espresso @ Jewel Coffee', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Single espresso @ Jewel Coffee'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Vm-2qLscqO6f9wn-Yu0jPA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-8?reviewid=s5o4MkuCTQSN50PQ92xWFw&select=Vm-2qLscqO6f9wn-Yu0jPA', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: A haven for coffee lovers in the CDB, Jewel coffee is doing some interesting things with single origin coffees, and with different brewing methods. <br><br>Espresso - the volume was perfect, with a medium dark crema. The dominant flavour in the shot is citrus - but it&#39;s a shot where the astringency is very evident - as much a sensation as a flavour, an intense hit of citrus that awakens your taste buds, with an aftertaste that fades out slowly. The mouthfeel has some syrupy elements, but not overwhelmingly so either. <br><br>The choice of single origin beans is a nice touch - when I visited, beans from Costa Rica and El Salvador were being served. Each has distinct tasting notes, however I found that the citrus elements were dominant in each. This is an intensely floral shot, and may not be to everyone&#39;s tastes. I&#39;ll never complain about single origin coffees on a menu - it&#39;s a sign of how far coffee culture has come, and it directly benefits the farmers who grow the beans in question. However, it could be a good idea to have one strong citrus single origin and one robust, earthy and less floral single origin paired with each other. <br><br>The cappuccino that I ordered came with smooth foam that complemented, rather than drowned out, the underlying coffee flavour. The layer of microbubbles added the required smooth mouthfeel, while allowing the coffee flavour to dominate. The layer of foam and serving size were just as they should be, ensuring that this was separate and distinct from a latte. The latte art, and contrast of light on medium dark foam, was a welcome touch.<br><br>There is a good selection of drinks on the menu, with Chemex, V60, Syphon and Iced coffees available also. It&#39;s a good coffee choice for anyone working in the Shenton Way area, however it is slightly more expensive, with an espresso priced at $4.20.

I&#39;m fortunate enough to have Jewel right around the corner from my office. I&#39;ve been going to these guys on-and-off for over a year and while I&#39;m not there on a daily basis I can attest to their coffee being of fairly reliable quality.<br><br>Jewel offer only single origin coffee on their espresso machine. I think this is overkill as there&#39;s nothing wrong with a good blend but the origins they have on offer (they usually have two to choose from) are normally pretty good.<br><br>Cafe owners passionate about coffee usually find it difficult to find service staff in SIngapore that can match them in knowledge and obsession, which usually affects the quality of the service. But the service quality at Jewel has definitely improved dramatically since I first started coming here which is very heartening to see.<br><br>My only gripe about the place is that it&#39;s obviously set up more to cater to the take-away office crowd (of which I am also part) than the drink-in coffee drinker. This is evidenced by their lack of seating inside the shop itself (they have a sizeable al fresco area), their use of bar-stools and the self service set up. While I understand why a business owner would employ self service, I&#39;m just not a fan. I don&#39;t like juggling two coffees while opening a door. It&#39;s a recipe for disaster if you&#39;re as clumsy as I am.<br><br>Bottom line though, these guys serve some of the best coffee in Singapore and their sandwiches are pretty good also. Give it a shot.

text: Gourmet coffee shops are becoming a trend around the island, especially in the financial and business districts - perhaps owing to the fact that people work hard in Singapore and caffeine is in demand. <br><br>This shop is known to serve double shots for all its cups of coffee. You get to choose your preferred beans while their chalk boards teach you a thing or two about brewing coffee. It&#39;s a great place to have a quick meeting or to catch up with a friend. Unfortunately the indoor, air-conditioned area is small so you may have to sit outside when it is busy. I had a cafe latte for $5.80 that was really strong and kept me going till 2am that night.

text: My go to coffee joint whenever i&#39;m in the area. The ambiance is nothing fancy, but the coffee is probably the 2nd best I&#39;ve had in Singapore (pm me if you want the first), and I drink a lot of coffee! Try the flat white, Melbourne style and with velvety microfoam. They also usually have at least 2 selections of beans to choose from.

text: First visit. Had a Gibraltar. For coffee lovers who like their joe slightly bitter with an astringent quality, this is for you. <br><br>Decaf lovers this is not your place. <br><br>My fav latte is still at Liberty. I applaud SG for offering so many decent cafe options!

My favorite coffee joint in the CBD area. It&#39;s a little bit on the pricier side, but the coffee is worth it and you can get a punch card and earn a free drink after 9 drinks. I personally love the flat white ($6) and the iced mocha ($7.50).

text: i finally got a flat white whilst here in singapore.  i miss them so much from my london days, b/c they are hard to find in the states (or, impossible, rather).<br><br>the coffees here are expensive, and if you want soy, it&#39;s an extra $1!  however, you do get to choose the type of bean you want.  i chose a brazilian bean today, b/c it had chocolate and caramel notes, and i was not disappointed!  the other choice was sumatran, so my indonesian cowkr got that one and liked it as well.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=-5YMIME_WEin_by41Bj-3Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/XzO0vlN24SvnUbjEiiWCCQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jian Hao T.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Jian Hao T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=-5YMIME_WEin_by41Bj-3Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 6, 'reviewCount': 21, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Heard a lot about this cafe/bar so decided one day I should drop by and try this place. It was quite crowded and service staff was non existent. But that&#39;s fine, this is normal for Singapore as I can understand during this period we are severely lacking of service staff. <br><br>Waited at least 20-30 minutes to get seated. Food was average, 6/10 in my opinion. Nothing fancy. But why is it rated 4 star by me ? Just when things was going downhill for me, I spotted people drinking from a bottle of cold brew which looks retro yet very good taste in terms of design. Ordered cold brew coffee, wow.... within 10 mins, ordered cold brew chocolate drink, WOW.... 10/10....<br><br>So that&#39;s what they are good at! Now, I&#39;m a frequent customer, but pardon me, I always only go there specially to purchase few bottles of cold brew to store for the next 4-5 days !!

The best cold brew', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The best cold brew'}]
text: Who doesn&#39;t love Old Hen Coffee Bar? What&#39;s not to love? :)<br><br>I had this vague impression that they opened a new F&amp;B outlet and this one closed down. So, I was actually on my way to Enchanted Cafe (situated next door) and I was pleasantly surprised to see that Old Hen Coffee Bar is still open! It was a quick after-thought visit that let me to pop in at 9.30pm (30 minutes just before they close!). I had a Mocha earlier but I was craving for a good old cold brew served in a bottle - I bought the $6.50 milky brown version and all traces of regrets flew out the window! The right balance of coffee and milk was perfect and yes, I didn&#39;t care that I was drinking coffee at 9.30pm!<br><br>The place, though small, was quite empty save for a couple at the corner on the laptop (plugged in to the wall sockets). The young girl behind the counter was quite cheerful, even though it&#39;s so late and that perked my spirits up a little. I&#39;ve been to Old Hen numerous times while it was packed and where I literally had to jostle for good seats (I love the window bar seats) or get take-away coffee (but then where&#39;s the fun in takeaway coffee when you can&#39;t enjoy the atmosphere and people-watch?), but the atmosphere two nights ago was just right.<br><br>Tip: Recommended to go slightly after dinner, or maybe near closing time if you want a quite respite.

Menu changes', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Menu changes'}]
text: I can see why my friend likes the waffle here and is a regular visitor to this cafe.<br><br>I finally made it here after months of hearing the raves about the waffle. I am never a huge waffle fan but this place can change my mind.<br><br>The waffle is light, crispy (not overly hard/dry) and just so yummy with the greek yogurt and apple compote, crushed pistachios and salted caramel sauce. You have to eat it immediately (within 15 minutes or so) as it does get a bit flat and tiny bit soggy after a while. That means it is not so heavy that you will feel like a ball of dough is inside your stomach. <br><br>The other crowd favorite is the cold brew white coffee. It is served in a glass bottle like a beer and you can either drink it from the bottle or a glass (ask for it). They do have straws which are too short for the bottle so it will sink. I fold the top of the straw and tuck it inside the bottle neck so it will not fall in. The coffee is creamy milky and not too sweet.<br><br>There are also some tea cakes in the display case next to the cashier. The lemon earl grey tea cake is nice and again not too sweet. I just find the slices a bit too thin. <br><br>The menu for food is limited but I think it is good if whatever they have taste delicious. Do well in a few dishes rather than have many choices which are mediocre or bad tasting. <br><br>I will be back here if I do want to have waffle again.

text: A small, cosy place to have a good brew alone or catch up with a friend. The cold brew here is beyond words-the best I&#39;ve ever had! If it&#39;s your first time here, do try the creamy white cold brew. ($6.50)<br><br>The food here is average and worth a try if you&#39;re hungry and here for their coffee. The seating area is rather limited, so do note that if you&#39;re thinking of camping here with your laptop! That being said, they do have free wifi, power sockets and water as well as a few atas magazines such as the likes of CEREAL for the hipster in you or as a prop for that Instagram flatlay.<br><br>(Minus that one star as it&#39;s hard to find a seat, especially on weekends!)

Matcha Latte $5', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Matcha Latte $5'}]
text: This place is run and owned by 3 brothers. Twins Ivan and Terry and younger brother Mason. Lovely chaps, friendly, unpretentious and bright, much like the inside of the Old Hen itself.<br><br>The cold brew is popular. $6.50 for a white served in glass bottles. The date is written on and the printed label says it should be drunk within 10 days. I&#39;ve had it twice and I don&#39;t really drink cold coffee but this was so yummy, I was craving it on the next hot day! 2nd friend 2nd visit - she was also remarking that she normally prefers hot coffee but she was really enjoying this as well. We had one hot one cold to taste test..for your benefit of course.<br><br>The latte is $4.50, currently from Yellow Bird blend from Oriole Roasters. Second time the microfoam was present, kudos! Both times coffee tasted good anyhow.<br><br>They had some cakes and a few savoury items only when I first went. They sought some feedback from me and 1st friend on the chicken cheese wrap. They themselves had prewarned us it was small. Glad to see this 2nd trip that the price has been revised to $6.50, down a dollar.<br><br>I also tried the waffles - friend found it a bit dry. I found it crisp and quite tasty and with the yogurt and blueberries didn&#39;t notice the dryness but it could have a bit more fruit though. At $9 for a full 4 quarter waffle, it was reasonably priced.<br><br>They had a new off menu item they were testing - crabmeat and coleslaw wrap. But they served it to us as a sandwich for a more substantial bite. Crabmeat was tasty and like the chicken cheese wrap, the fillings were perfectly seasoned and very tasty.<br><br>They seem to be slowly expanding the menu. Very sensible. We also tried the croque monsieur at $7.50 for the 2nd trip. Toasty comfort food on good bread. My friend said she had the croque from DB Moderne recently and this was way better as the DB one was just so salty. I notice a theme here..food is really well balanced, simple but tasty fare. Even the baby spinach salads they serve on the side (nice touch instead of cheaper mixed leaves or lettuce) had dressing that was yummy and just the right mix of sweet and vinegar.<br><br>Location is good for me so I can see myself dropping by again. I loved sitting by the bar having a chat with the guys and my friend. Don&#39;t take my seat!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/63OpmblUA3n6Pbp20JlCTw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/old-hen-coffee-bar-singapore-2?reviewid=8RfQfn7W0Hs0V7dFI9_irg&select=63OpmblUA3n6Pbp20JlCTw', 'altText': 'Photo of Old Hen Coffee Bar - Singapore, Singapore. Waffle.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Waffle.'}]
text: I came here for a UYE organized by Cindy Q, and I&#39;m glad I came, because I hardly come to this part of Farrer Park.<br><br>I had a waffle, which I felt was good, nicely browned, and crispy, with yogurt and blueberries. Yum! I did feel a bit meh about feeling forced to order it because I&#39;ve been trying to go vegetarian for the short term and it was the only non-meat item on the menu. I would have liked a salad with grilled veggies or an avocado sandwich.... just saying.<br><br>I didn&#39;t have the coffee because I am hyper-sensitive to caffeine, but everyone seems to love the cold brew in the glass bottles. I guess part of the novelty is opening bottled coffee bottled by the cafe itself? I dungeddit, but perhaps it really is out of this world.<br><br>Cindy Q generously ordered some cakes for us to try, along with 2 or 3 other cakes on the house. They ranged from good to okay, but I only would order the banana slice I guess. The red velvet was soso, especially if you are like me - if you like thick cream cheese frosting!<br><br>Would I come back again? Maybe. It&#39;s not too far from the MRT station, and has a cosy atmosphere.

This is one of several nice cafes that have popped up in Rangoon Road and the surrounding area. As we were staying fairly close by for a week we did explore the area a bit and ended up visiting this place and a few others.<br><br>First things first, the coffee is good. The guys know what they are doing. The cold brew in the bottle is very good, it is available both with milk and balck. For me it is a given that one would not want to ruin it with milk but apparently a lot of people prefer it that way. They also offer a rotating selection of filter coffees. I tried a nice Rwandan coffee but also interesting beans from Bangkok&#39;s Roast and some other micro roasters. <br><br>They do also offer very nice sounding teas and other drinks as well as of course espresso based beverages. Had a very nice grilled sandwich and the cakes looked excellent so no need to go elsewhere for food.<br><br>The space is nice and fairly cozy, it is a bit small, the seats are not super comfortable and there is no free wifi so perhaps not the place one spends several hours. A really good place for coffee in Singapore and with the friendly service this place is my top choice in the area.

text: Honestly not sure what the fuss is about.<br><br>Saw decent crowds in the cafe, so I decided to try it some time. <br><br>Their brunch menu is pretty standard for a cafe (no proper kitchen, so everything is toasted or pre-made) - waffles, toast, granola, salad, etc. I ordered a Croque Monsiere (ham and cheese on toasted bread) and a matcha milk.<br><br>The Croque Monsiere was decent, but nothing to shout about. The matcha milk was pretty good (very lightly sweetened and not bitter). <br><br>However, the cafe itself was small and seating was not cozy, which takes away from the experience. When I&#39;m paying cafe prices, I expect it to be nice, intimate and cosy. It wasn&#39;t. They also don&#39;t accept credit cards, which is not really acceptable for the kind of food and prices they charge.<br><br>I&#39;ve heard their cold brew coffee is good - I&#39;m not a coffee person, so I can&#39;t judge that. But based on everything else, I don&#39;t think I would go back.

text: Though the place is kinda small with limited choices on the menu, Old Hen serves very good coffee! The place is quite cozy with a communal table and an outdoor seating area. Had the chicken burrito which was very tasty. It was served with a salad that had nice tangy taste, adding a tad of freshness to the whole dish. Old Hen is definitely one of the better cafes in Singapore!

Off the main strip cafe that serves decent food and coffee in a trendy atmosphere. Sitting mostly communal style, the coffee could be stronger but should suit most drinkers. Love that you can buy their cold brew as take out in a cute brown beer bottle :)

text: Disappointed. The cold chocolate is worse than magnolia chocolate milk. White coffee is bland. Carrot cake is soggy . Not coming back again

Chili crab pasta ($17++= $20) - 4.5 stars<br>Huge portion! Lots of fettuccine, and better still ample crab meat and even soft shell crab! Taste was spicy enough to make time perspire but for some reason the flavor was a tad lacking. Not enough for me to complain though.<br><br>I love the decor here - the spacious minimalist interior and huge windows! Coming back for sure.

Crabmeat fettuccine  $16', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Crabmeat fettuccine  $16'}]
text: Crossings offers quality food in a casually nice ambiance, with all profits going to charity. Whenever a restaurant has an open kitchen, I know that they pride in the food they prepare, with nothing to hide. I was very satisfied with the items I ordered: The crabmeat fettuccine, mushroom soup, sweet potato crossings, and Americano.<br><br>Taking a star away for the sweet potato fries which could have been more flavourful (or come with a side of sauce). Otherwise fantastic experience, will definitely return to try other items from the menu!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dIDID17NtJceFT3CeRKTZw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/crossings-cafe-singapore?reviewid=eLXMbIuiwEIXx-qwvBRUEg&select=dIDID17NtJceFT3CeRKTZw', 'altText': 'Photo of Crossings Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Went to Crossings Cafe for lunch to celebrate my dad&#39;s birthday.  Its a Saturday afternoon and it was crowded.  Luckily I made a reservation.<br><br>We ordered the quesadillas and chicken wings for appetisers. The quesadillas were good, even though the fillings were distributed a little unevenly. Chicken wings were good too, with a very good crunch to them, but just slightly over-salty. <br><br>For mains, we had the laksa, braised beef shin, chicken parmigiana and honey berry ribs. The laksa was surprisingly the best dish of the lot, although 12.90 for laksa is rather expensive. The parmigiana was tasty, but don&#39;t order it if you don&#39;t like your food deep fried. Some of the ends were almost charred. Almost. The beef shin was tagged to be the best dish of the lot, but unfortunately it was pretty ordinary,like stir fried beef at a zhichar stall. The honey Berry ribs were alright, although I couldn&#39;t taste the honey or Berry in the sauce. The ribs themselves were fall-odf-the-bone tender, but slightly underseasoned. <br><br>Now all the food was served with impeccable timing. The appetisers were served first, and once they were done, all the mains came together..  Except the ribs. Unfortunately the waiter forgot to key in my order, and the ribs only arrived 15 minutes after everyone else had finished their mains. The waiter was of course apologetic,and I found it hard to lose my cool when scripture was hanging on the wall right in front of me. <br><br>Overall, the food was good but somehow just missed the mark by a little bit. If it weren&#39;t for the forgotten order, I&#39;d have given it 5 stars.

text: Been wanting to try out this place for about a month now after chancing upon reviews on Yelp and of course to aid social enterprises along the way. <br><br>Came here after attending a visual art exhibition at Singapore Arts Museum (walkable distance) and since there were quite a number of space, we managed to get seated on a comfy sofa like chair. <br><br>The waiter approached us checking whether we would want some iced water while we decide on our orders. It was a nice professional gesture from their end. <br><br>After browsing through a one double sided menu, I decided to order the following.<br><br>1) Wanted to order root beer but it was out of stock. Same with my friends&#39; orders of Ginger beer.<br>2) Decided to order Snapple&#39;s pink lemonade instead.<br>3) Chilli crab pasta sounded good at that moment so decided to order that. They ran out of Fettuccine so I had to change the pasta to spaghetti instead. Verdict: pasta was warm when it was served, chewy and tender in terms of texture. The  deep fried soft shell crab were both delicious and crunchy (managed to get the ones with eggs) and the Crossings&#39; own chilli crab claw meat sauce were flavorful and hint of spicy made the dish special. (definitely recommended)<br>4) My friend ordered fish and chips. The fish batter was pretty good and the portion of the fish fillet was bigger than expected too. <br>5) Hazelnut molten cake with ice cream. The dish was warm when it arrived to our table. The chocolate was a little bitter but the cake was moist and soft. Combined with the vanilla ice cream, it is one of best lava cake in Singapore. <br><br>Overall, price wise it was quite affordable and considering that profits will be directed to charities made this place a gem. The service was excellent too as they checked on the customers&#39; needs quickly when customers raised their hands. As my friends and I left for this place, we were also greeted with a thanks. Will be back soon for more yummy goodies :)

text: Though waiting time can take a little longer but the food never disappoints. As a social enterprise, I am very impressed with the level of service delivered by servers who are challenged in different special ways. They are professional and extremely polite. <br><br>The greatest I derive from dining at this place is the fact that not only do I get good food and good service, all profits are donated to charity! So as I enjoy a good meal, I am also able to contribute to the society. What more can I ask?<br><br>There are many places that use the term social enterprise very loosely and patrons suffer either from high price (in the name of social cause and benefit) or bad food/service and we are expected to be understanding because the special needs or at-risk individuals are involved. That should not be the case. Quality and experience should not be compromised for the sake of social good. <br><br>I fully support Crossings because they have created an environment that bring out the best in all the staff, regardless of their special needs and patrons are always well taken care of. Respect!

text: Nice cafe with a meaningful concept and tasty food. It is a social enterprise which hires disadvantaged people. I had aglio olio with mushroom and bacon whereas my friends had chilli crab pasta. We also shared sweet potato fries. The dishes were all well done and service was attentive. I would highly recommend checking out this cafe and contributing to society in a small way.

text: I always go cos I want to support this local social enterprise cafe. They hire kids with disabilities or are disenfranchised or marginalized. For this fact alone, I will go support them. But more importantly, I love their coffees as they are yums and come in nice mason jars. Additionally, their sweet potato fries are substantial for an appetizer and very yummy. Oh gosh. I am drooling.

text: Modest little social enterprise cafe on Waterloo street. Prompt service and cheap food. The ribs I had were a ribstickingly generous portion. Could&#39;ve done with a stronger marinade. But the sweet potato fries were delicious. <br>The spicy coriander fish was good. Decent slab of fish and the coriander paste was tasty and nicely calibrated. I like that the orange juice tasted fresh squeezed not concentrate. Place was bright and buzzy and there&#39;s free wifi. <br>Good place to grab quick bite and I love the social enterprise driven nature. Go support support!

text: I had fish and chips, and honestly speaking, taste way better than your regular chain of fish and chips. Fish is breaded and the chips are those thicker fries. And suprisingly, very well fried and all the strands taste almost the same. Even the salad and the dressing harmonise well. The staffs are always ready to serve. Definitely coming back monthly!
