text: This café is worth a visit if you&#39;re in the area. It&#39;s another one of those café-in-neighborhood, except this one has a Kodak photo printing station as well, and it has a social enterprise component to their business. So rather cool. <br><br>Payment in cash, unless you&#39;re eating with several people and your bill is over $40, then Credit Cards are accepted. <br><br>Come here if you want to print photos from a Kodak photo station. And if you want good American fare, decent desserts, and all the while supporting a social enterprise. The café is nicely tucked inside a neighborhood with minimal parking but that shouldn&#39;t be too much of a problem.

The View from Outside, Baristart', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The View from Outside, Baristart'}]
text: *Coffee Snob Intro*<br>When you&#39;re let go from a company the locations you frequent many many coffee shops.<br><br>These wonderful roasteries provide the perfect balance of professional attitude, casual attire, and passionate delivery to aid you in your job search.<br><br>I&#39;m going to rate a bunch of coffee shops based on this metric and a few others and provide an overall rating for the experience.<br><br>----------------------------------<br>OVERALL: 4 stars<br><br>Ambience: 4<br>Coffee: 4<br>Food: N/A (did not try)<br>Meeting Place: 4<br>Working Space: 4<br>----------------------------------<br><br>*Coffee Review*<br>Baristart is a solid 4-star coffee venue ticking all the boxes! If you can handle the heat I suggest you sit outside at the slim table and enjoy the people watching in Tras Street which is an interesting distraction from your digital device ;) <br><br>Inside is a very slick &#39;n&#39; slim modern coffee shop which buzzes with activity. You order at the counter, take a buzzer, then wait for your coffee order to be ready back at the counter. This actually helps to keep that area free of a queue clutter --- and why are we all standing around waiting anyways when we have our stupid friend Nancy&#39;s endless insta stories to catch up on? [Note to Nancy: No one cares about your ugly cat Minxy!]<br><br>If I come here to work I generally pick the spot at the high chairs, with the wall-garden, facing the front door. This maximises serenity and peripheral optics.<br><br>The coffee has some solid options (usually fruity or nutty for the single origin aficionado&#39;s) and I almost always opt for the dark nutty single origin varieties as I like a dark &#39;n&#39; rich roast - always sans milk. Otherwise I&#39;ll just opt for a soy latte. It&#39;s a good coffee, and definitely one of the best in the area. Also a solid place to meet for an interview or 1-to-1, as the sharp-looking surroundings should suit the business formality.<br><br>NB: Tras Street itself has many shophouses which have a mixture of full-length French windows and half-length casement windows so you&#39;ll be taking photos.)

We are yelp elites from the San Francisco area so our love is made around hipster coffee shops and this place nailed it! The decor is so cute on the inside and there is plenty of seating and outlets for anyone wanting to study. The coffees are simple but very delicious. I wanted to go back everyday if I could  i got the iced vanilla coffee!

text: Hipster coffee shop known in Japan for their amazing latte art. They make everything from Hokkaido cows milk which is flown in. I was more impressed by their variety of coffee beans to be honest. The costa rican and ethiopian ones were stellar. Their affogato, well lets say its not like you&#39;re italian one, way way more ice cream, and not gelato, its a soft serve made from the aforementioned cow&#39;s milk. I&#39;m not saying its not good, but its a affogato just in a manner of speech, I&#39;d more call it soft serve with espresso! They have decent food options too, but its all about the coffee and milk!

text: 5 stars for the cream puff; it was so good, we went back the very next day for more.<br>The expresso drinks were good, but the Hokkaido milk shines in the cream puff and less so in the coffee drinks (don&#39;t know about the tea-based drinks).<br><br>Service was warm &amp; professional. Barista is indeed an artist, check out that rose!<br><br>They are sticklers about opening time, please respect that - don&#39;t enter before even if the door is unlocked &amp; open; if the sign says closed, they&#39;re closed.

Recent visit was April 4th 2019.'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5NcxAKzcbYF23MBIKSiZ-A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-bean-and-tea-leaf-singapore-54?reviewid=5rdI8Obr-DPpwTRYf3WmMQ&select=5NcxAKzcbYF23MBIKSiZ-A', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RtNwMY8CBI5NU82GcMzcjw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-bean-and-tea-leaf-singapore-54?reviewid=5rdI8Obr-DPpwTRYf3WmMQ&select=RtNwMY8CBI5NU82GcMzcjw', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf - Singapore, Singapore. &#34;Burnt&#34; edges of Puff pastry...', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': '"Burnt" edges of Puff pastry...'}]
text: For now this location of The Coffee Bean &amp; Tea Leaf receives 3 stars in my books.  For one, it is Halal Certified by MUIS, which is definitely good in my books.  During the weekends, this eatery DEFINITELY will be swamped to the brim.  I will avoid at those times.<br><br>Depending on the day or time I went, especially during the NON PEAK hours, I always managed to grab a seat to enjoy some snacks or beverages at this establishment.<br><br>At times, my order of the Spicy Chicken Curry Puffs (SG$4.10) is placed on a plate.  But with this recent visit, it was just placed in the originally packing of the box.  *SIGH*  When it is heated up, there will be a tendency that outside the puff pastry tends to get darker, due to the oven heat/broiler.  I so wish that they can &#34;control&#34; the temperature setting etc.  This Spicy Chicken Curry Puff, is spicy and I like the flavors of it with some chunks of chicken in it. <br><br>With regards to the beverages, if I could recall properly it was one of those Iced Teas.  Note to self, next time request for less ice.  It seems that its more ICE than anything else for my order of beverage.  *DOUBLE SIGH*<br><br>I may return to this establishment when needed, even though each time I went here those Spicy Chicken Curry Puffs DEFINITELY &#34;scream&#34; order me, eat me...

text: Always deserves a 4star... Coffee is one of the in this city. Also, pastry seems OK ( I have not tried this time). Very good location. Seats were comfortable too.

Coffee Bean is one of my favourite eating place. This store located right at the entrance, so convenient, but noisy. We visited the place at about 8pm, the staff there already look tired, dull and indifferent. Service was poor. So disappointed :(

text: Cute little cafe for Kopi and Teh. They also offer some sweets. Service was quick and friendly. There was a wall unit air conditioner in there but they kept the door open so it wasn&#39;t that cool inside. It was comfortable enough though after a long, hot walk outside. They said they might change their hours of operation in the future but I&#39;ve filled in what I can for the moment.

text: Great coffee!!<br>No salty or any bitter taste - just perfect.<br>Original Italian crema, very delicious.<br>A very nice little place to drop by, unwind and enjoy.<br>To be honest, the best espresso in Singapore.<br>Colonial style, excellent barista.<br>I recommend!

Cocoa 78 with cinnamon stick', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cocoa 78 with cinnamon stick'}]
text: The chocolate is really really really good!<br><br>I love dark chocolate with its bittersweet aftertaste and this place does have a good cocoa.<br><br>The menu is varied and simple. It has a bit of everything. From breakfast pastries like croissant and pain au chocolat, muffins, ice cream and cakes to sandwiches for lunch. Beverage includes many types of hot cocoa (different grades from milky cocoa to the 100% dark chocolate level and even alcoholic version), coffee and tea. <br><br>It looks like a corner food stand catering to those who needs some sustenance to go, but there is a tiny counter at the side (just 4 stools) for those who want to sit down and take a breather. <br><br>I love that you get the option of having a cinnamon stick for your hot cocoa. It adds a different dimension to your drink. <br><br>The latte is surprisingly good, smooth and with no/low acidity. <br><br>The double chocolate muffin is to die for! I love the dark chocolate chips in the soft and moist muffin. A bit too crumbly though and the dessert fork is just too small to scoop up the pieces. <br><br>There is a nutella banana walnut cake which caught my eye *drool* That will be next on the list of things to try.
Had an iced latte. Did not disappoint. Highly recommend. Can&#39;t wait to try their chocolate drinks!

text: We had the umi rice, salmon baked rice and wagyu rice.  Dishes came out fine tasted ok and looked ok.  Nothing special but perhaps priced a little high?  Just based on the cost of latte at 7.8 and that is before gst and service charge.  Think be better off to get at starbucks.  <br><br>Jan 28th &#39;17<br>Pinoy waitress not that great but Kuian i think was her namr was excellent. Back again just because i love the fluffy pancakes.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/mbph6TiuJrbCjm2KvbwPcw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/watanabe-coffee-singapore?reviewid=E97hrKpTqtgYF_X0VhX2Jg&select=mbph6TiuJrbCjm2KvbwPcw', 'altText': 'Photo of Watanabe Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Just another coffee shop.<br><br>I&#39;ve heard stories about Watanabe from my cousin, so I figured, I might as well try it while I&#39;m in Singapore. I may have hyped myself too much, but I found nothing special about this place. The ambiance is rather unpleasant - a bunch of snobs talking about money. <br><br>But let&#39;s talk about the coffee.<br><br>I&#39;m a huge fan of pour overs, but I found nothing special about theirs. It&#39;s literally just normal Brazilian pour over priced atrociously high. I believe I paid $9SG or more for the coffee, which I can seriously make at home. I&#39;ve Geisha, Blue Mountain, Kopi Luwak and those definitely worth the price. I just can&#39;t justify and defend Watanabe.

text: I walked in without doing much research and proceed to order a Latte. And when i ask how much, the waitress said $8.35 and I thought i heard her wrongly. <br><br>How much again?<br><br>It&#39;s $8.30, Sir. <br><br>Not wanting to create too much fuss, I paid anyway and waited 10 mins for my coffee. The restaurant was not even full that time. <br><br>I am unsure about the food quality, but judging from the price of the coffee alone, I suppose I need to bring some diamonds if i want to eat here. <br><br>Not coming back.  <br><br>p/s: coffee was just mediocre or even below average.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/_2NKN0PcVEIZiQz3p549cQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/watanabe-coffee-singapore?reviewid=eHvXlzqsQeH1s-eig0aMjQ&select=_2NKN0PcVEIZiQz3p549cQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Watanabe Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Entrance', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Entrance'}]
text: Located right next to the entrance of Isetan Scotts is Watanabe Coffee. Only a few weeks old and it&#39;s getting pretty popular to both the Japanese and locals.As with typical Japanese cafes, there&#39;s wooden benches that line the entrance, the idea is to sit there while waiting for your table. When I arrived at 130pm, I only managed to get a table at 230pm for 5 adults. A one hour wait, as they do not take reservations during lunch hours. Also take note, they only have two large tables to accomodate more than 4 pax.<br>Looking through the menu, their drink prices caught my eyes. $8.10++ for an iced matcha latte! Their dutch style cold brew at $6.80 was the highlight of this cafe, with the word &#34;Coffee&#34; in the shop name, you would think they are proud to serve it. <br><br>1. Dutch Style Cold Brew (L) $6.80++<br>It was incredibly bitter, even after adding condiments, but you could definitely feel the effect of this strong coffee! Apparently, they only make 10 cups of these every 8 hours. Interesting!<br><br>2. Matcha Roll Cake $11.80++<br>I love Japanaese roll cakes! This is no exception, the cake was moist and the cream was delightful. The green tea powder used to decorate the plate was a nice addition, and it was authentic and quite bitter. A good tea time snack!<br><br>3. Ramune Float $2 add on (with the roll cake afternoon set)<br>By it&#39;s own, it is priced at $9, a rather expensive ramune, which you can get at Daiso for just $2 in a bottle. It tasted like every ramune but their ice cream was pretty dense and didn&#39;t melt in the drink. Instead, I had to use the metal spoon to scoop up the ice cream.<br><br>4.  French Fries with Truffle Salt $10.80++<br>No lie, the whole cafe smelt of truffle! These fries were addictive. Not something I would normally order, but it was well worth the calories! The fries were crispy and not oily, the salt was evenly distributed and the smell is just so good!<br><br>5. Matcha Ogura Honey Toast $16.80++<br>Probably their best seller, as almost every table order one. It is a pretty instagrammable honey toast. It is huge, and I would recommend sharing it amongst 4 people! It comes with green tea ice cream, vanilla ice cream, red bean, whipped cream and 3 mochis.<br><br>We tried cutting into it gracefully, but made a mess. The whipped cream melted too quickly. The bread on the outside was toasted well, and on the inside, white and fluffy bread that was quite airy, with a slight crisp on the edge. <br><br>I think there&#39;s a few hits and misses here at Watanabe, first of all their service could be improved. The lady at the entrance was so busy, she was pretty rude to a number of people waiting in line. I did sit on the bench for an hour and observed her attitude, I ended up handling the menu to several people waiting in line with me, as they were all asking for menus, but she kept ignoring them. Yes, the cafe is full. Yes the shop is very busy, but don&#39;t act as if you&#39;re too busy to help others in line.<br><br>Secondly, the food is quite pricey and not very impressive. However, they do carry alot of the typical Japanese favourites. I lost count of the number of Japanese families with young children that surrounded my table. <br><br>Last of all, they need to either figure out a way to get people to leave when they&#39;re done eating or add more tables. I witnessed several parties using their laptops or reading magazines once they were done eating and no effort was made to hand them their bills. In the mean time, the queue outside the shop continues to grow with potential hungry customers.

text: Good coffee and breakfast! We&#39;re here to have breakfast and coffee and amazed on the taste of the coffee, bitter and a bit sour at first then sweetness came at the end. Nice coffee. We had the morning plate toast for breakfast which consisted of toast, or rice, egg, slice of ham, sausage, salad, and jam and butter. Quite nice. $$

text: Favorite coffee shop around here. Cold brew is a must. Great selection of Japanese desserts and main courses as well.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hSGyFNVrNLzuFt7qJSh3Fg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/watanabe-coffee-singapore?reviewid=q4EKDQMQ3bGyzZvNNP5bag&select=hSGyFNVrNLzuFt7qJSh3Fg', 'altText': 'Photo of Watanabe Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. From left to right: Cold Matcha Latte,Soy Chai Latte, Syphon Coffee', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'From left to right: Cold Matcha Latte,Soy Chai Latte, Syphon Coffee'}]
text: A nice, cozy cafe where people can socialize and work. If you are in need of several cups of good coffee, this place is for you! The syphon coffee came in a round flask that served ~3 cups. It was smooth and not too bitter.<br><br>The soy chai latte was mediocre--it could have used more spice than sugar water.<br><br>The matcha pudding was good but overly too sweet because of the added syrup on top. The coffee paired well with the pudding.<br><br>I would recommend the ice matcha latte though! The matcha was not overpowered by the milk and it was just the right amount of sweetness.<br><br>If it weren&#39;t for the slow service (it took ~20mins for the drinks), this place would have received a 4/5.<br><br>Note: Free wifi upon request

text: Came here on a weekday about 4pm and got in without a queue with a friend and ordered a matcha latte and cod roe pasta, with matcha pudding and some bubblegum-blue drink for my friend.<br><br>My friend wasn&#39;t too impressed, but I felt my latte was okay, and I loved my pasta. The pasta here has a very chewy consistency, and every strand was coated with creamy mentaiko sauce and topped with a mound of nori. Very tasty.<br><br>Service here is a wee bit slow, but the environment was pleasant enough to have a chat in. I am not sure about prices, but I do remember the pasta&#39;s portion was on the small side, and slightly pricey for what it was.<br><br>I would come back for the pasta.

text: After a quick trip to the Thai Embassy around the corner we were in the mood for a coffee. The window signage promoting Japanese Coffee roasters drew us in being total coffee snobs. I had a macchiato and my husband had a double macchiato. They were strong, a nice crema blended in with well textured milk. <br><br>There is complimentary wireless. You can also buy beans to take home too. The food offereings looked good too.

text: 3.5 stars at first, but I decided to minus 0.5 star when I looked at the waitresses&#39; face. Lol.. call me mean .... but walking into a cafe/ restaurant on Saturday afternoon, I expected a warm welcome especially when you are not charging $2 for a cup of coffee but in the range of $6 to $9 ... I am not saying that they are rude or what, but they showing blank face, not even smiling. To me, they don&#39;t enjoy what they are doing at all. <br>Alright, back to the food. I ordered a premium French toast set, come with a drink (you can choose from the list), it costs $17.90. Not a bad deal at all. <br>The French toast came with blueberry sauce (they have 3 choices mango, blubbery and ... sorry I can&#39;t remember), topped with a vanilla ice-cream. It is good, but nothing fantastically impressive. I paired the pancake with hot soy latte. Pretty good. <br>The place is not crowded, good place for friends gathering. And they do serve wines too. <br>I will consider come here again, for the coffee. <br><br>Cheers!

Matcha shake and matcha Swiss roll', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Matcha shake and matcha Swiss roll'}]
text: Classy decor and quality food at decent prices in terms of Orchard Road&#39;s centre. During peak hours, there is a sign saying maximum 1.5h of dining if there are other customers waiting and each person must order at least one item. Sounds stringent but understandable. I got the set of matcha Swiss roll cake and matcha shake (add $2 compared to other beverages). My friend had matcha latte and toast with banana/caramel. Service was rather slow but the taste was good.

Overpriced and nothing like the original genre. But a good place for meetings, if you can handle the slow service, because both it and the food quality for the price point mean the cafe is half empty even on weekends, despite its extraordinarily busy location.<br><br>We came for the breakfast sets. The idea comes from Japan, where you can find low priced cafes where salarymen swallow a quick pizza toast and filter coffee before heading to their offices. Efficiency and cost are the deciding factors, understandably that means the coffee quality takes a backstep.<br><br>Unfortunately, Watanabe caught my attention by advertising being a roaster. This is a departure from the style. I thus had high expectations of my &#34;Dutch-style&#34; drip coffee... and they were most certainly not met. Either the coffee is stale, or it is roasted to such a high level as to be practically burnt. Since the beans I saw come off the roaster were a nice medium roast, I assume the former. I noticed the menu said $5 for a drip coffee, and $8 (if I recall well) for a &#34;special house roast&#34; or similar wording, which implies that the regular coffee does not come from their home roasted beans. Well, I can&#39;t complain. At the price point of the set, and considering the origin of the genre, it&#39;s not supposed to be a light roast filled with floral tones and a long finish. Still, disappointing.<br><br>The service was slow not because of the incompetence of the staff - on the contrary, they did a marvellous job - but because the cafe is SEVERELY understaffed! There were only two people on duty, and this is not a &#34;8 seats at the counter only&#34; sized place. They looked pretty exhausted but dutifully processed all the orders as well as they could. My coffee arrived well after I had finished my toast and egg, and we waited 4 minutes to be seated despite a half empty cafe. It&#39;s OK if you expect it. <br><br>The food - except toast - is extortionately priced. In fact, for 2 dollars more than the paltry looking &#34;wagyu&#34; roast slice (the thickness of a chashu slice at Sapporo Ramen) you can head for Bistro du Vin and have a 3 course lunch which is still awesome after all these years in the finest French bistro tradition, including foie gras stuffed ravioli with roast hazelnuts where the foie gras actually seems to have increased in size in the last 4 years... I disgress. <br><br>The sofas and the armchairs are comfortable and the tables nicely spaced apart, so this is actually a great location for business meetings compared to alternatives in the area. This redeeming feature will probably see me back, as the average hipster cafe is usually packed to the brim and communal tables don&#39;t make for the best business setting.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=dmq0nRDZBHzj0l9CBVnDsQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Maggie C.', 'displayLocation': 'Chicago, IL', 'altText': 'Maggie C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=dmq0nRDZBHzj0l9CBVnDsQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 91, 'eliteYear': None}
text: The Dutch Style Cold Brew and the Cold Brew Float (includes ice cream) were delicious and really hit the spot during a hot, humid day.  We also had a piece of the Matcha Roll Cake and Red Bean Pancake which were fresh, light, and very flavorful.

Watanabe Coffee is conveniently located in Shaw House, and they have a full menu of coffee, food, and drinks.  We stopped by for coffee and ice cream, and the place is comfortable for chatting and taking a shopping break, which is nice because service moves at a glacial place.  But first, I&#39;m happy to say that both the inhouse roasted coffee and cold Dutch coffee were very good.  The Dutch coffee in particular was very robust and strong and even when iced, it doesn&#39;t lose its intensity.  However, it took about 25 minutes for the coffee to come out and then another 10 minutes for the ice cream.  I cannot understand how it could take 35 minutes to get a scoop of ice cream unless someone forgot.  But they did not explain it in that way so not sure what was going on. They had 3 servers so I&#39;m guessing that the operational constraint is with the coffee and kitchen, but they can also do much better with setting expectations.

text: We had the coffee blend and hokkaido pound cake slice. <br>Liked the coffee - strong but smooth flavour and presented in a very interesting contraption. <br>The cake was delicious but a large dollop of cream in the centre was frozen stiff and difficult to cut into. So we ended up eating the cake, but leaving the frozen cream centre as is. <br>The menu looked interesting and we will consider returning to sample other stuff on offer.

Iced Doi Chaang', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Iced Doi Chaang'}]
text: Hipsters, this cafe is not for you. You would feel uncomfortable here as there are no racks of reading materials, glowing filament bulbs, or shaggy bearded baristas with man buns. But what you will find at Doi Chaang is a friendly welcome and a helpful attitude. Searching for a late lunch, I came across Doi Chaang and was greeted by Joseph working the front of the house. He told me about their cafe&#39;s special organic coffee, which is ranked in the top 1% worldwide by Kenneth Davids, but you be the judge. With some help from Canadian backers, the beans are cultivated &amp; exported by the Akha hill tribe in Northern Thailand.<br><br>For lunch, I decided on the recommended green curry rice which was tasty but typical, though the side of chili and baked egg &amp; cheese was a nice touch. Permanently listed on the menu board are sandwich and waffle options. I spied also some cakes that looked pretty moist and fresh. The curry was likely a daily special. <br><br>Ordering the iced Doi Chaang was perhaps not the best choice to enjoy the characteristics of the single-estate brew, but it was still quite enjoyable. Reminds me a bit like dark chocolate. Will need to return to try and try a naked cup next time. United Square Mall wifi is freely available.

Great coffee! This place is pretty chic, the coffee - repeating myself I know - is very good, albeit a bit pricey. <br>I had a strong yet smooth latte which is perfect as I usually try to have just one large coffee a day - and this will keep me going ;-))<br><br>The food - sandwiches and pastries etc. - also looks delicious. The small space is teaming with office staff (and expats, like me ;-)), and there is outdoor seating, also.<br><br>Staff is borderline snobbish, though, hence 4 stars.<br><br>As this is close to home I will be back for coffee and testing of staff demeanour.

text: Right next to my work, this place gives a great cup of coffee at a reasonable price for Singapore. I order the mocha almost every time and haven&#39;t been disappointed. They also offer a variety of cakes and sweets. I tried the lemon bite which was lovely.

text: This review is for the coffee only, since I&#39;ve only really done takeaway coffee here. The coffee is one of the best I&#39;ve had in Singapore. Better still, it&#39;s consistently good! Being spoilt after living for years in Melbourne, Dimbulah was my saving grace when I was based at Raffles Place. That cup of Long Black brightens any dreary morning or day.

text: First let me say that I am not quite on board with Australian coffee culture.  I was just learning about americanos and now I have to tackle flat whites? Give me a couple months to catch up.  Aside from that little jargon on the menu this place is an acceptable chain coffee shop.  I only frequent here because of its proximity to my husbands office and I go with my standard latte.  One time I tried to order a iced chai latte and it was the worst coffee experience in Singapore.  The barista should have warned me. It tasted like drinking cold pepper and still leaves a bad taste in my mouth for Dimbulah. Stick to your usual.

Great choice for affordable healthy lunch. They aren&#39;t crowded during lunch either! I always go for the comfort fix (chicken thigh, onsen egg, broccoli and brown rice) and its filling enough that I ask for less rice.

text: Honest, healthy, scrumptious good food! I love the DIY factor. If you like Grain Traders, you&#39;ll LOVEEE this, the food is freshly cooked and not left outside after being cooked like at GT. <br><br>I was not a fan of the pork sausage (too sweet and tasted weird to me albeit the nice fragrance in the air), but I&#39;m a HUGE fan of the grilled halloumi cheese. It was perfection and I dream about returning for that amazing slab of tofu-like cheese.

text: After our disappointing lunch at Kotobuki, I decided to give a treat to my sis. We came to Hoshino Coffee for their coffee and famous soufflé. This was my first time visiting Hoshino so I did not know what to expect. My sis said Hoshino has this really yummy soufflé. <br><br>So I ordered a royal milk tea, my sis a coffee and of cos a soufflé to share. She was right, the soufflé was delicious. It would be too much for any of us, sharing is caring works here. <br><br>The staff has asked me &#34;sugar or syrup?&#34; for the milk tea. I chose the syrup. After emptying the whole miniature syrup jar, my cold milk tea still wasn&#39;t to my liking in terms of sweetness. I would like to see more dessert items here. <br><br>I like the ambience and decor here. Staffs are nice too.<br><br>Will definitely be back!! :)

text: This is my first time dine at Hoshino Coffee. I ordered the lobster bisque soup spaghetti and was expected lobster meat in the pasta but what I got was prawns instead. Upon enquiry, the staff told me their lobster bisque soup pasta doesn&#39;t comes with any lobster! I was surprised because the main ingredient of lobster bisque soup is lobster meat hence the name LOBSTER bisque soup!! <br><br>I was fairly disappointed with the answer and didn&#39;t want to argue. The soup and pasta taste alright but the prawn is completely lack of seasoning and taste like it&#39;s been frozen for a long time. Hugely disappointed  with Hoshino Coffee, don&#39;t think I would ever return here again.

text: I waited for 30minutes for my souffle to arrive! Because apparently the first one failed and they had to re-make it. I guess I&#39;ll never come back though the variety of Japanese fusion is good.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dHCJsJBoit5EcrhqOJKFDA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-7th-cylinder-singapore?reviewid=TRXgfNhNVGMlnlA-H0N_fg&select=dHCJsJBoit5EcrhqOJKFDA', 'altText': 'Photo of The 7th Cylinder - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: First off, I megalove the ambience. Skylight, black and white, quiet, calm, unique motifs and over all theme. Reminds me a bit of the Folsom area in SF (but that may just be wishful thinking). They even painted the power points black -as my dad so helpfully pointed out. <br><br>BUT okay, I have to be honest. The Music could do with some improvement - stop with the darn radio. For serious. Figure out your theme and get a soundtrack that fits. Please. <br><br>Food - It&#39;s only been around for one month so hey, I&#39;m sure they&#39;ll improve (crossed fingers) but so far nothing very original when it comes to omnomnoms. I ordered the ERP eggs: scrambled eggs with toasted bread, blueberry preserves, and side salad. Salad was fresh, bread was good, and scrambled eggs were scrambled. They did okay with this - but I&#39;d want to see what else they come up with. <br><br>Coffee. Oh coffee. And this is what made me want to write a review for them. <br>I ADORE coffee served in large mugs. I go crazy if the mugs are black. I will literally come back here just. for. my. caffeine. fix. #truth #givememore <br><br>Hot chocolate (oh my word yes yes yes yes YES) they beat Drury Lane hands down. And I love Drury Lane but give me hot chocolate (in a black mug!!!!) with a good froth layer sprinkled with chocolate flakes ANYTIME. I hateeee when they put hot chocolate in a tiny latte cup. <br><br>So there ya go. Review written. Now y&#39;all know what to do ;)

text: Decent coffee albeit a bit pricey and the wifi was fast. But the guy in charge when we were there was incredibly rude, obnoxious and disrespectful. I would not reccomend coming here.
Good wifi here! No decaf coffee unfortunately. <br><br>Smoked duck ciabatta ($6.50) - 3.75 stars<br>Good! But simple - just the sandwich and nothing on the side so not many veggies in this meal.

Highlander Coffee, Kampong Bahru Road', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Highlander Coffee, Kampong Bahru Road'}]
text: Outram Park in Singapore has become a mini coffee hub recently, with at least 4 cafes (Nylon, Highlander, Oriole and Strangers Reunion) serving artisan coffee. Highlander was one of the first (if not the first) third wave cafes to open in Singapore, and is still roasting and serving interesting blends of coffee on Kampong Bahru road.<br><br>The espresso shot that I ordered came with a light brown crema, and the volume was spot on - a good single shot should not fill up an espresso mug. It had a interesting acidic taste - not tart, but the right amount of bitterness. The biscotti which come with all coffees in Highlander are sweet, and balance out the acidity.<br><br>The house blend in Highlander is a combination of beans from Brazil, Ethiopia and Sumatra, which is a good combination for lattes, cappuccinos etc. The stronger, lasting aftertaste ensures that there is still a definite taste of coffee, and that the steamed milk does not mask any flavour. Highlander house blend uses a specific ratio of beans from these different countries to ensure a very specific taste. <br><br>There is a retails space also, with coffee accessories available, such as grinders, filters, aeropresses and vacumn packs to store ground beans. Pricing is good - consistent with other cafes, beans are slightly cheaper. well worth visiting for well executed coffees and some very good shots.

Let a social coffee drinker offer some tips on Highlander:<br><br>a) they&#39;re a coffee geek sort of place. Which means the coffee beans are freshly roasted, the beans and some bits of equipment are available for purchase should you feel like playing barista at home<br><br>b) they&#39;re a coffee place. DO NOT DO WHAT I DID AND ORDER A NON-COFFEE DRINK. Goodness me that smoothie was not smile-inducing, let&#39;s just say. <br><br>Out of the various coffee joints on the street I do feel that they do java best, though I will say that if you&#39;re not looking for coffee head elsewhere!

text: Before indie cafes were cool in Singapore, there was Highlander. Notice how many indie cafes are sprouting around Outram and Tanjong Pagar? Cause the Godfather of coffee lives on Kampong Bahru road. None of those geeky snobbish pourover, just straight and honest espressos. Service is excellent as my barista remembers the drink I want even before I order it. What more can you ask?

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=Vt_lIJ3gqZ_Vm4p2fAqMGA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/up9HBj8pETlFqIw3HvFBow/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Dominique L.', 'displayLocation': 'London, United Kingdom', 'altText': 'Dominique L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=Vt_lIJ3gqZ_Vm4p2fAqMGA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 89, 'photoCount': 230, 'reviewCount': 422, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Despite the Scottish moniker, Highlander Coffee is in no way Scottish. Instead, it&#39;s a coffee shop, coffee retailer and coffee academy all rolled into one. Run by two brothers - Cedric and Phil - who are incredibly passionate about coffee, this place is one of the best places in Singapore to grab a great cup of coffee. The brothers, who trained in Sydney (but where else?), have trained quite a few baristas from all over the region, so it&#39;s no surprise that the staff here take their coffee very seriously indeed.<br><br> The coffee bar is very nice and comfortable, though a little on the small side. Even though I was just drinking a flat white and reading through a couple of magazines one sunny weekday afternoon, the staff didn&#39;t harrass me in any way to order more. Instead, they left me in peace.<br><br> It&#39;s not that easy to get to, so if youre going to make the effort to come here, check out the directions on their website. Even a cab driver most likely wouldn&#39;t be able to get you here as it&#39;s easy to miss if you&#39;re on the road. Still, given the quality of the coffee, it&#39;s defintiely worth the trip if you&#39;re a coffee-lover!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hZ6dI19dvGm1E73kmL27Hg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sinpopo-brand-singapore?reviewid=gFw7VqaTvd4m0PoBeQdbjw&select=hZ6dI19dvGm1E73kmL27Hg', 'altText': 'Photo of Sinpopo Brand - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: This restaurant is really a hidden gem in Katong!<br><br>I don&#39;t usually start my reviews like that so that&#39;s how good an impression it made on me. We stumbled upon it completely by accident and thought it was going to be overpriced and modified local food not done well. Boy were we wrong.<br><br>The ambience was nice with a touch of local culture such as the old fashioned shutters in the corner. We tried the sng muay pop and the milo dinosaur for drinks and both were impeccable. Especially the milo dinosaur (I confess my love for milo now but there is nothing more heavenly than a milo dinosaur done right)<br><br>The har jeong Kai wings for starters turned out great as well, juicy with a slight crisp. The mains were good too. The crab bee hoon was hearty and tasty and the nonya kiam chye arg tasting relatively authentic.<br><br>Didn&#39;t have space for dessert but I guess that means an excuse to visit again. And that&#39;s nothing to complain about.

Gula melaka jelly', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Gula melaka jelly'}]
text: Ordered kiam chai arg (salted pickles soup with duck) which supposed to be Chinese traditional dish, but most Chinese wouldn&#39;t deep fried the duck leg before cook it in the soup. 1 star  deducted. The portion is not really as big as described by the waiter, big for a lady, but barely enough for 2. The Roti babi was nice, minced meat deep fried with a toast. Gula melaka jelly so so, but the durian penyet paired with coconut ice cream was impressive. Advisable to make reservation to avoid disappointment, sometimes this place is fully booked.

A very bad decision to go to sinpopo. Went there because Wahiro and many other eateries around Katong were packed and full house on a Friday evening. We had the pork chop which costs us $20 it was not worth even 1/4 of the price. The presentation was basic. We ordered an appetiser too - The crab wanton looked pathetic and tasted bad $8 for those tiny bits. The crab bee hoon was too salty and not tasty also not worth $18. Overall bad experience. The service wasn&#39;t worth mentioning, no particular service. Dinner for $57. We should have just eaten at home. Won&#39;t be back and would not recommend anyone at all.

text: This brand is under the Awfully Chocolate group, and I must say I think it&#39;s one of their better concepts. I&#39;ve been here a few times and I&#39;ve enjoyed what I&#39;ve tried, from the main courses, drinks, to desserts.<br><br>The nasi lemak for two is well portioned; they don&#39;t skimp. Sure, it&#39;s a bit fancier than Ponggol Nasi Lemak, but I loved all the sides it came with! I&#39;ve also tried their Har Jeong Kai burger, which is their rendition of the famous Everything With Fries version. I thought it was well done and I admit I finished the entire thing (and it was huge!) I REGRET NOTHING.<br><br>Their popular orange kaya pisang creme brulee is worth trying, though it might be too sweet for some. I thought their longan drink was very refreshing during those hot Singapore summer days!<br><br>Solid food and near my place? Yup, I&#39;ll be here a lot more often.

Orange Kaya Pisang Crème Brûlée with double shot (upon request) Mocha.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Orange Kaya Pisang Crème Brûlée with double shot (upon request) Mocha.'}]
text: Quintessentially Singaporean, from tiles right up to the ceiling fan, this café is a nice little chillout with spacious seating and quiant interior decor. For those vintage lovers, it harks back to the 60s: the vibe is just unmistakable.<br><br>The menu is impressive. Fusional interpretations of local delights with European techniques remind us that Singapore is a multicultural society, ready to adapt and create new flavours without sacrificing quality and authenticity. While I only had the Orange Kaya Pisang Crème Brûlée and Mocha, Sinpopo is already beckoning me for a return trip!<br><br>The taste and texture of the Orange Kaya Pisang Crème Brûlée are pretty consistent. The complex flavours all keeping in harmony at the first bite. A hint of Pandan can be detected, which further impresses that this is a signature dessert of Sinpopo and possibly, of Singaporean cuisine, albeit a little niche. However, as we dig deeper into the core of the dessert,  it starts to feel more diabetically sweet than can be handled. I immediately abandoned all hopes of finishing it up. As a warning to those with a moderately   sweet tooth, share it with a few friends or completely avoid it! If you are a sugar addict, this is definitely recommended!<br><br>The Mocha, on the other hand, was the clear winner for me. However, I cheated a little, I requested for a double shot as I prefer mine strong and thick. The coffee, even at double the amount, wasn&#39;t overwhelming the chocolate. The chocolate was smoothly intertwined with the coffee at every sip, waking me up and at the same time, lifting my spirits up! Absolutely recommended!<br><br>Overall, even though this was my first visit, the consensus is that I&#39;ll be back to try the main course and see for myself if this is truly worth the 4 stars it currently deserves!

text: Don&#39;t fix it if it isn&#39;t broken. <br><br>We&#39;ve walked pass this place countless of time, always telling ourselves that we have to try it one day. <br>At a glance, it looked like a nice old coffee shop which serves some of our favourite food! Scissors Cut curry rice, ice ball... All served in classic &#34;chicken bowls&#34; or enamel ware, so it really disappointed us when the old shophouse gates were gone and the place started looking like any other hippy cafe. <br><br>Given the fact it was still there, and crowded, we decided to try.<br><br>Durian Pengat<br>An updated version of the version found commonly at buffets around Singapore, <br>A good generous bowl topped with a pretty decent coconut ice cream. Definitely for the durian lovers! Croutons added a nice crunch to a dish which would otherwise me a soft pasty texture trough out. Would have been better with more drizzles of gula Melaka or if a stronger durian was used, otherwise, a very decent dish. <br><br>Brown butter sugee cake. <br>Another update to a local dish, the Sugee cake is every sugar lovers dream, which may not be a good thing. The cake itself was moist with the nuts on top giving it a nice, crunchy, earthy flavour with every bite. However, the icing over the top is a tad too sweet and I found myself filling up with water every 2-3 bites. <br><br>Horlicks and Maltersers Shake.<br>If you&#39;re a huge fan of Horlicks, this is one dish you&#39;re never going to complain about. Every sip of this thick, rich shake is like putting a table spoon of Horlicks powder in your mouth (don&#39;t deny it, I know plenty of you did it while still a child). <br>Be warned. This drink is a meal on its own!<br><br>Har Joong Gai Wings <br>This had to be their most disappointing item of all. Described as being made the &#34;traditional&#34; way, the wings failed to live up to any expectations. <br>At $6.00 for 4 midpoints (yes, you don&#39;t even get the full wing), it&#39;s far from being a value for money. <br>Taste wise, the wings are as traditional as a laksa spaghetti is in Italy. <br>While the taste of the Har Joong (fermented prawn paste) was there, it wasn&#39;t prominent. Instead, there was a horrible bitter after taste, similar to what you get when either something is burnt, or the oil they used hadn&#39;t been changed. <br>Certainly not our favourite dish by any means. <br><br>Whilst the atmosphere was still nice, the music was far too loud and the staff (there was only 1 working) not being as attentive as she should be, the food itself is best described as average. With its more traditional items, plenty of people would have flocked there, just to eat their favourite / nostalgic dishes. Being in Joo Chiat, Gastrobars and Hippy Cafes are slowly becoming a common sight and changing the concept to compete with the rest might not be the best option. Just look at Alibabar, the hawker bar next door, despite having nice decor and a good array of beer, their Char Kway Teow remains one of their most popular dishes, proof that the people living in the area might not need another pretentious up market cafe, but maybe one that serves all time favourites (even if it&#39;s a modernized version of it) like Scissors cut curry rice and ice balls.

text: The nasi lemak set is ok but all the food are very salty.    Including the nasi lemak sambal. We ordered the so called durian desert. Very strong pungent taste.  On second visit, we tried  muaji salad and the crabmeat bee hoon. The muaji salad was ok but the crab meat bee hoon again was very salty. I thank we will not eat here again. One positive note is that the staffs were very friendly.

text: A brand off of Awfully Chocolate (which I was surprised there are two awfully chocolate stores in this area as well) <br><br>Nutella tart $9. Comes with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. The tart was so sweet but had good Nutella flavor. I liked how it came out warmed at the top so it was a little gooey with the chocolate. The crust held up which is good, but I think it could be slightly less sugar in the crust and be more fine in texture. <br><br>Cafe is cute. Nice openness to it. I like the design and set up. <br><br>Menus I feel should be redone in my opinion. They&#39;ve definitely seen better days and it makes it look less classy when they are all tattered on the corners etc. <br><br>Server was nice and she was pretty attentive for the most part. <br><br>Tip: bathroom is outside-ish. <br>Tip: they accept credit cards and do charge service and gst

text: If it&#39;s hearty grandmother food that you&#39;re hoping for, you&#39;re generally better off going to one of Singapore&#39;s many hawker centres. I&#39;m sure the regular punters at Singpopo come to enjoy the chilled out vibe and the heart warming &#34;blast from the past&#34; environment, knowing full well that they could probably get the same food but better and cheaper elsewhere.<br><br>Having said that, on a scorching day in Singapore, a Gula Melaka Soft Jelly ($4.90) and a round of Sng Muay Pop ($3.90) would definitely go a long way in helping you to keep cool. Points for commitment to recreating some of Singapore&#39;s vibrant past but the &#34;classics&#34; on the menu in Sinpopo&#39;s case, aren&#39;t really worth returning for.

text: Best coffee in Singapore, they make a great latte or flat white. Food is also tastefully prepared and affordable! Focus on all day breakfast and lunch food. Haven&#39;t had dinner here yet but would love to give it a go.

I was really looking forward to eating breakfast here prior to starting the full day of garden touring. The line was long at 0900 on a Sunday morning, and I ordered a ham and cheese toastie on brioche bread...and it was good but a bit expensive for what you get.<br><br>I&#39;d still eat here when coming back to the garden though.

text: Don&#39;t get the cake. The crunchy hazelnut chocolate cake I had tasted a bit stale and the cream had an oily aftertaste. It was quite bad that I left it half eaten. I am not sure if they bake cakes on the premise or they get them from elsewhere. Or maybe it has been sitting there for a few days, not surprising if most of the patrons do not really order cakes. <br><br>The carbonara was good, creamy and tasty. I like it. <br><br>The flat white was equally decent. In the hour I was there, most people ordered the sandwiches or pasta and coffee. Not many people actually had desserts. Maybe I should have observed more before ordering.<br><br>It can get pricey considering it came to over $30 for just a coffee, pasta and cake.

text: I was walking around the gardens (a definite must do) and was hungry for lunch.  It was hot outside and it is air conditioned inside.  I ordered the salmon argula sandwich.  It was very good but at $20 SGD, it was pretty pricey.  Including several drinks to rehydrate, my total for 1 person was getting up there.  Service was a little slow to get my sandwich but the staff was friendly.  The air conditioning was set pretty low so it felt great.  There are not a lot of cheap options in the park so I would recommend eating before seeing the park or bringing your food and enjoy a picnic in the park.

text: The photos showed looked delicious but when our items came, the chicken for our salad was not grilled like it showed on the menu board. They were frozen cut pieces. The salmon over rice was disappointing. Nothing looked like the picture at all. Over priced crappy food.

Dropped by for a mid afternoon coffee and was forced kicking and screaming to eat some of their chocolate cake. <br><br>We dropped by on a trip to Gardens by the Bay and ordered a Flat White Coffee, a Latte and suddenly heard our names being called by  double chocolate heaven cake and a banana chocolate cake. Having no willpower whatsoever we gave in and ordered a piece of each. <br><br>Many calories later it was hard to conclude which was the better. The double chocolate was heavier but had a great chocolate flavor. The banana chocolate had a really nice banana flavored Mousse in the middle.  <br><br>Coffee was also good but cups rather small. Overall great taste but a little pricy.

text: What can I say about this place? In the most beautiful patois ever created by Mankind (Singlish), I can pithily conclude my review of this place in two words:<br><br>&#34;OK lor.&#34;<br><br>Nothing impressive. Would come if I was at Gardens... but definitely not worth us driving out of the way just to dine here. <br><br>Price point: My pasta was $20ish.

The chicken and waffles was awesome. The burffle (waffle burger) was awesome. The price - is fair and not dodgy (no additional taxes, no service charge - you order and pay at the counter, but they serve food to you), you pay what you ordered.<br><br>I would definitely come again!

text: Located near Beauty World MRT (Downtown line) is a stretch of eateries facing the private estate of Lorong Kilat.  I visited on a monday night at 8pm and it was 3/4 full! I was surprised at how busy it was. There were school students from the nearby schools as well mostly youngsters grabbing a bite together with their friends.<br><br>Their menu had a pretty interesting design, it was swivel menu with placards and both food and drink items were compacted into that one menu. I was quite impressed, was the level of details they had in their interior design and menu.<br>There&#39;s both outdoor and indoor dining areas. The whole cafe has a circus theme.  The wall decorations were pretty colourful and eye-catching.<br><br>1. Cookie Monster $8<br>It was a really hot and this cookie monster was the perfect saviour. I really loved the lingering aromatic cookie flavour and aftertaste without being overly milky or sweet. It was more of a &#34;gao&#34;/thick milkshake. And all that crumbled up cookie gives it a grainy feel. It was a sinful but calorie-worthy drink.<br><br>Revelry ovffers a range of milkshakes and depending on what you&#39;re game for, Revelry will have something for your sweet tooth!<br><br>2. Truffle Fries $8<br><br>Truffle fries are French fries tossed with truffle oil, truffle salt and parmesan cheese. Truffle oil is used to impart the earthy flavour and aroma of truffles to fries; giving it a strong smoky after-taste. It is not hard to understand why people crave for it. There is just something appealing about the exotic truffle oil - you either love it or hate it.<br><br>It really is a huge portion so, as much as you hate to, you&#39;re going to have to share.<br>The aroma of truffle oil is delightfully strong for this cafe. The fries were crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.<br><br>3. Chicken and Waffles $17 *highly recommended*<br>After seeing tons of pictures of this dish, I finally made the trip down here . Featured here is their signature chicken and waffles, buttermilk waffles served with a crispy fried chicken cutlet that is huge and succulent. The waffles were cirps and light, with a fluffy and slightly soft interior. You couldn&#39;t get full eating these waffles at all. At no point did I felt gerlat either. The texture was one that I adored. The mapley syrup drizzled seemed to be less sweet than others that I&#39;ve tried.<br><br>4. On Cloud Nine $15<br>Another very instagrammable waffle, decorated with toasted mashmallows, lemon curd, vanilla ice cream, popping candy and cotton candy. The buttermilk waffle here was crispier than the waffle with chicken. It had a stronger aroma of sweetness, mainly from all the sweet toppings. Fortunately, the sweetness was just right for me to bear. The cotton candy managed to alleviate the subtle vanilla ice cream flavour a little. The ice cream with popping candy was surprisingly good, I really liked the feeling of the popping candy in my room. A cheap thrill!!<br><br>5. Mocha $5.50<br><br>I ordered a takeaway mocha, just before I left the shop as I needed an energy booster for my long night ahead and it worked well. The mocha had the right tones of coffee bitterness and cocoa sweet notes. It definitely gave me a kick in my brain to empower me through the night.<br>Overall : I love the decor of the cafe, the food was decent, not too expensive but service could&#39;ve been improved. The staff mixed up my order of my drink initially but they apologized for the mix up.

text: Love waffles? Then you GOT to come to this place. I am not a big fan of waffle because it fills you up with minimal flavor. But this place does wonders to their waffle. It is crispy, fluffy and airy. The bite starts with a crunch and ends with a silky texture that just makes you want more. They keep their menu simple with your basic waffle with syrup/butter/fruits or a few fancy ones with chicken/sausage. In addition to waffle, they also have pasta and French toasts. The chicken that comes with their waffle is also delicious.<br><br>The service is to be bragged about. The owner was sitting at one of the tables working on his computer but his eyes and ears is always on the look out for customers request. As we stepped up to make our order, his counter staff was called away by the phone. But he immediately stepped up to serve us. If it wasn&#39;t for my Yelp reviewer eye, you would not even notice it because he was that good. He did that a few times throughout our trip there. Definitely a dedicated boss!<br><br>The ambiance is also very pleasant with an elephant themed decorations and jazzy music. On a nice breezy day, you can also opt for outdoor seating. Will definitely be back!

Tom Yum Prawn Pasta ($17) - 4 stars<br>Well done!<br><br>OK Waffle ($16) - 4.5 stars<br>Otah, kai lan and cheese made a surprisingly pleasant combination. The waffle itself was excellent!<br><br>Free wifi available though I didn&#39;t try it.<br><br>Ambience - 4.5 stars

text: Decided to satisfy my chicken and waffle craving today and paid this place a visit around 1pm today. Finding a seat was not a problem at all.<br><br>The decor was nice and simple. So was the food. Rather yummy but I do admit that while it tasted great at the beginning, it kinda lost its appeal toward the end (probably the guilt setting in). <br><br>Definitely worth a visit but it&#39;s on the pricey side! Then again, which cafe isn&#39;t.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zlokbl285f8XzajRfG2VOw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/two-bakers-cafe-singapore?reviewid=SVKXOJKsfjW3hBy0H8AtEg&select=zlokbl285f8XzajRfG2VOw', 'altText': 'Photo of Two Bakers Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Unicorn Hotcakes. Each one is a different unique flavor. Not too sweet. Perfect texture. Get them!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Unicorn Hotcakes. Each one is a different unique flavor. Not too sweet. Perfect texture. Get them!'}]
text: Eat here! They have a certificate for Le Cordon Bleu for crying out loud. I need not say more but will in case you were looking for details. <br><br>Completely exceeded my expectations. The Unicorn Hotcakes were so delicious with the perfect consistency. I&#39;m from New York City and wish there was a place that could compare to this spot but unfortunately there is not. <br><br>The Unicorn Hotcakes look like they could give you a toothache but! They are not as sweet as they look. Perfect amount of sweetness. Each different colored hotcake is a different flavor. My favorite flavor was the purple beetroot. WOW. Such a uniquely satisfying flavor that I had never tasted in a hotcake. <br><br>I also had the Truffle Omelette which had a black truffle spread and tasted like perfection. The truffle taste wasn&#39;t overpowering at all. If you love truffle then try this dish. Mix the salad in with each bite. Perfect combination of flavors. The dressing for the salad is honey mustard and really complements the Truffle Omelette.<br><br>One of the other things I tried was the fries with truffle mayo. Also a win. Perfect crisp to each fry with a great flavored truffle mayo to dip in to. <br><br>Lemon Yuzu Tart was yet another winner because unlike most lemon tarts, it was not overpowered by the lemon. <br><br>This place knows how to feed their customers right! I will definitely be back again during my business trip in Singapore and will surely be dreaming of the magical Unicorn Hotcakes once I return home to New York City.

text: Another great find along Horne Road!<br><br>If you just finished up at Bao Makers, Two Bakers is a great follow up for dessert. They have lots of cakes to choose from, and if you&#39;re in a big group you&#39;ll have the luxury of trying ALL THE THINGS.<br><br>From the variety that we chose, my favourites would have to be Le Chocolat Noir and the Yuzu  Lemon Tart. Le Chocolat Noir reminds me of an opera cake, or the cake version of a Ferrero Rocher. The Yuzu Lemon Tart served as a great palate cleanser, with the tartness cutting through some of the heavier cream of the other desserts that we chose.<br><br>If you&#39;re one of those Instagram folks, sit at the large table in the back as there&#39;s a window on the ceiling that will provide the natural light you&#39;re looking for. You&#39;re welcome! ;)

text: Great brunch, better coffee...Loved this place! Desserts are unique and they do not disappoint!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ngu0YgYWr4m0_500ucVndw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/two-bakers-cafe-singapore?reviewid=se58PnQSTTgN5GIeQrM6LQ&select=ngu0YgYWr4m0_500ucVndw', 'altText': 'Photo of Two Bakers Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Duck confit fusilli (S$21.80) - taste OK only though :/', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Duck confit fusilli (S$21.80) - taste OK only though :/'}]
text: I&#39;m pretty critical when it comes to judge any kind of pasta dish because come on! pasta is like one of the easiest bunch of dishes you could make yourself. I ordered Duck Confit Fusilli (SGD$21.80) in which they claim to be one of their Chef&#39;s recommendations. This is the description of the dish on the menu: An all-time classic French delicacy of shredded duck leg confit and roasted leeks tossed with fusilli cooked al dente. Sounds amazing, isn&#39;t it? That&#39;s what I thought too. However it turns out that this dish is very very ordinary - taste wise &amp; appearance wise. I cannot imagine how their mains taste like if their chef&#39;s recommendation turns out to be like that only... <br><br>On a positive spin, I&#39;d have to agree that this place is a good place for young people to chill. The cafe is spacious and the ambiance is very laid back.

Cake', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Cake'}]
text: You had me at artisan bakery Two Bakers. Cute hip little cafe serving all day brunch, lunch sets and delicious coffee and fancy cake. Tried the Raspberry Lychee Mousse Cake and it truly heavenly. Coffee blend is strong and smooth. Really want to come back for breakfast before we leave SG.

Key lime tart and famous la  chocolate ganache was good', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Key lime tart and famous la  chocolate ganache was good'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/I1Wcmo2jTMifKw2_J-_b_w/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/two-bakers-cafe-singapore?reviewid=pRzoeP2YHe45rBkGnqIbpQ&select=I1Wcmo2jTMifKw2_J-_b_w', 'altText': 'Photo of Two Bakers Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Luncheon meat fries, truffle soba, pasta linguine with prawns and sambas risotto', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Luncheon meat fries, truffle soba, pasta linguine with prawns and sambas risotto'}]
text: Portions are decently sized but not exactly big enough for verocious eaters. Had the soba, which was aromatic. Pasta is so-so, feels like they used canned tomatoes to do the sauce and frozen prawns. Not really worth that amount of money I am paying for. Sambal risotto was served undercooked the first round. Taste was however refreshing and very interesting concoction I must say. Crowded at lunch time, recommended to get reservation before heading there. NO WIFI and there is bad reception. Not great for studying or doing work there despite a cosy ambience.

Best pulled pork burger we&#39;ve had, followed by The 1925 Microbrewery.  <br>Their brunch is based on bagels and sous vide-d eggs which comes out perfect!  <br><br>Great ambience plus most definitely nicest looking pastries and cakes.  <br><br>My new goto brunch place for a slow relaxing day on the weekends.

It will be a pity if this continues to remain undiscovered, because, Fawr &amp; Co makes coffee that will knock your socks off.<br><br>Besides being a distributor of Dimattina coffee, Fawr also offers some home made cookies for sale. The cafe is small and cozy, a little nook to while some time away in this sleepy estate. This makes a nice conclusion to nearby springleaf prata. Do visit and have a cuppa for me!

My latte', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'My latte'}]
text: I have to say, some times fusion food can go quite wrong.  But in the case of Collective Brewers, IMHO, they&#39;ve got it just right.<br><br>I went with a bunch of colleagues, and so we tried every &#39;rojak&#39; dish we could find on the menu.  Off the top of my head, lap cheong aglia olio, tonkatsu burger, beef rendang sandwich and they have an appetiser which is like siew yoke sliced like char siew.  I could described them one by one, but instead I&#39;ll just Collectively say, all good!!!  And they come with ngoh hiang (5 spice) fries.<br><br>And the best part for me.  The coffee after.  They are very attentive how they make it, brewed to perfection. Will probably be a regular.

Earl Grey Cheesecake', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Earl Grey Cheesecake'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-I6dipbQX2lo-Ei8eKohSg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/collective-brewers-singapore?reviewid=KruNE1D9DwV8n2PU7pWUNQ&select=-I6dipbQX2lo-Ei8eKohSg', 'altText': 'Photo of Collective Brewers - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: In a but unlikely location (at least to me this is a bit out of the way) on Changi Road the great cafe Collective Brewers have set up shop. I visited when they had a coffee event in February but now have also sampled it under more normal circumstances.<br><br>They focus on local roasters and have a rotating selection for espresso, filter and cold drip. The coffees are very nicely prepared but of course the quality on the day may depend on which roaster is represented but I have had very nice coffee from both Jewel and Nylon here. They also have a lot of food on the menu and ai have sampled some of the breakfast items and these are solid options but what has mainly stood out to me has been the nice pastries (Earl Grey Cheesecake is excellent) as well as the awesome Ice Cream Sandwiches (they even have one with bacon in). Do make the effort to go here and try their coffee and sweets,

text: Good n interesting range of coffee n teas including cold drip coffee which is aromatic n refreshing. The Bohemian lager on the tap is refreshing n they have also a IPA on the tap n others in bottles. The Assam Pork Chips is a great idea n delicious too, 5 stars for this dish alone. Good open ambience :-)

Collective Brewers for great coffee and food. Heard their teas are good too!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Collective Brewers for great coffee and food. Heard their teas are good too!'}]
text: Besides the all day breakfast egg benedict and pastas that are the standard fare for most cafes, Collective Brewers has a couple of unusual creations like the rendang sandwich, assam pork chips, sweet dough fritter with dulche de leche dip and ondeh ondeh pancakes that are worth a try. The rendang sandwich is becoming my fav must-have. The assam pork chips are belly pork slices marinated in assam and cooked till crispy. They are served with a sambal blachan dip which may be too heavy for an appetiser. The owner and staff are personable and are willing to talk to you about their food and drinks. That&#39;s a great plus for service!

text: A diamond in the rough.  The Cold drip coffee and iced chocolate is delicious to say the least.  The Satay chicken chop was done to perfection. The atmosphere was warm, pleasant and the staff was very friendly.

Decent coffee but forgettable. Probably wouldn&#39;t travel all the way back just to have coffee. But if I&#39;m in the area and looking for coffee (there aren&#39;t really that many in that area) I might just pop by again.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=_xNkmAVZGiMKm7geujdEXQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Yushan C.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Yushan C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=_xNkmAVZGiMKm7geujdEXQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 1, 'eliteYear': None}
text: My friend and I decided to visit Brew Maison on the 26th August 2016, Friday as we were drawn to their lovely interior design after viewing pictures online.<br><br>When we arrived, we were indeed astonished by their Korean-Japanese fusion theme cafe where the walls are washed with soft pastel Colours, which creates a very inviting ambience. There were only 4 tables being occupied at that point of time, thus the quiet environment made it even more cosy and relaxing. <br>However upon arriving at our table, I was a little turned off by how dirty their sofa were. Their pastel blue cotton sofas was filled with many obvious dirt and food stain that were left behind by previous customers. Not only did it affects the ambience of the cafe, it also made me question their service and hygiene level.<br><br>Furthermore, there were very little food available from their (already very little) food selection and it was only 5.30pm, halfway through their operating time. <br><br>As mention before, the cafe was very quiet thus it&#39;s understandable that they only assign one service staff on duty at that point of time. However, the fact that i have to wait 30mins for a drink and 60mins for my main dish is really ridiculous. The poor service staff (probably new) does not seem to know what he was doing and he could not locate the cook (which resulted in the long wait). The price was rather reasonable but the food was only average, definitely not worth the long wait.<br><br>Overall, I would recommend this place only if you just want to find a place to chill your time away.

text: This spot makes me happy in the morning. Love the toast. All of it. <br><br>But if I&#39;m honest w myself, I&#39;m there for the teh.

Soooo good!  Great value too! Look at that beautiful lamination.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Soooo good!  Great value too! Look at that beautiful lamination.'}]
text: I loved that Toast Box was within walking distance from my hotel. I woke up early every morning looking forward to eat their lava croissants and Nanyang kopi (aka Singapore&#39;s version of coffee). The croissants were flaky, buttery, and crispy. The &#34;lava&#34; filling inside was creamy, custardy goodness. It was amazing. Their kopi is different in that they mix their fragrant coffee with rich condensed milk. I couldn&#39;t get enough of it. Forget Starbucks. Get the kopi here. <br><br>They also have several other baked goods. I&#39;ve only tried their sausage bun and coffee bun, with the latter being quite tasty and one I&#39;d order again. Such aromatic coffee flavor in the bun. <br><br>They also have lunch choices. Of course, I&#39;m obsessed with their laksa. So, I ordered Toastbox&#39;s version of laksa. It was pretty good. The broth was still creamy, but lighter than other versions I&#39;ve tried in Singapore. The noodles were cut into bite size pieces so it can be eaten with a spoon. They even sell their laksa paste so you can bring a little taste of laksa home. <br><br>Overall, this is a solid breakfast and lunch spot in Singapore. They are a chain and have many locations. But, you should only go to a Toast Box in Singapore. We went to one in Hong Kong, and it just wasn&#39;t the same (and it was more expensive. Arghh). <br><br>Please check out Toast Box when you come to Singapore.

The Traditional Kaya toast was pretty good- but nothing revolutionary (toast, butter and jam...). They offer option of soft boiled eggs to dip the toast in which made it more interesting and tasty. The coffee was decent. Service- the guys were a tad rude, but perhaps because of a language barrier. Also- they open at 8:00 AM, NOT 7:30 AM as it states here on Yelp!

text: This outlet is a very popular eating place in Singapore. It can be found almost every where and some are opened as early as 07.30 am every morning. Good place for breakfast, lunch and dinner too. Just now we had a noodle soup and a ham &amp; cheese sandwich set. Quite delicious and satisfying. Good friendly service too.

Cold egg tart means no flow of golden lava (salted egg yolk)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cold egg tart means no flow of golden lava (salted egg yolk)'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/K-WxKxrsb1QE_BFzhFP6pA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/toast-box-singapore-27?reviewid=-tE_DewSdEPQ1TP0z1jF6g&select=K-WxKxrsb1QE_BFzhFP6pA', 'altText': 'Photo of Toast Box - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: If you have not been to the basement of Isetan Scotts, it is time to make a trip. Food Republic has opened, and with it Toast Box and a ramen place. <br><br>The Toast Box at Shaw House is different from the others as it has a tiny bakery attached. The bakery sells buns, tarts and bread and has a different queue from the main Toast Box line. You can order coffee with your baked goods now. <br><br>The main attraction is the egg tart! It has 3 different fillings underneath the egg custard - golden lava (liu sha or salted egg yolk), coconut (grated coconut drenched in gula melaka or brown sugar) and mochi (chewy glutinous rice flour). <br><br>I have only tried the golden lava and coconut. The golden lava was amazing, especially when warm. The liu sha would be a bit liquid and might ooze out if not careful. Not so nice when it was cold. So maybe just re-heat the tarts in the toaster oven for a while before eating. <br><br>The coconut was nice but a bit too sweet, still a nice afternoon treat when you need a perk-me-up or sugar rush. The crust was very buttery, similar to pineapple tart, and broke off easily. Beware the crumbs. <br><br>The coffee is good, as per the usual Toast Box standard. Sometimes the staff may help you find a table during lunch period. The turnover of tables can be quite fast as people do not linger over their food (local stuff like laksa, curry chicken, mee siam etc) and drinks during lunch time. <br><br>Quite a perfect combination for the Breadtalk group. Eat at Food Republic, and hop over for coffee and old school cream cakes or tarts at Toast Box.

Food: 3.5/5.0<br>Service: 2.0/5.0<br>Value: 3.5/5.0<br>Decor: 2.5/5.0<br>Overall: 3.5/5.0<br><br>Did the kopi/egg/toast set.  Kopi was great, and runny eggs and toast were good.  Didn&#39;t try anything from the bakery section.  Looking forward to this chain expanding.

text: A great establishment for a fantastic and unique cup of coffee or a latte. I found out that the coffee beans are hand picked and roasted by Singapore&#39;s reigning barista champion! the food is very well done also. definitely several steps above your standard chain coffee shop. the decor is top notch, great natural light, chill atmosphere, and the staff is always friendly. highly recommended!

Friendly staff and nice location close to my hotel. Kudos for having chai bag of tea, and not forcing me to drink that sugary garbage. Staff was super friendly and very polite. The only downside is the air conditioning was not running in the building when I was there. It was horribly hot and humid, so I had to get my drink to go.

text: Excellent place for a quick, decently priced and freshly cooked meats and vegetables.  The business owners and their staff are very friendly and helpful when they serves us.  What I love most is that every dish that they&#39;ve cooked looked so delicious and tasted so great!  In addition, their cafe is clean and bright and spacious!  We&#39;ve been eating there every day since they&#39;ve opened just so we can taste all their dishes!<br><br>Morning breakfast consists of local delights and of course, toasts, eggs, coffee and tea. After 2 pm, they serve a variety of cook to order food and they are equally fabulous!<br><br>A must try!

text: After walking around the ION dining hall, I found Ya Kun Cafe and wanted to share a combo meal with my parents.<br><br>I ordered the kaya butter toast set which came with the perfectly crisp toast slathered in generous amounts of butter and kaya jam, soft boiled eggs, and kopi range. I also added two more cups of a la carte coffee for my parents.<br><br>I was glad to only order one value set to share between three people. It was just the right amount for a perfect afternoon snack. The kaya toast was absolutely delicious; super aromatic, buttery, and sweet. Super addictive and definitely not health conscious. Kopi was a little sweet with some condensed or evaporated milk but it was strong enough to help tone down the sweetness of the toast. Soft boiled eggs were pretty bland so there&#39;s white pepper and light soy sauce on the side. <br><br>Overall, I was really glad to have tried Ya Kun Cafe and some of the most well-known Singaporean staples. Highly recommend!

text: Dal.Komm is the most underrated place for good savory food in Singapore. Ok, at least IMO. But seriously..<br><br>The first time I was in a Dal.Komm, it was at the location at Centrepoint (or was it Centerpoint (Sp?)) mall. I had a rose latte and a mille crepe. They were good.<br><br>During my quarantine (Stay-Home Notice) in Singapore this past June, I was housed at the Conrad Centennial Singapore. I had all my meals provided in the hotel but knowing me, I needed my sweet treats and a change of food.  With the late night binge watching Doom at Your Service, I definitely needed something to sustain myself throughout the night.<br><br>I ordered from this particular location multiple times throughout my quarantine, via this Foodpanda delivery app for their Rose Latte, Mango Cube and Coffee Cube. They were so yummy! One could not really find something similar anywhere else. At times I would order a few so I could have one for the day and one for the night. Yep, I could be that extra :P <br><br>Then one night I decided to get some snack and saw this Ssamjang Chicken Cruffin on their online menu. There was no going back ever since. That Ssamjang Chicken was absolutely amazing! I never have anything like that. The cruffin was super flakey and the Ssamjang chicken so tasty. Words really could not describe it. One just needed to try and would get to know what I meant. <br><br>The staffs clearly cared and always packed the food and drink items extremely well. I had never physically go to that location before but managed to visit the store before I flew back to Atlanta. The staffs there were super nice and the ambience was definitely an A+<br><br>There was no Yoo Shi-Jin or Seo Dae-young at the café, it was still a cool place to be at. I was happy to be there :D<br><br>Many thanks to the staffs at this Dal.komm location, your staffs made my quarantine even better :)

text: There is a dozen coffee stalls in this hawker food center. This is the first one I tried and it was gooood. The coffee strength is just right, the cup is super heated, the milk proportion perfect. Loved it. <br><br>Usually I have a cup per visit, today I had 2. <br><br>$0.90 is super crazy reasonable by singapore standards!

text: A real nice place to go while kids are having tuition classes. I always thought sitting in this place must be all those lazy free people, but now I realize that&#39;s not true! The busy people also sometimes have to have such kind of places to accomplish their busy task.<br>Caramel or hazelnut latte are my usual choices, the kids love the red valet cake or cheese cake, sometimes breakfast could be a choice as well...
