text: The cafe was located at the bus interchange, but away from the busy buzz. Usually there will be free wifi, but the network was down when I was around that day. One can detect 2 pokestops while dining at the cafe. There was a gym which was just a stone throw away.<br><br>Turkey Bacon &amp; Cream Pasta ($9.90)<br>The dish was served with parmesan cheese and breadstick on the side. The pasta was coated in a rich and creamy sauce which was not bad. <br><br>Brew of the day Coffee ($4.20/ regular)<br>I had it with milk which tasted average.  <br><br>The place was quiet and cozy. Too bad there was no free wifi, else I would stay a bit longer.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/F8yHSUSAMGQ1M3ySDIwmkQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/ya-kun-kaya-toast-singapore-22?reviewid=hxOEKb-q7irvmnDbzeP7Xg&select=F8yHSUSAMGQ1M3ySDIwmkQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Ya Kun Kaya Toast - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Set A breakfast. 2 soft boiled eggs, Kopi C &amp; Kaya toast. Was surprised that they used brown bread split in half. This made the bread a little too dry when toasted. The quality of the coffee used was robust with a nutty taste. The eggs were done perfectly! No egg whites on the inside of the shells. The yolk was bouncy and very much runny. An authentic local breakfast for all to try.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ruHRuJDeynfFGF-mdZRD_g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/ya-kun-kaya-toast-singapore-22?reviewid=54YM3o4iwGNUK7pQmAuG4w&select=ruHRuJDeynfFGF-mdZRD_g', 'altText': 'Photo of Ya Kun Kaya Toast - Singapore, Singapore. Kaya toast', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Kaya toast'}]
text: Kaya Toast was on my list of things to try while visiting Singapore. My research led me to Ya Kun and conveniently this location was close to where we were staying. It was still early so it wasn&#39;t super busy when we arrived. We both ordered kaya toast with 2 boiled eggs and iced coffee. My husband ordered peanut butter kaya toast while I stuck to<br><br>Everything is made it order and our food came out quickly. We tried each other&#39;s kaya toast and both preferred the original. It was sweet and tasty. Dipping the toast in the soft boiled eggs is highly recommended. Coffee was good too. I recommend trying kaya toast from this place.

I&#39;ve been an ardent fan of Ya Kun since the age of 6. And 50+ years later, still going for my comfort food very regularly visiting any branches I chanced upon. <br><br>However, this morning&#39;s visit is very amazing. I&#39;m greeting with warmth and smile from the cashier and she even cracked a joke with a Chinese saying! And the lady in charges of toasting the breads brought it to be when she&#39;s done and she does to all her customers! With a smile and eye contact. Similarly when the cashier thanked me, she made eye contact too. <br><br>And I noticed that the tables were cleaned up very speedily. So the place is keep clean and neat throughout my stay. <br><br>And i especially have to mention that the cashier is just as friendly to the supplier who came in to ask if she needs anything. She made eye contact, smiled and thanked him for dropping by. <br><br>I have to write this because this is the most feel good Ya Kun place I&#39;ve been to and trust me, I&#39;ve been to many in and out of Singapore. <br><br>Take heart that there&#39;s a really wonderful Ya Kun in Fortune Centre and I&#39;m definitely going to be there again!
Great first breakfast in Singapore! NEED this place in the U.S. Peach iced tea with chunks of peaches...the jam on the kaya was AMAZING. Love, love, love.

As part of the Ya Kun Kaya Toast chain you get reliably good Kaya toast (I recommend butter sugar toast) and kopi here. Stay away from their seasonal things like Kaya balls and other promotion items. Those usually end up being limp in taste. Air con needs some work at this outlet. It&#39;s a good spot to start your day at.

Steamed Kaya Toast!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Steamed Kaya Toast!'}]
text: Ya Kun Kaya Toast was one of the recommended places to get kaya toast when I was doing my research on Singapore. So on our first morning, we walked over to this location which was close by.<br><br>While there weren&#39;t a ton of people inside, there was a consistent stream of people coming in and out. Most of them seemed to already know what they wanted to order, so I assume they must be regulars.<br><br>The menu has a variety of toast options, and most people order the set ($4.80), which comes with a toast of your choice, 2 soft boiled eggs (or hard boiled if you ask), and a drink (tea/coffee).<br><br>We tried both the Steamed Kaya Toast and the Cheese Toast. I loved how warm and fluffy the steamed toast was, which sat comfortably in my stomach. In contrast, the cheese toast was bland, and I really couldn&#39;t tell that there was cheese in it. Also the bread was flat, hard and a little on the burnt side.<br><br>What I also didn&#39;t really love, was the 2 eggs. I&#39;m a little iffy about runny eggs, so we asked for them to be cooked fully, which was not a problem, only took a little more time. Even after waiting though, the eggs were still on the undercooked side.<br><br>In general though, I really enjoyed my first kaya toast in Singapore. This place really provides a quick and cheap way to taste a Singaporean breakfast! Unfortunately I&#39;m not the kind of person to enjoy the eggs, but I can see how other people love it.

text: If this is one of the better Ya Kun Kaya Toast&#39;s location the others must be disgusting.<br>The coffee was very good, but that&#39;s it.<br>The place was dirty, service unfriendly, they even wanted to charge a simple napkin. At least it was something new, Kaya with semi-boiled eggs.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=Ovdu6JsesZc1x19gsWSprA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/soYYPiO3N0BPwkasX4_Y5w/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Emily C.', 'displayLocation': 'Los Angeles, CA', 'altText': 'Emily C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=Ovdu6JsesZc1x19gsWSprA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 12, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 111, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I&#39;m not a huge breakfast person, specifically because I don&#39;t love eggs, but if I&#39;m going to eat them, I like &#39;em poached. I came here on my first morning in Singapore and enjoyed the spot. It&#39;s not fancy, but I wasn&#39;t looking for fancy, so it worked. I had two poached eggs with toast and black sweetened ice coffee for $5.60 (in Singapore dollars). I was surprised when I bit into the toast and there was a giant slice of butter and a sweet spread on the toast, but it was tasty despite the surprise. <br>From what I understand, this is a traditional breakfast, so definitely worth trying, although I look forward to trying something different tomorrow (aka it wasn&#39;t so stupendous that i&#39;d forfeit an opportunity to try something new).

text: Kaya toast with soft boil egg and tea is the best thing I have tried in singapore so far.  I have not had good experience with singapore food before this anyways.  $4.80 for the combo.  I recommend getting tea which is not just hot water and tea leaves. <br>The combo was very filling.  I saw people cracking open the soft boil egg and soak it with bread. But I opt to eat it separately.  Needed a bit of seasoning. They also sell kaya jam here which makes a great souvenir.

text: Rather than eat the sad buffet at Ibis hotel next door I opted to drag the guys to this toast joint next door. There&#39;s a entrance inside the fortune center as well as outside. We ordered a variety so we could try everything! Steamed bread with kaya, toast with kaya and some cheese toast with kaya on the side. The eggs are runny and best with a dizzle of soy. Be sure to get a iced coffee. They are strong and delicious. This is a solid spot for breakfast. It&#39;s crowded in the morning and the tables go neglected. Be sure to ask for napkins if you want any!

As part of the Ya Kun Kaya Toast chain you get reliably good Kaya toast (I recommend butter sugar toast) and kopi here. Stay away from their seasonal things like Kaya balls and other promotion items. Those usually end up being limp in taste. Air con needs some work at this outlet. It&#39;s a good spot to start your day at.

text: If this is one of the better Ya Kun Kaya Toast&#39;s location the others must be disgusting.<br>The coffee was very good, but that&#39;s it.<br>The place was dirty, service unfriendly, they even wanted to charge a simple napkin. At least it was something new, Kaya with semi-boiled eggs.

So this is a good place for some authentic Kaya toast or even take home a jar of kaya for less than $5. But the real star for me was the Kopi O- delicious strong black coffee that is brewed using a slow drip method. It is ever so slightly sweet and absolutely one of the best coffees I ever tasted. The &#34;O&#34; stands for black, by the way. Order it hot or iced. Cheap and you get a huge 16 ounce glass.

A hell of a good cup of coffee!  Great Ethiopian blend, blueberry aromas and blended into a cafe  au last...really kind of caught me off guard it was so full bodied and nice.  <br><br>Currently the only &#34;coffee specific&#34; coffee shop in the Marina One the Heart mall in the CBD, what a charming little spot for a cup of joe.  Also to find out that the first Jewel coffee shop opened up in the CBD One Shenton Way in only 2011, Jewel is like the fastest growing coffee house chain in Singapore with several outlets around the island. <br><br>They have seating, the decor is &#34;red subway tile meets stainless steel &amp; wood&#34; is cute yet edgy, the staff is friendly and your cup is brewed fresh.  The bean was good, the single origin flavor and its delicious roasted aroma is better than the average house blend you will find out there.  I am a hard core coffee drinker and I was impressed.  They rotate their bean varietals daily. <br><br>And from a marketing perspective, their loyalty card is a home run (I don&#39;t know why all coffee spots don&#39;t have them...It makes a customer like me loyal! DUH!).  It tosses a dog a bone and I always like to see this touch at establishments.  Buy 8 coffee drinks, get one free! <br><br>I enjoy giving my money to anyone but the Starbucks monster machine, so I think I might be in love with the new gem of Jewel Coffee in my hood.

Cute original place reminding me of Killiney but not as commercial chain-like. They have western health food influences like whole wheat instead of only white bread for your traditional toasts. And orange ciabatta? Wow, pretty impressive.<br><br>Good morning Nanyang is small and convenient, right by the Chinatown station. <br><br>I got a honey lemon drink, while my mom got a complicated version of coffee. Quick service on a weekday afternoon. There&#39;s also a buzzer to let us know when our food is ready. <br><br>I had traditional toast, good but nothing special. Orange ciabatta with butter was surprisingly tasty! A little sweetness, but not too much. Nicely toasted and not too much butter. Love it!<br><br>My honey lemon drink was nicely done. Not too sweet but not too bland. My mom also really enjoyed her coffee, and has been frequenting this location for awhile. <br><br>I wouldn&#39;t make a special trip to visit, but if I was by chinatown and was looking for a short break or snack, I will definitely stop by. P.S. there is free wifi if you need some!

Lunch crowd', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Lunch crowd'}]
text: I&#39;m giving this 3.5 stars. The sweet spot to come in during lunch time is before people finished eating lunch as many actually came for the after meal coffee. <br><br>I had the chicken curry with rice set which came with a drink. The coffee was nice but it was not sweet. Perfect for those who always order their drinks as &#34;siu dai&#34; (less sweet) as this is their normal. I requested for more sweetness and it was still not as sweet as the drinks you get at Ya Kun or Killiney or Toastbox. <br><br>The rice which came with the chicken curry was very hard. It looked like it was scraped from the bottom of the rice cooker. Either that or it was old rice. Being a Monday I would not be surprised if they actually served leftover rice. The chicken curry was good, thick rich spicy gravy with potato and 3 pieces of chicken (2 mini drumlets and a mid-wing). <br><br>It got noisy when packed and you could hardly hear yourself think. There was nothing to absorb the noise. <br><br>I would be interested to try the other food as they do have different types of bread for toast.

Orange Ciabatta Kaya Toast', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Orange Ciabatta Kaya Toast'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/0mMDRVqmQq4VUancA55erw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/good-morning-nanyang-cafe-singapore-2?reviewid=s29x2N6-e8PeC-hpwDZbJg&select=0mMDRVqmQq4VUancA55erw', 'altText': 'Photo of Good Morning Nanyang Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Set C: Orange Ciabatta + Kopi O + 2 eggs for S$5.50', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Set C: Orange Ciabatta + Kopi O + 2 eggs for S$5.50'}]
text: Hidden in a little back corner at bustling Far East Plaza is this branch of this lesser known chain. Perfect for those like me who wants to enjoy a quiet traditional breakfast of a cup of kopi, soft boiled eggs and kaya bread but dont want the noise and crowds at the popular Ya Kun. <br>Though not so traditional is their wonderful take on the traditional toast. Here, you have the option of ciabatta toast which is fluffier and less dry than normal kaya toast. Even better is the orange ciabatta where the tinge of orange zest complements perfectly with the smooth pandan kaya. <br>As with most kopi toast places, they also serve an array of local asian fare for a more filling meal. These include curry chicken, laksa and mee siam.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/MOQXTiKU2_WhKLASDs9kpA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/good-morning-nanyang-cafe-singapore-2?reviewid=BZ9crxyOpUenJFMyvJihCg&select=MOQXTiKU2_WhKLASDs9kpA', 'altText': 'Photo of Good Morning Nanyang Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Bamboo Charcoal Bread set', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Bamboo Charcoal Bread set'}]
text: 5 minutes walk from Orchard MRT to Far East Plaza. Tried the Black Charcoal Bread Set (SGD$6.80) - standard like any other kopi place (2 x soft boil eggs, 1 drink - I chose kopi C ping). A tad more expensive than the rest but the bread alone already costs SGD$3.00 (promo price). <br><br>The highlight was the black charcoal bread. A good amount of sunflower seeds on the bread. Toasted until crispy on the outside but still fluffy inside - the tradeoff is a good 5-10 minutes wait. A tad too much butter layered on top of the kaya. <br><br>Nothing to note for the Kopi C ping nor the pair of soft boiled eggs.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BWK_4vLd0Kcd0L0Dy_5v1Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/la-ristrettos-singapore?reviewid=KEQacpvWY29xlnDZiu1bxQ&select=BWK_4vLd0Kcd0L0Dy_5v1Q', 'altText': 'Photo of La Ristrettos - Singapore, Singapore. Savory pancakes ($11) - spinach instead of bacon', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Savory pancakes ($11) - spinach instead of bacon'}]
text: In the back of my mind La Ristrettos has always been just another cute hipster cafe. But they&#39;ve upped their game with their pancake offerings!<br><br>Savory pancakes ($11) - 5 stars<br>My first-world brunch problem has always been &#34;I really want the pancakes/French toast with caramelized bananas and ice cream but I&#39;ll feel sick after a few bites and wish I ordered something savory.&#34; La Ristrettos solves this with their savory pancakes: two huge pancakes with a mass of scrambled eggs and bacon with a side of maple syrup. I asked if I could substitute the bacon for some sort of vegetable and the lady kindly offered spinach. The cherry (cheese) on top was that they cooked the spinach and garnished it with a dollop of ricotta. I suppose from bad experiences elsewhere I was expecting them to say no, or just give me a few token raw greens, so this was such a pleasant surprise. The scrambled eggs were creamy and substantial and the pancakes were gigantic and fluffy! These were the pancakes I&#39;d expected Clinton St to have, and that I&#39;ve been looking for! No more $20 tiny pancakes thank you.<br><br>They also offer sweet pancakes with vanilla gelato and salted caramel that I&#39;m going to have to come back to try.

text: Brunch at @laristrettos <br><br>French Toast with Bacon and Banana (S$13.80)<br><br>Signature Crab Linguine (S$14.90)<br><br>Flat White (S$5)<br><br>Original Lemonade (S$3.60/ large)<br><br>Only indoor dine in area so quite limited seats. Waited quite awhile for the food to be served. I&#39;m so hungry that I finished everything. Mom was wowed by the roasting machine. She thought it&#39;s for show.

text: It&#39;s a hole-in-the-wall place, hard to find and only known to a few. Or if you happen to work here, this could be a great hide-out for a quiet lunch. Not common to see some office, doctor-types on weekdays. Minus one star as the place is small and might not have enough seats now given the safe-distancing measures. The place also kinda smelt like fried food, which I can smell through my mask. Oh well, luckily I came early on a weekday for brunch and I snagged the counter seat with some green views.

text: I walked past quite a few times as my dentist is located on this floor and if it wouldn&#39;t be for Yelp I would have continued walking by. But the Yelper in me says that a place hidden in a corner with tons of positive reviews must be good and indeed, it is!<br><br>I am not a big coffee connoisseur, I am more of your average Starbucks girl but this latte was good! I really enjoyed the aroma of the coffee. I also had an egg toast with avocado and that was pretty decent too. <br><br>Next time I have to go to the dentist I will make some extra time to have another cuppa and some food!

text: Great little cafe tucked away in a medical center. Good selection of caffeine beverages and tea, but only a few dessert items offered. The reason they do not have decaffeinated coffee is because they only serve their own in-house roasted beans and am not interested in the complicated decaffeination process. <br><br>There is food too, mainly pasta. Indoor and outdoor seatings. Relaxing atmosphere with nice music (inside) and if you like the sound of iron beams being jack hammered into place, you can sit outside (until the hotel is completed, that is).

text: I&#39;ll admit: I&#39;m quite picky about my coffee. And while I usually complain about the standard of coffee in cafes around Singapore, I also frown at the hefty price tags many popular coffee establishments place on my favourite caffeinated drink. <br><br>I found out about this gem of a place by some chance encounter some years back and I remember being pleasantly surprised by how a cafe that actually got its coffee right was able to keep itself hidden in a little corner of a medical centre. While I feared that it would eventually close due to a lack of awareness from the community, I&#39;m glad that it&#39;s not only doing well, but also getting a lot of positive attention (which it fully deserves) in recent years. <br><br>The ambience here is classy. Very nicely spruced up decor - if the indoor seating gets a little too cramped, the outdoor area has plenty of sitting space too. <br><br>The food here is a little on the pricey side, but definitely worth giving a shot. The coffee, however, is where it shines. <br><br>Definitely one of my favourite coffee haunts in central Singapore.

Crab cake breakfast', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Crab cake breakfast'}]
text: The coffee here was great.  I had an iced latte and an espresso on my visit.  I also had the crab cake breakfast which was delicious and filling.  The rest of the menu looked good and also like there are daily specials.  I went at around 9 am on a weekday and it was not crowded, so the crowds are probably at lunch.  The register is just inside the door, so a line in the hall might make it look more busy than it really is, but there is ample seating in the neighboring courtyard.  On the 8th floor of the medical building (a little hard to find) but worth the trip.

It&#39;s places like La Ristrettos that make me thankful that I Yelp.<br><br>Why do I say that? First of all, the chances of finding this place is pretty low. It&#39;s in the most random location ever- the 8th floor of the fairly new Novena Medical Center. There are no advertisements around Square 2 or anywhere else around the medical center (at least, that I&#39;ve noticed) so unless you have a doctor&#39;s appointment on the 8th floor, you&#39;ll never know this place even existed! But thanks to Yelp, you are now cooler and better person. :)<br><br>I loved the ambiance of this place. It&#39;s quite cozy, with cute, vintage coffee signs on the walls. They have high-tech machines that make badass brews. The free pitchers of ice water with orange slices was a nice touch. They were also playing some classic Frank Sinatra while I was there, which put me in an even better mood. <br><br>I wanted to have breakfast, but most of their breakfast offerings seemed too heavy for me. They had dishes like croissants and frittatas, but they all come with salads, which I simply wasn&#39;t in the mood for. (Also, who has salads for breakfast?!) I did see some smaller offerings in their counter, but it wasn&#39;t well labelled and I didn&#39;t feel like asking about them. I ended up settling for a banana and a cappuccino. <br><br>I&#39;m not a big coffee drinker, so all I can say is that I did enjoy my cappuccino and I thought it was fairly priced at $5. <br><br>Bottom line, my first visit was a success. If they could offer smaller bakery items and free wifi, they would really win me over. If you have time before your medical appointment, or even if you&#39;re just hanging around the Square 2/Velocity/Tan Tock Seng area and you&#39;re craving an upscale coffee experience, ignore Starbucks and give La Ristrettos a try.

text: Wasn&#39;t able to try their pasta mains as they&#39;re only available after 12pm (was there ard 11am) so I opted for the Tostini (roasted chicken breast, spinach, tomato and a poached egg on top sourdough bread accompanied with honey mustard sauce) - was average, nothing specky except I really liked the honey mustard sauce and egg was poached perfectly. Mum&#39;s choice was heaps better (I had secretly wanted to prefer that but wouldn&#39;t make sense for both of us to have the same mains). She had the New breakfast #1 (smoked duck breast on a bed of peas with potato croquettes and poached egg accompanied with honey mustard sauce) - it was yummm!! <br><br>You can be sure you&#39;ll get a good cuppa coffee here and the barista takes so much pride in preparing your cuppa with cool latte art! Had a Piccolo latte and Americano and left us happy as punch :)<br><br>I&#39;ll definitely return to try their pasta and for their coffee.

text: La Ristrettos is hidden on the 8th floor of Novena Medical Centre. If you haven&#39;t been here, you probably wouldn&#39;t know that this cafe existed. This building is directly connected to Novena MRT Station and it&#39;s very easy to find (just take the exit towards square 2). Not to worry, there are lots of parking lots in this building.<br><br>It&#39;s a small and quiet cafe. Since this place is so secluded, there aren&#39;t a lot of customers especially during weekdays. This cafe is probably catered towards providing a nice and cozy environment for surgeons to take a break from their hectic schedules or to discuss some work over a nice cup of coffee. 3G reception is poor here, fortunately they provide free WiFi.<br><br>They is a big table placed in the centre (that can probably fit 10 people) and a long table top (with red plastic chairs) facing the garden.The interior is filled with wooden furniture, with fake bricks embedded onto the walls. Outdoor seats are also available in the garden for you to breathe in some fresh air. Besides, this cafe is tax-free - you could save a couple of bucks!<br><br>I ordered their Macchiato ($3.50). The coffee is smooth and tastes great. Could have been much better with some caramel to sweeten things up! I later found out that they are the sole distributor of Caffe Agust Beans which is an Italian coffee brand that is organic and certified 100% Fairtrade.<br><br>I love the presentation of the food here! Food is served in brightly coloured dishes on a nice wooden tray. I tried their Grande breakfast set ($14.00). You have 3 choices for the egg (either poached, scrambled or sunny side). Served together with mushrooms, sausage, salad and 2 slices of sourdough. Sausage and salad dressing was good. However, bacon was burnt and quite tough. Poached eggs were a disappointment - it&#39;s overcooked!<br><br>For coffee lovers, this is the place to go. Food is satisfactory, not good enough to keep me coming back. As for me, I think I&#39;ll only come back for their coffee, provided I&#39;m around the area.<br><br>Signing Off,<br>Zhan Hao<br>Founder of TheCafection

The complete set up - cappuccino, breakfast sandwich, and a view of an 8th floor garden - priceless :)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The complete set up - cappuccino, breakfast sandwich, and a view of an 8th floor garden - priceless :)'}]
text: La Ristrettos is hidden away on the 8th floor of the Novena Medical Center.  Sure, there is a sign by the entrance to the elevator lobby but without actively seeking out the spot or unless you happen to be a patient on the 8th floor, you would never find this place, which would be your loss.  La Ristrettos serves some excellent coffee and food, which would put the other coffee places in Novena to shame.  Start with the coffee and the name sake - ristretto.  They actually have a ristretto pulled espresso on the menu!  Sure, you can ask a barrista to use less water, but here it&#39;s a given.  But their lattes and cappuccinos are also really good - love the strong coffee against a creamy backdrop.  But the surprise would have to be the breakfast sandwiches.  I had the one with eggs and pancetta, and it was delicious!  Yes it&#39;s a little pricey at $11 but totally worth it.   By using pancetta, I didn&#39;t get that nasty surprise - turkey bacon.  And the bread was amazing - a little hard on the outside but chewy, I would have loved to take a few and use them for a proper Philly cheesesteak.  Service may be a little slow, but it&#39;s really worth the wait for the hand crafted coffee drinks and food.  Plus the view of a secret garden is so peaceful, you hardly notice.

text: Coffee here is on point! Brunch is great, my favourite on their menu is the crab cake. Smoothies are also delicious, banana chocolate is a must try. Friendly staff and lovely ambience. Outdoor seating in the garden is really refreshing.

text: The good atmosphere! I study at the cafe during the whole morning. I would suggest you to have a good day there. Plus, the tea was quite excellent.

&#34;I need coffee so badly&#34;<br><br>&#34;Quick! I&#39;ll take you to the hospital&#34;<br><br>Well, that&#39;s not quite the reaction I was imagining when needing a coffee on a recent trip to Singapore. I mean, I know I&#39;m a caffeine addict but a visit to the hospital? Really?<br><br>Turns out there&#39;s a cafe serving good coffee in amongst the long and hidden corridors of the Novena Medical Centre. You&#39;ll ride the lift with people heading off to see there acupuncturist, gynaecologist,  allergist, neurologist, dermatologist... and you&#39;ll feel both smug and shameful all at the same time because you&#39;re heading off to see Doctor Coffee and have no ailments at all, except for a terrible addiction.

Hidden in the crevice of Novena Medical Center, this place is a real gem if you happen to be in the area. There is limited seating inside, but there is a whole garden outside for you to explore! Why stay indoors! Zen out sipping on your espresso while watching leaves drop into the little pond in the center of the garden. <br><br>If you&#39;re looking for coffee that is bold and strong. You&#39;ve found the right place. To all you third wave coffee lovers out there, you&#39;re going to be disappointed if you were looking for something fruity and juicy. <br><br>*Free wifi available.

text: A self proclaimed coffee specialist that does not serve pourovers. The girl at the teller didn&#39;t know what a pourover is either. FAIL.<br><br>Other than that, the piccolo latte I had was nicely done. <br><br>The indoor seating area does cloy up with the smells from the kitchens. I elected to sit outdoors in the courtyard.  The courtyard is a great venue.

text: Excellent artisan coffees made by expert baristas who take their job seriously. <br><br>Above average Food is decent, but probably not the main attraction here. The chicken cotaletta sandwich is fresh and well made. <br><br>The main let down is speed of service in which they sometimes can be overwhelmed during weekends.

text: What an oasis. Sure, you have to go into a medical building to get there, but once you arrive, you&#39;re transported to a little bit of coffee heaven. Give yourself some time since everything is freshly made. And while the interior is fun, I loved sitting in the quiet garden outside.

Latte at La Ristretto&#39;s', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': "Latte at La Ristretto's"}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fCGjMJq_CUo47ZMQyAFs9Q/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/la-ristrettos-singapore?reviewid=QaWsco8L2nnij-ghVplXzw&select=fCGjMJq_CUo47ZMQyAFs9Q', 'altText': 'Photo of La Ristrettos - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/2m9XiA3Wn2rcR-q1p3OIgw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/la-ristrettos-singapore?reviewid=QaWsco8L2nnij-ghVplXzw&select=2m9XiA3Wn2rcR-q1p3OIgw', 'altText': 'Photo of La Ristrettos - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Novena medical centre is exactly as you would expect - unremarkable corridors lined with doctors offices, waiting rooms, more doctors offices, yet more waiting rooms, and in the midst of all this, an unexpected outlier - a small and cosy Italian style cafe, serving up interesting ristretto shots. <br><br>The inside is quite small and cosy, but the limited space is put to good use. A communal table lies in the centre of the room, flanked by counter seats, and a door that leads to a shaded outdoor seating area. Tampers and espresso shot cups line the shelves, while the staff pull shots at an open bar counter lined with espresso machines and grinders. I like the concept - it&#39;s always interesting to see the baristas at work, and for coffee geeks, to see the shots themselves being pulled. This can tell you a lot about the quality of coffee at a cafe - a spaghetti strand sized column of dark black liquid slowly lining a shot cup is a sign of good underlying espresso, while a 10 second downpour of pale brown liquid is a hint that you should quietly slip out the entrance without waiting for your drink. Fortunately, La Ristretto&#39;s shots were good examples of the former, with a 20 second extraction of potent espresso.  <br><br>The espresso shot had a medium brown crema, and a robust, full bodied flavour with distinct hints of chocolate. It was bright without being bitter, and potent without being burnt. The shot glass of water on the side is a nice touch also, and was used, as the serving size is a little larger than usual for a single shot. The coffee beans used were from Agust coffee roasters in Italy, which I haven&#39;t come across in Asia before, and are quite distinct in their own right. It&#39;s also interesting to be able to sample a robust Italian style espresso, which contrasts with the trend for citrusy single origin shots that are on offer in a number of cafes at present. <br><br>The latte that I ordered had smooth foam, and a large serving size. It was quite mild, but the underlying espresso shot was muted rather than being completely lost, and could easily be detected in the aftertaste.  This may be the result of the larger espresso shot sizes mentioned earlier. The overall character was of coffee rather than milk, so despite the serving size, it avoids the easy mistake of serving warm caffeinated warm milk, rather than coffee. The foam maintained it&#39;s integrity throughout, without breaking up - a small detail, but one that&#39;s consistent with correct steaming temperature and duration, and something that I&#39;ve seen a few cafes get wrong in recent weeks.<br><br>There is a good coffee menu on offer, with the usual combinations of espresso and milk, and brewed coffees. One thing that differs is the presence of shakerato on the menu (a shaken cold espresso), that I have not seen before, and something that I&#39;m genuinely curious to see made. Prices were as expected, at 8.50 for the latte and espresso above.<br><br>Overall, La Ristretto&#39;s is interesting in that they are serving something genuinely different, and it&#39;s an opportunity to try a fairly authentic Italian espresso. The location may be an issue for some, in that it&#39;s in the middle of a medical centre, rather than in a standalone cafe. This should not deter you from visiting during non peak hours however, especially if you happen to be in the area. However do bear in mind that the cafe itself is quite small, so please let patients and staff take priority!

text: Excellent coffee place, sadly in a very hidden location. You need to take up the elevator to the 8th floor and then walk past a couple of medical suites to get to this gem. It&#39;s a small but lovely place in the otherwise sterile environment of the medical center. Good strong and bold coffee with creamy milk.

text: Nice hidden gem in what feels like a sterile hospital. Randomly found it while looking for our gp,i had thr mango/strawberry and it was amazing. The cafe is small but the decor is nice. We didnt have time to try the food but the wife said the coffee was amazing as well (beans are from Italy).

Stopped in this arvo for a quick coffee and some cake to satisfy a need for something sweet and I wasn&#39;t disappointed. The coffee was excellent and it was served with a smile by the nice young guy at the counter. I also had a slice of their lavender earl grey cake and it was divine! I&#39;d go back just for the cake and need to figure out the recipe pronto. The cafe is right on the corner of Maju and Farleigh so it&#39;s a great place to watch the world go by. I will certainly be stopping by again the next time I&#39;m in Serangoon Gardens.

text: Came by for breakfast the other day and it was a tasty experience. Located in the Owen Link at Farrer Park, it is a more of a quick service venue.<br><br>Ordered the hot milk tea which came out smooth and not too sweet.<br><br>The Mee Siam was on the sweeter side and also had a nice kick to it. The Vermicelli was light.<br><br>The fried Bee Hoon with fried chicken wing and egg was a light a tasty breakfast too!<br><br>Ordering is done at the counter as this is a self service cafe. The cafe does have A/C!
Pretty good bakery with a variety of artisan bread selection.<br><br>The croissant sandwiches here are quite good (though a bit pricey) as well.

Located in Dempsey this place is a bakery cum cafe. Their specialty is sourdough bread and they have a wide array of freshly baked goods on display. We tried their sourdough and soy bread which had a nice nutty flavor that went well with the sourdough taste. We also tried some meringue cookies which were average. I would definitely go back to try more of their breads.

text: It is such a cute little shop offering simple yet pleasurable coffee and pastries. It is a close walk from the riverside and is easy to locate. The interior is clean and service was pleasant. I ordered a cappacino and Brie sandwich and they both were delectable. There were many patrons dot &amp; dashing (see what I did there? ) as their service is extremely quick yet efficient.

text: A nice cafe with plenty of sunshine coming in thru the windows! I tried their lunch set menu, which comes with a pita and ice tea, the price is decent however portion is quite small. Definitely recommended if u just want to find a place for a good chat and some sweet dessert!

text: Beautiful cafe, went on Friday at 3 pm and there were a lot of seats, so that was nice. Staff was very friendly and the food was great! Ordered the strawberry shortcake that costed 6.5$, the chocolate croissant (it looks like a danish) that was 7$ and the raspberry scone for 4.5$. I ordered the cappucino and it was presented very cutely, with a teddy illustration! The cappucino also came with a cute lil biscuit! Their iced mocha was super delicious, and it costed 7.5$ (it was really good). Their Blissful Berries drink (it&#39;s under the tea section) tasted really good too! Not your usual tea I suppose. And also look at their bathroom tho, how extra! Lovely cafe, would definitely come back for a chill tea time with friends. People come here with their families too! Salad-loving friends can join the crew too because they also sell salad, it costs 14.9 and if i&#39;m not wrong they have three &#39;flavours&#39;. They also have other main dishes!

Clean and cool inside. They have some kind of neato popsicles but didn&#39;t try those. Hokkaido milk flavor was one that stands out. Honestly ducked in here to use the restroom bc I didn&#39;t wanna use the ones at the market. The hub got some English tea and a cream pastry which he said was alright. It was bright inside. And the bathroom was super cute and clean although outdoors kind of so felt hot. Still grateful to be able to use it. They also have French macarons which were v pretty. Not sure of the taste though.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SlBHEpeKnkMh961K_nQqZA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/whisk-cafe-singapore?reviewid=7HrlWL3byQnJmnpzPJPvAw&select=SlBHEpeKnkMh961K_nQqZA', 'altText': 'Photo of Whisk Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Mother&#39;s cooking. Reasonable priced sandwiches and a very nice and clean cafe with window seats looking into Tiong Bahru. There&#39;s also an actual piano so if you&#39;re game go right at it!<br><br>Perfect air-conditioned place for a coffee and a cake otherwise in the afternoon.
Pastries are so-so, coffee and other drinks just average. So sad that the former roast meat store occupying this space was replaced by a generic cafe.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ifk-yrsiMzFP5AGnnJbdQA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/whisk-cafe-singapore?reviewid=I2fF4FAsAK8l7NrC_h6kJw&select=ifk-yrsiMzFP5AGnnJbdQA', 'altText': 'Photo of Whisk Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AWg0Ddvd8hWgiLTMBHzfDg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/whisk-cafe-singapore?reviewid=I2fF4FAsAK8l7NrC_h6kJw&select=AWg0Ddvd8hWgiLTMBHzfDg', 'altText': 'Photo of Whisk Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Latte and piccolo latte (50cents difference...)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Latte and piccolo latte (50cents difference...)'}]
text: This place is getting more and more crowded.... <br><br>You are actually spoilt for choice when wanting a cuppa coffee in Tiong Bahru. Whisk is but one of the many cafes around the area offering you a decent cuppa coffee and pastries. Price range is about the same as most others. Pastry and cake selection not as wide. <br><br>But still a nice place to just people watch (right at the cross road where Tiong Bahru market is) or just read a book (not as busy as Tiong Bahru bakery right across the road, and definitely not as noisy...). <br><br>No wifi though and I don&#39;t see power points around...

text: Whisk is a cozy cafe right in the heart of Tiong Bahru.  The staff are nice and you can tell that the owner/chef takes a lot of pride in her work. The atmosphere is warm and inviting so it&#39;s a nice place to relax with a cup of coffee, but the star of the show are the desserts.  I first tried the cheescake which was amazing... hints of citrus which I quite liked and a smooth, creamy texture.  Another time I tried the carrot cake; now I&#39;m not really a carrot cake person, but this was damn good. Not too sweet with a nice, nutty flavor.  Will definitely go back to try other pastries :)

text: Agreed with all the good comments on this clean cut deco and spacious cafe. The staff was pleasant and knowledgable. Impressed with the nice toilet  and wash basin lay out. It is a good place to chill on a week day afternoon. Think it makes a pleasant place to hold small discussion too.

text: Cute deco but I dunno how long it will last. Good looks can only go so far. The pastries are alright but they&#39;re too sweet and over priced. The staff are really nice but too bad they have a mean lady boss she will say a horrible thing but in a &#34;nice&#34; tone, those people are the worst! Good luck!

text: Newest cafe in the area. Not a bad place to pick up a drink on the way to work. Quick &amp; Easy unlike the other cafes up near Kim Tian.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=c1MlVimAp5QjP1GU75zXvA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'C T.', 'displayLocation': 'Houston, TX', 'altText': 'C T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=c1MlVimAp5QjP1GU75zXvA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 5, 'reviewCount': 45, 'eliteYear': None}
text: A very nice little cafe. Great pastries and cakes. A nice cup of coffee. A very modern look and quiet atmosphere. Beautiful food. They staff is very friendly and eager to have you as a customer. I&#39;m told the carrot cake is very good and think I will go back to try it out. The lemon tart was even better than it looked and it looked amazing.

The Moroccan Mint Late is a really good tea based drink, quite tasty and hit&#39;s the spot. The Coffee Bean &amp; Tea Leaf consistently has exceptional roasts and tea blends. Far better than Starbucks, and I was quite glad to see one in Singapore so went out of my way to visit.

text: Probably not the west place in singapore..... but certainly amongst them!  With so many great places to eat the only thing to say about this &#34;caf&#34; is that it serves hot tea, albeit right  , and it was convenient.  Unless you are desperate, do yourself and favour and keep walking and certainly don&#39;t eat from here

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cc3nWEDFC5YIK-_k3WTqmg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/k88-coffee-house-singapore?reviewid=1skmNUjmfnlt-pzMy3Wbww&select=cc3nWEDFC5YIK-_k3WTqmg', 'altText': 'Photo of K88 Coffee House - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: K 88 Coffee House is a typical Singapore Style Kopi Tiam, where all day long hot coffee like KopiO and Traditional  Tea is served in the relaxed atmosphere of Chinatown. Every good Coffee House in Singapore has his Food Stalls-here it is: Chicken Rice, Steamed Dumplings, Seafood, Thai Food, and the ever popular &#34;Economy Rice&#34;

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hHZhsgjbmNaPtBqejBt8-g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/k88-coffee-house-singapore?reviewid=_FHW2lWLnMnino1YUKa_Hw&select=hHZhsgjbmNaPtBqejBt8-g', 'altText': 'Photo of K88 Coffee House - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/K08w3-mToG4x5TGu5ew1Ng/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/k88-coffee-house-singapore?reviewid=_FHW2lWLnMnino1YUKa_Hw&select=K08w3-mToG4x5TGu5ew1Ng', 'altText': 'Photo of K88 Coffee House - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: As my Hainanese Chicken Rice pilgrimage in Singapore continues, I continue to wonder how spots that are overly close to award-winning spots survive. Here is another one of several stalls that is within walking distance of the famous Maxwell Food Centre Tian Tian Chicken Rice, which is one of three favorite Singaporean Hawkers featured on Hawker Heroes and currently challenging Gordon Ramsay in cook-off at Newton Food Centre in Singapore. The competition is still midway as I write this review.<br><br>Wang Wang Hainanese Chicken Rice is a small stall within K88 Coffee House that seems to have a good line and crowd following especially during meal times. At first, I wasn&#39;t sure if they were just catering to a crowd that either: (a) hates joining super long mealtime lines; (b) prefers fast ordering due to short lunch hours; (c) finds it more convenient - not needing to walk about 150 more steps, cross the road, and then get into a line; (d) feels that this chicken rice spot is decent enough to patronize, or (e) all of the above.<br><br>Yet, after sitting down and trying it out for myself, I found that the chicken rice and especially the chicken, the condiments, and the soup (as well as the side of crispy tofu) was pleasant to the palate. Of course, they aren&#39;t as magnificent as Tian Tian (which I personally still find to be the best Chicken Rice in Singapore)...but they are still good enough.<br><br>So based on my earlier thoughts, I&#39;m just going to guess this:<br><br>1. There are Singaporeans that freaking HATE Tian Tian&#39;s long lines as much as myself (I only eat at Tian Tian during off peak hours so that I can grub within 5-10 minutes of lining up instead of the usual 30+ minutes).<br><br>2. There are Singaporeans that will just not take an extra step to eat something a little bit better for the same price.<br><br>3. There are Singaporeans who don&#39;t give a crap...as it is still CHICKEN RICE after all...(this is definitely supported by long arse lines I tend to see at spots like Ananas Cafe...)<br><br>Yelp 100: 48/100

text: Excellent brunch place in the Tanjong Pagar area. Fresh ingredients and tasty options presented beautifully. I got the soft fried egg with chicken sausage which was excellent. Good drink options as well.

Valrhona chocolate and brandy cake ($9) - 3.75 stars<br>There are chocolate cakes and there are chocolate cakes. This one seems defined by its thick sturdy ganache topping. The cake itself is just as hardy and has the consistency and taste of say the centre of a baba au rhum - it&#39;s not a light and fluffy cake or  creamy mousse or a melt in your mouth Sacher torte. It&#39;s sort of like a more solid truffle. Anyhow it satisfied my chocolate cake craving, though I could only power through a couple of bites. The brandy is strong enough to give me a bit of a headache...<br><br>Caramel shortbread ($4.70)

Salmon pizza, Hazelnut Crodo and Chinotto ;)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salmon pizza, Hazelnut Crodo and Chinotto ;)'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/auNcEeSBT_mEZRJbz0VSgw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/da-paolo-gastronomia-bukit-timah-bukit-timah?reviewid=cx9IkEO_QcqBowAADnc_kg&select=auNcEeSBT_mEZRJbz0VSgw', 'altText': 'Photo of Da Paolo Gastronomia - Bukit Timah - Bukit Timah, Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Decided to swing by here on a Sunday afternoon. <br><br>The crowd was surprisingly not too bad. Managed to get a seat inside the store itself.<br><br>Been wanting to indulge in the pizzas for a very long time but when I used to visit the branch in Grandstand, I tend to divert my attention to the list of pastas instead.<br><br>This time round, my eyes were fixed on the pizza section. The price was reasonable and the one catches more attention than the salami pizza was the smoked salmon pizza.<br><br>Browsing through the section of cupcakes and crodos, found myself eyeing on the hazelnut Crodo (Christmas spun for the Crodo). Queued and gave the waitress my two food items that I wanted to try this time round.<br><br>The pizza base was crispy and fluffy. Surprisingly it wasn&#39;t too salty. I was looking for light bites and the pizza definitely satisfied my cravings. It was a little expensive but quality wise, it is worth the money spent. You can ask them to re-heat for you too.<br><br>The hazelnut Crodo was interesting. It was decorated with thinned dark chocolate that looks like a nest. Inside was the hazelnut cream. The colored leaf like sugar toppings definitely brought colors to the dull Crodos. The hazelnut creme wasn&#39;t too sweet. Not too thick either and it oozed out of the Crodo while cutting the dish into smaller bite portions. The dark chocolate helped to tone down the sweetness from the sugar sprinkles on top of the Crodo and the other sugary items inside.<br><br>Service was pretty efficient here. The waitress cleared up my plate quickly after I emptied the two plates of dishes. This was the second time that I&#39;m here for some light bites and desserts. Will definitely be back again ;) Cheers!!
My fiancee and I had breakfast here the day that he proposed and I can tell you the highlight of that day was eating a cronut from this bakery.

Gourmet food', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Gourmet food'}]
text: When I was wandering around the entrance to the Botanic Gardens I saw this place and thought that I might stop by afterwards and grab myself a cup of coffee, however once I had finished my explorations of the gardens I was simply way to hot for such a beverage, so I decided to step in here and grab myself some iced tea (which is really popular in Singapore). This place is one of those foodie delights with all sorts of gourmet food available. However I&#39;ve never really been all that much of a big fan of such food, so instead I simply grabbed myself a drink. It was a bit annoying though because I was standing at the counter for a while and everybody was ignoring me, until I realised that you had to walk around to the other side to actually pay for your goods. I can&#39;t say that this is one place I would be visiting again if I happen to be in Singapore.

Inside the café', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Inside the café'}]
text: This Italian Café is in a prime location, next to the wonderful Singapore Botanic Garden. Despite being next to a busy road, the glass acts as a perfect sound barrier. It isn&#39;t too crowded, and one or two tables are available at any one time. Outside tables are also available. There are a very good variety of table sizes. The atmosphere is very good, with nice, jazzy music in the background as you eat away. Service is quick, and the staff have a very good grip with English, so there will be no miscommunication, or difficulty understanding anything. The coffee is great quality, and at a good price ($5.50 for one). The ice chocolate is not a sweet one, more a savoury one. The food looks AMAZING, though. They have monster meringues, a wide variety of pastries and cakes, and a great assortment of drinks available. This place is recommended for a quick stop or lunch. Great café.

Came here for the salted egg croissant. They warm it up for you, but it doesn&#39;t ooze out like liu sha bao because it&#39;s not that type of salted egg. It reminds me strongly of the salted egg yolk that resides in traditional mooncakes, which is ok if you&#39;re a fan of that, but I happen not to like that. I have to give it credit for the texture of the croissant, which is deliciously flaky, fluffy and crunchy without being overly oily.

After visiting the Botanic Gardens, we were looking for a place to sit and drink / eat something small. <br>This place was just across the street and had still one small table left outside. <br>Their was no menu, you had to go inside to look at the big board, order and afterwards they would bring your things to your table. <br>It was 6pm and there was not a lot left anymore of the sweets (like we saw on the pictures here on Yelp), but there were still many pizza slices. We went for the vegi slice (7,5S$). It was served hot, with a wide variety of vegetables, but unfortunately the pizza was somewhat dry. Therefore only 3 stars, but it could have been more.

Cream-filled crodon (cronut).', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Cream-filled crodon (cronut).'}]
text: This cafe/bakery is located just across from the Botanic Gardens which is why I came in. I needed a coffee and some breakfast. I went for the unhealthy option and got a cream crodon (cronut), partly because another Yelp reviewer recommended it. I&#39;ve had cronut a before but never a cream-filled one. It was a very good cronut and a terrible breakfast choice: very heavy and safe to say my blood sugar level has skyrocketed.<br><br>The coffee is good. Hot, smooth and tasty. And I asked for some water after I had been sitting for a while and I&#39;d finished eating and I was quickly brought a ice-cold cup. Perfect.

I think this cafe at cluny court is a really nice and relaxing place that sets your mind at ease, with delectable desserts here that are simply awesome! The wide variety includes pastries, creme brûlée, pizzas and juices available. <br><br>Most people who come here are expats and the atmosphere and mood here seems to take on a slower pace than the usual fast-paced Singapore.

text: I like this place. Not much indoor seating so you&#39;ll have to like the outdoor type. I&#39;ve been to another location in the mall but this is of course more better with a more cafe feeling right next to the botanical garden. The food is a good buy for the price. The hazelnut cake was surprising good. It looks so ordinary especially in the plastic to go container but the hazelnut inside was crispy and fresh so it was very nice. Espresso is above average. Not the best but very nice. I like this particular location.

The carrot cake was a bit mooshy and soggy, however the cheesecake and the tiramisu didn&#39;t fail to disappoint. Overall wasn&#39;t a great but wasn&#39;t a bad experience.

text: Came here to try the crodon but unfortunately it was sold out :( gonna come here again tomorrow for international coffee day when they&#39;re gonna be selling almond macadamia milk from the mlk co to go with my coffee :D can&#39;t wait!

Grilled chicken and zucchini with caprese salad... and all gluten free!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Grilled chicken and zucchini with caprese salad... and all gluten free!'}]
text: Great gluten free selection... I had some fantastic grilled chicken and zucchini with a caprese salad. My boyfriend (not gluten free) said his salted caramel croissant doughnut was delicious. We are just traveling through Singapore, but will definitely come back to Gastronomia again before we leave.

text: Da Paolo Gastronomia caters more for takeaway and at the same time it also serves as a mini Italian supermarket where you can get your fresh pastas such as squid ink pasta and even ravioli. The biggest downside at Da Paolo would be price with small items like a single Stuffed Portobello mushrooms costing up to $7 or $8 depending on the weight. Like any supermarket Da Paolo sells most of its items or antipasti by weight hence the price rockets if you&#39;re not careful with your portions. Sadly for an Italian owned business, coffee is poor as well with a mighty upsetting bitter to sour taste. The only saving grace would be the Tiramisu but look out for some that have been sitting in the shelves for too long, the alcohol soaked layers may be dry and would definitely kill your joy. Once again a great location to spend your weekends but not my best choice for food and drinks!

text: Finally manage to try the new trend called cronuts halfway around the world from where it all started. This place named it crodos, but they&#39;re basically the same. The place itself is pretty fancy and charge a bit more than other bakeries, but hey, you don&#39;t see these too often in Singapore (or anywhere else for that reason). My favorite is definitely the 1 with cream filling - the cream filling just works better with the layered textures compared to just the glaze on top.

text: I&#39;m no salmon expert, but I&#39;m addicted to their toasted salmon sandwich! It melts in your mouth and the dressing they use is full of awesomeness.

Da Paolo is my to-go when I&#39;m in the mood for something filling, substantial and relatively &#39;healthy&#39;. My favorite has to be the salmon avocado sandwich (ciabatta). The bread itself is huge- as a girl with a hearty appetite, I&#39;m usually already quite full halfway through it. The sandwich is made on-the-spot, and can be customized to your preferences. They are also usually quite generous with the salmon helpings, but the quality isn&#39;t always consistent- there were times when the fish was limp and flaccid, and other times when it was over seasoned and hence too salty. Some might say that at $14++ per sandwich this standard is unacceptable- but I&#39;m usually not too fussed because I think the ingredients and portion sufficiently justify the price. Very unusually, the veggies are in fact the star of the sandwich- they always come very fresh and crunchy. The vinaigrette dressing also elaborates the overall taste of the sandwich.<br><br>On days when I decide to indulge, I head straight for the tiramisu. Their rendition is light and silky, allowing one to taste individually the chocolate, rum and expresso. The smallest portion is more than enough for 2- it is not cheap, but it is definitely worth it.

The music in this place - spectacularrrrrr.<br><br>Portions are great, juices are great, iced coffee was spectacular. We had the farmer&#39;s harvest thingy too - fries of all types of tubers. Not bad. Too little sauce, but you could probably ask for a refill.<br><br> Comfy sofas to sit in and and work/read a book/space out/hide from life. <br><br>Also, great wifi. <br><br>Only thing I&#39;d like to change is... hmm.... well... nothing?<br><br>DO IT.

text: A newish cafe to the market, situated in the Duxton enclave, it is in good territory as there are a multitude of cafes littering the entire area. And boy, this one is good. It is much better than its neighbor, Group Therapy cafe. <br><br>First up, the bangers and mash were a good deal at $16. The sausages were big and filling. My dining companion - a starving man - said he was quite full at the end of it. The portion was generous. My cousin who had the fish &amp; chips said the dory was so light and fluffy it was like &#34;a pillow&#34;! Hahahaha certainly one of the better fish and chips around. I thought it could be bigger but at $16 it was ok. My Garbage Omelette (with sausages, mushrooms, cheddar etc) wasn&#39;t too bad but it wasn&#39;t wow. It was something I could&#39;ve gotten at a hotel brekkie. <br><br>I enjoyed the Farmer&#39;s Harvest with fried sweet potatoes, lotus root and potatoes. Delightful. <br><br>Churros were a little overcooked and thus a bit too crispy and brittle. I would&#39;ve preferred it came a bit moe doughy in the middle - as if taking it out two mins earlier from the oven would&#39;ve been perfect. <br><br>Red velvet lava cake was interesting. My cousin thought it was too sweet but her husband enjoyed it. I would&#39;ve enjoyed it but I noticed they added condensed milk (or was it white chocolate?!) to the red velvet lava!!! I thought that&#39;s a little strange!!!! Hahaha oh well. It wasn&#39;t awful but I was perplexed. <br><br>Overall I would Defo go back!!! I wanna try their salads and other mains.<br><br>A delightful eating experience with attentive staff who anticipate your needs. One last tip - they don&#39;t open on Sunday.

text: Signature Chocolate Fudge Cake<br><br>Very good, soft &amp; moist.<br><br>Better than Lana Cake&#39;s.<br><br>Lighter than Awfully Chocolate&#39;s.<br><br>Cash terms only.<br><br>Need to order in advance.

text: Decided to drop by on a Thursday noon for its cupcake.<br><br>I was the only customer at that time and so I had a chance to look at what&#39;s on their display case. After looking at the Yelp reviews the day before, I decided to try out it&#39;s dark velvet cupcake - take away.<br><br>Consumed the cupcake 1 hour later. Here&#39;s the verdict. It is similar to Lana&#39;s famous chocolate cake. The base of the cupcake was moist and similar to lava cake, it has chocolate that gushes out from the cupcake. It was slightly sweeter than Lana&#39;s cake (probably the different types of chocolate that they use) and the dark velvet cupcake was topped with cream cheese and a piece of milk chocolate. The cupcake gave a light sensation and had effects that lingers in the mouth. <br><br>Price wise it was pretty decent considering the types of chocolates they use to make one reasonable sized cupcake. The staff was also friendly and welcomed me when I first entered the space. Definitely a good place to try out if you are a cupcake lover like myself :)

Chocolate fudge cake ($6.50) - 4 stars<br>Kind of expensive. Haven&#39;t had Lana cake in ages so this may not be the best comparison but they taste comparable. This cake is moist and not overwhelmingly rich.<br><br>Cupped forest ($4.50) - 2 stars<br>The cake was drier than the cake used for the chocolate fudge cake and they don&#39;t use fresh cherries. Go for the chocolate fudge cake.

Chocolate Fudge Cake topped with dinosaurs and volcanoes. The volcanoes were also chocolate fudge cake.", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Chocolate Fudge Cake topped with dinosaurs and volcanoes. The volcanoes were also chocolate fudge cake.'}]
text: WOW! Just WOW. Having lived in the U.S. for over 2 decades, it&#39;s been years since I&#39;ve had Vicky&#39;s chocolate fudge cake  But we are back for a visit and on a friend&#39;s suggestion ordered my son&#39;s birthday cake from Vicky&#39;s. My son is into dinosaurs and had imagined a cake with a volcano and dinosaurs. We ordered the chocolate fudge cake, gave them some dinosaurs and asked if they could create a volcano. We were all delighted with their creation! And the birthday boy&#39;s eyes got big and wide when he saw it.<br><br>And oh, the taste! The chocolate fudge cake is more moist  than I recall. And they nailed the amount of chocolate fudge so that it&#39;s not  too much and not too little with each bite. It was a decadent delight and this is coming from someone who doesn&#39;t even really like cake! So thankful we ordered from them! YUM!

text: This isn&#39;t going to be a fair or balanced review.  I&#39;ll be the first to admit that I&#39;m such an adoring acolyte of Vicky&#39;s chocolate cake that I absolutely cannot be relied on to be objective or informative.   Let&#39;s just say for the sake of didactic discussion that I happened to witness something unsavory happening at Vicky&#39;s, you&#39;d never hear about it from me.  I&#39;m just that hopelessly devoted to every thing that Vicky&#39;s puts out.<br><br>For those of you who remember Vicky&#39;s from Henry Park, well, it&#39;s the exact same family run operation, just back in a new location.  I have to say that their timing is impeccable and with the expanded concept of a café, Vicky&#39;s Café could really ride the wave.  I&#39;m just hoping that they stick around forever like they did in Henry Park to become a neighborhood fixture.  It can only be a good thing.<br><br>The new retail space is nice and cozy.  TJ who used to run the front of the house operations at Henry Park has taken on more responsibility as the barista at Vicky&#39;s Café here at Royalville.  He pulled a very decent double espresso for me when I visited and he&#39;d be the first to tell you that he&#39;s still working on getting it just right.  They use CSH as their roasters and it comes through in the coffee.  Kudos, TJ!    The café has the unmistakable miasma  of &#34;hipster-ness&#34; about it.    Not really my thing, but I love it because it&#39;s Vicky&#39;s.  <br><br>Of course, you can do like all Vicky&#39;s long time stalwarts do and just call in, order and drop by to pick up.   There are also cakes available for pickup.  An 800g square of perfection will set you back $32.   Let&#39;s face it, there aren&#39;t many things left in Singaporean life that&#39;ll put a smile on your face.   Vicky&#39;s chocolate cake never fails to put a smile on each and every face in my family every time.  It&#39;s just that consistently good.  The sponge is texturally unique in that you won&#39;t find many chocolate cakes this moist that have a sponge this, for the want of a better word, zippy!  If chocolate sponge could be al dente, then Vicky&#39;s certainly is.  The chocolate is deceptive and its full complexity sneaks up on your unsuspecting jaded palate.  There is of course the deep dark and almost earthy flavor notes you&#39;d expect from any good chocolate, but then it blooms, developing an umami almost salty dimension reminiscent of a molé, It takes your breath away if you&#39;re not expecting it and then you have to smile at being taken for a pleasantly surprising flavor joyride.  I&#39;ve been told variously by different members of my family that Vicky&#39;s is good because you never get &#34;gelak&#34;, meaning you never reach a point of diminishing returns, it&#39;s just that good that you can keep on going.<br><br>Me, I&#39;m just glad that Vicky&#39;s is back!  Santa, please make them stay.  I promise I&#39;ll be good.

text: This place is a work hanger built into a restaurant.  It&#39;s a very cool concept. The food is reasonable priced for Singapore. Plates were a good sized.  Chicken was a full breast.  Garlic bread was crispy and good.  I like the ambiance. It&#39;s a good place to come and chill. Have. Coffee and small bite or a meal. <br>Fried Cauliflower very good.  Lemoned iced tea very strong. Coffee looks good too. (Didn&#39;t try it though. So that&#39;s off what I saw being served.) <br>We would come back and eat here.

text: I&#39;d have to agree with most reviews / comments from friends, this place has a nice ambience, but food is mediocre. The cafe interior is great, air-conditioned, wide spaces, high ceilings, a range of sofas and seats for the solo people-watcher to diners. Food-wise, nothing to shout about. I would say over-priced too for the type of foods that they serve, but arguably the prices are quite typical of any cafes you&#39;d visit. (The iced espresso ball was $9, and it was really just a little cup of iced latte. Guess you&#39;re paying extra for the fun of melting the espresso with milk)<br><br>It&#39;s self-service at this place -- order at the cashier and get a buzzer, pick up your food from the counter once the buzzer rings. They don&#39;t charge GST and Service Charge here. <br><br>They only have 4 parking spaces in front of their outlet (where the signature blue gates are). Free parking available on weekends at the industrial building next to it. Alternatively, limited street parking is also available (60c per half hour, even on Sundays). <br><br>They are on Burpple Beyond, but there are T&amp;Cs behind the Beyond deals -- a max of 4 redemptions per table, and any Beyond payments need to be made via cash or nets only. For all other payments, credit card is accepted only for bills above $20.

text: The craze for this hipster,instaworthy cafe has died down.<br>But the food remains satisfying!<br><br>My colleagues and I had<br><br>-All day breakfast <br>- Fish &amp; Chips<br>- Seafood Pasta<br>- Grilled Chicken <br>- Taco Platter <br><br>The portions were generous, the only downside was that the chicken lacked seasoning. <br><br>I would definitely order F&amp;C again, feeling blessed as I had 3 awesome F&amp;C from different places this year! (TICM and Workbench!) Wheeler&#39;s has a large serving mayo for those who like to splatter their fish with! <br><br>Fries are plentiful too, it&#39;s the kind of fries that are still delish even it&#39;s not piping hot. It was a hearty meal overall.<br><br>The ambience of the place has an industrial chic vibe going on, the signature blue doors, high ceilings are unseaworthy.<br> <br>* Weekday Set Lunch <br>$19.90 for selected mains with soup or salad and a drink.<br><br>*Water is self serving, I really dislike food establishments that charge for water!

text: Have heard much about this place and as this is my first time here, what I heard didn&#39;t disappoint. The ambiance and atmosphere was vibrant and the food scrumptious. The soft shell chilli crab spaghetti was a little spicy for me but the Suki beef rice bowl was done just right with the right amount of sauce, and the beef, tender. For drinks, the Hulk, which was a concoction of green Apple, ginger and honey and the Tropical Dream, of mango and raspberry was perfect compliment to the meal.

text: Wheeler&#39;s Yard, you surprise me.<br><br>Your concept is too cool for school. You are a bike shop, a pop up bar, and an air conditioned cafe all in one. I love how you picked up on today&#39;s industrial decor trend and morphed your huge warehouse to house all three concepts.<br><br>I&#39;m not a bike rider, so I can&#39;t comment on your sweet looking bikes, but I am an eater and drinker, so I will give you my 2 cents on that! Your calamari is a great starter; LOVE the sauce it&#39;s drenched in though the squid was a bit too chewy at times. Your Caesar salad is my second favourite in Singapore (next to, you guessed it, Salad Stop&#39;s haha.) I love how you give me those cute little cookies to go with my coffee, and how I have a good choice of ciders if I&#39;m in the mood for one.<br><br>And how can I say no to the easily accessible pitchers of ice water, some which are displayed on the back of a bike?<br><br>I normally decide to cool down in your air conditioned cafe, where I enjoy listening to your awesome pop playlist. I love how I spot neighbours of all ages hanging out here and in the al fresco dining area too. <br><br>Basically, you know how to appeal to the local community, and you&#39;re doing it all right. And hey, you&#39;re even willing to serve not-cool-enough people like myself with a smile, so you get all the stars for that!

text: Wheeler&#39;s Yard is my go-to place during the weekday if I need a place to complete work or do some readings. The high ceilings and spacious arrangement doesn&#39;t give a claustrophobic feeling. Best thing is, I don&#39;t need to sit elbow to elbow with people and fit for a good cup of coffee. <br><br>The servers pretty much leave you alone most of the time so don&#39;t expect service here. It&#39;s something that I don&#39;t mind when I prefer to just concentrate on my laptop and my readings. <br><br>Food wise- the fries are a must-try. My friend and I made a mistake of ordering our mains AND fries. The portion is so huge that even on its own, the two of us could not have finished it. The big breakfast set is rather big also. However, the price did leave a huge hole in my pocket. <br><br>Overall, good place you want to have some quality time with friends or by yourself.
