Seating inside and outside.", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Seating inside and outside.'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HsVP__17nJuFDj0LeKnqAg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/wheelers-yard-singapore?reviewid=_jXDH2zhHz8cnMs5VHX9xQ&select=HsVP__17nJuFDj0LeKnqAg', 'altText': "Photo of Wheeler's Yard - Singapore, Singapore. The favourite blue door", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'The favourite blue door'}]
text: What a find!<br><br>In what feels like the middle of nowhere, Wheeler&#39;s Yard doesn&#39;t look like much from the street. A big blue door on front of a warehouse doesn&#39;t hint at what&#39;s behind... but the people standing in front of it madly taking selfies indicates that perhaps something interesting is going on inside.<br><br>Walk down the side alley and through a big open door and you suddenly realise that this place is choc-full with people drinking coffee and eating brunch. I&#39;m not talking just a dozen people, but a hundred, maybe more! <br><br>There&#39;s two areas to sit. Behind the glass doors, you might be lucky to score a seat on the big communal table where you can read magazines and relax in AC comfort. Outside there&#39;s more seating and also the view of the bicycle workshop where you can buy a funky bike or bring yours to be serviced. I spied some cute kids helmets sporting animal faces, and only wished they came in big-kid sizes!<br><br>We stopped in for drinks only - there&#39;s coffee and tea, interesting soft drinks and also a small selection of beers. But many visitors were sharing piles of fries, sweets and brunchy items that looked appetising.<br><br>It&#39;s great to see that the entrepreneurial F&amp;B world is alive and kicking here in Singapore and if Wheeler&#39;s Yard is a sign of more fun things to come, then it&#39;s safe to say that Singaporeans have a lot to look forward to when it comes to innovative venues.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=AbfS_oXF8H6HJb5jFqhrLw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7U3-fksAWs4oUiRlgmPGzg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Paco G.', 'displayLocation': 'México, D.F., Mexico', 'altText': 'Paco G.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=AbfS_oXF8H6HJb5jFqhrLw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 44, 'photoCount': 22, 'reviewCount': 55, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I am a strong supporter of bicycles as a mean of transport, and I sometimes miss those Sundays back home when they close some main avenues so we can cycle just for recreation. No wonder any kind of place devoted to cyclists will always catch my attention.<br><br>Wheeler&#39;s Yard is on a quiet area in the border between Whampoa and Toa Payoh. The restaurant is inside a spacious industrial warehouse, sharing the massive space with a bicycle shop and self-labeled atelier. In a time of crammed cafes and confined restaurants dubbed as &#34;intimate&#34;, the high ceilings and massive tables of the restaurant are a delight. The whole place is a vintage paradise, highly appealing to architectural restoration enthusiasts. They basically kept as much as they could from the original warehouse and made the restaurant and atelier fit in there, creating a vast place with a warm atmosphere, ideal for groups and sharing.<br><br>The menu is varied, with some Japanese inspiration and local ingredients. I had a nicely done pan-seared snapper served in a small pool of fragrant mushroom stock. It was not spectacular, but the flavours were wisely balanced. My wife had a sous vide chicken, which was juicy and fairly tasty. We also had the truffle fries, which we liked a lot. They have a small, careful selection of local craft beers at reasonable prices. Another plus is they don&#39;t impose service charge, since the place actually works on a self service basis. The food prices are not those of a self-service place, though.<br><br>All in all, Wheeler&#39;s Yard works as a retreat from the race of the chase. It feels ideal for a quiet afternoon in Whampoa (which is quiet enough itself). I can imagine myself arriving there after a long and tiring urban cycle ride. Yeah, that&#39;s going on my list.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nBLmHtJhJZYxEkaKpSdGLA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/wheelers-yard-singapore?reviewid=gkke9zCCRJjtuHD85Lj1jQ&select=nBLmHtJhJZYxEkaKpSdGLA', 'altText': "Photo of Wheeler's Yard - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I went to Wheeler&#39;s Yard yesterday evening with my partner and the first impression was very good. Nestled within an industrial warehouse, it&#39;s like a hidden gem that&#39;s waiting to be uncovered. The ambience within the cafe is certainly unique - with its high ceiling, warm lighting and consistent bicycle theme. It felt like a place where one could relax and chat with friends for hours. <br><br>The food and drinks were definitely pricey, especially considering the location and the fact that everything is self-service. We were there too early for dinner, so we ordered a bowl of truffle fries to share ($14.90, i think).<br><br>The truffle fries were AMAZING. The moment the bowl was set on the table in front of me, I was hit by the aroma of truffles. That was when I knew this was going to be an experience to remember. The fries were hot and crispy and the chef was definitely liberal with the truffle oil and grated cheese. The portion was just right for 2 people, and we polished it off in no time. The truffle aroma stayed with us for the rest of the night, even through dinner. I&#39;m still gushing over it. We&#39;ll definitely go back again.

Being a cyclist from the moment I heard of this place I was intrigued. My first thought when I walked in was that it is awesome and very Melbourne...<br>The coffee was good and definitely a stop point after my morning rides<br>It definitely had the potential to be a 4 star food experience. Unfortunately we had to send back our burger because the meat was sloppy red raw! So we sent it back and the next one was really good and fresh, which is why I think this place still has potential and  just needs to ask how you want your burger done.

I was frankly pretty disappointed with the visit. The ambience and layout are really fun and the place looks like it ought to be great. Sadly, the food was only so-so. <br>We went for Sunday brunch and between everyone at the table sampled quite a few items on the menu. I had the Ultimate Beef Yard burger and my wife had the Big Breakfast. My burger was slightly undercooked and VERY greasy and the fries (which I had heard good things about) were dry and overcooked. The breakfast items were rather bland as well. Prices (as mentioned in other reviews) are not cheap and frankly very inflated for the quality. <br>The place is fun to visit and I suspect that&#39;s what you pay for. It is family friendly but very, very noisy for lunch on a Sunday - don&#39;t expect any intimate conversation. <br>I think this is a low 3 star rating due only to the quirky fun atmosphere but I would not return for the food.

The drinks/ coffee are good but the food is terrible! I ordered the Salmon Mentaiko pasta which was a chef&#39;s recommendation. I love mentaiko everything but this $19.90 pasta was fishy, bland and tasteless all at the same time. It was definitely cooked by someone who could not care less. Even Whampoa Market/ Pastamania serves better food. My partner ordered a fish and chips and beware! It comes with fish bones! You are only paying for the ambience. What a shame.

A place like this exists in Singapore, holy schnikes! Texas barnyard meets Novena hustle &amp; bustle. At the onset, when you first lay your eyes on this beauty, you begin to wonder, &#34;this place looks out of place doesn&#39;t it?&#34; You walk inside this pimped out barnyard and you concur, &#34;this place is really out of place!&#34; But I guess, that is part of the charm of Wheelers Yard, a huge pimped out warehouse located in a quiet street corner of Novena with neighborhood Aunties and Uncles as regular customers.<br><br>Inside this proverbial barn is a restaurant, bike shop, a pop-up bar/cider stand, and what I swear is a stage concert. Literally, the place can turned into anything the owner desires.  <br><br>In terms of the food, the Fried Calamari dipped in black sweet sauce is a MUST try. I know I sound like a broken record that this and that is the Best in Singapore. But, why not, I&#39;ll say it again, the Best Calamari dish in Singapore. The Calamari portions are huge, even for Singapore and the Sauce was well... the bomb diggitty. The Prawn Aglio Olio, which I seem to try at every restaurant, was good, but doesn&#39;t compare to Starker down the road. I didn&#39;t try the bbq ribs, but I might as well have had it since my fellow communal seating partner was gorging himself right next to me. Based on his reaction after every bite, it must have been good or at least worth the consideration.  <br><br>Overall, Wheelers Yard is a MUST SEE cafe and truly embodies the creativity of Singapore and its people.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/iR8F1Ir8WnSUO9UoM4aoNg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/wheelers-yard-singapore?reviewid=qMbXPcolfRzaD2L9WNjwrA&select=iR8F1Ir8WnSUO9UoM4aoNg', 'altText': "Photo of Wheeler's Yard - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dbabYBhy-yZ5smhmN1_5zg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/wheelers-yard-singapore?reviewid=qMbXPcolfRzaD2L9WNjwrA&select=dbabYBhy-yZ5smhmN1_5zg', 'altText': "Photo of Wheeler's Yard - Singapore, Singapore. Super cool place", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Super cool place'}]
text: Whilst the burger was pricey and could have been bigger I can&#39;t but rate it as one of Singapore&#39;s best offerings.  The Wagyu fat infused patty was close to perfection, rested well and a nice grill to it. The onsen egg precariously resting on top was both theatrical and fun to pop allowing the yolk to coat the ingredients. The pickles were sensibly left on the side as they were sweet and would have distracted from the hero of the dish, the patty.  All this in a great venue. Ask them to keep the fries hit though!

Great ambience with wide spaces - something hard-pressed to find in Singapore. Food range is surprising wide. Love the food choices we made although the poached egg is still far from world standards. The coffee is good. A glance at the drinks list reveals another surprisingly wide range of whiskeys, cocktails and beers. A bit hidden from the main road but a definite gem if you are looking to chill in a unique and cool environment amidst good beverages and decent food

I found a review online that mentioned the Ribeye steak was worth a shot! Steak in a cafe didn&#39;t seem like the natural option but none of the other items on the menu impressed me much so I decided to go for it! What&#39;s the worst that could happen? $27 wasted and a sad face. <br><br>Boy! Was I glad I decided to take the path less travelled! The Ribeye steak was delicious (I had it medium done)! Unfortunately, the same cannot be said about their burgers! <br><br>My friend asked the cashier, &#34;what&#39;s good here?&#34;<br>She replied, &#34;up to you lor&#34;<br>Unsatisfied with the answer I chimed in, &#34;but what would you recommend?&#34;<br>She asked, &#34;the burger&#34; <br>He decided to go with her recommendation but we weren&#39;t impressed. The meat was subpar. It tasted kinda chewy and over marinated... kinda like cheap sausage meat grounded into a patty? Either she has poor taste or she gave him really bad information. <br><br>Coffee-wise, I really didn&#39;t think that they were as good as Nylon etc. Passable but it wasn&#39;t impressive.<br><br>Service was also rather slow that day. My steak came out on time but my friends&#39; food didn&#39;t. <br><br>Ambiance-wise, Wheeler is unbeatable! A beautiful hipster cafe! I love the concept and the deco. Not so much the location and the parking. There&#39;s barely enough lots to fit 5% of the customers. They only have 4 lots out front. All 4 were taken when we arrived. Plus, the remote location (an industrial like area) didn&#39;t really help because it wasn&#39;t very accessible via public transportation so I wished they had more parking space!

Food is ok, to medium. I had eggs and bacon breakfast, jus and coffee. You pay for a premium, at a self service station. Where are my 10% service charge going?.. Seriously?<br><br>I agree the front door is nice.. Inside is a nice concept too. But it doesn&#39;t justify the price. <br><br>For cheaper and better (food) I would go to Jewel cafe instead... It&#39;s 15mins away but I&#39;ll not feel like raped off on Saturday or Sunday morning for brunch. <br><br>I tried it once, I&#39;ll not go there anymore for sure.

The hype over the locality of this place, an industrial space functioning both as a bike atelier and a cafe at the same time, Wheeler&#39;s Yard is a place where you can get unique bicycles while also having western food items and drinks!<br><br>The food menu is rather extensive here.<br><br>And the drinks menu! Rather simple.<br><br>The Latte ($5) tasted ok with the right amount of milk added. Nothing too great.<br><br>The Big Breakfast ($14.90) is served with a wholemeal bread toast, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, hashbrown &amp; garden salad. This is way better than the coffee although not overwhelming as well. The toast was rather nicely toasted and crusty. The scrambled eggs are nice. The bacon is great. The sausages and the hashbrown are average. The garden salad is also not too bad. In overall, this could have been better.<br><br>If you live or is around the Balestier area, this place should be considered to have your meal (for its ambience; do not expect too much from the food and drinks)

So there&#39;s food and coffee here but that&#39;s not what I&#39;m talking about (if you must know, its ok).  But the bike shop here is fantastic!  Custom builds from Taiwan.  Amazing little accessories.  Bamboo fenders!  And a smart and enthusiastic staff with a strong love for all things bike.  Ya...I get it...it&#39;s about as hipster as you can get but they know how to throw down for reals.

text: Ok so I ordered a dish called &#39;sticky ribs&#39; or something like that few weeks ago.<br>I asked for medium rare and later I was told it&#39;s already precooked so I just went with it.<br><br>When it was served oh boy, the worst ribs ever tasted and it was not cheap. It tasted like something out of a can... <br>And why aren&#39;t the servers patrolling to see if customers have needs? They just stand behind the counter and chatting away. I was once a part-time waiter back in  UNI, so u must prove ur value. My 2cents: minimum care only gets u minimum wage.

text: Amazing space with a good vibe going around. Perfect spot for a read or for a talky talk - the tables are pretty spread apart so you have good noise level. Coffee&#39;s good enough but it can be better. Same for the food. If you have that then this place is set.

text: Looks cool, great concept. Food sucks. Grilled chicken dry and bland. Burger is dry and bland. Truffle fries is decent.

text: Cool bikes, cool owner, very laid back place ... Opening hours is a bit tricky to follow though... Food is, well, I would love it if I can DIY it there! New concept right?

I loovvveeeeee this place! Located in Chinatown in Singapore, we came here on vacation &amp; this place was on our list to try out. Really cheap &amp; really good food. We had breakfast and tried a little bit of everything, the butter toast, rice rolls, chicken curry and of course the hot and cold coffees. Really recommend this place for any foodies &amp; you should definitely try their coffee! The iced coffee was my favorite

text: The cafe management is not up to standard . I had done in before the food just taste so so nothing great and I found the website that they have delivery services so just to share with you guys due to bad experience i had with them I will advise if you want to order from them be prepared , firstly they will stated food is preparing and after waiting for one hour , they will cancel your order due to their own reason so it&#39;s quite piss off and I will not order from them anymore .

text: It just opened at the basement of Orchard Central. It is a smallish place near the florist and all the shops which sell soaps, very near the underground link to The Centrepoint. <br><br>Due to the limited space, it focuses more on its core business of serving coffee and tea plus toast and soft boiled eggs. There is a small selection of steamed buns too. I like it this way, keep it traditional. I find the bigger and more well known names of local coffee and tea have deviated from making coffee and tea and try to do too many things like selling laksa, sandwiches and chicken curry and more. <br><br>So it is a treat to see this simple coffee shop. I had the teh and it was really good. Sweet but not sickeningly cloying sweet and the tea was fresh with no acidic aftertaste or bitterness. It was made by the elderly uncle and maybe he had the experience. I hope it will remain this way as it is getting quite hard to get the kopi and teh done exactly right.<br><br>It is on the pricey side at $1.70 for a small cup of tea/coffee. Then again, it is getting to this price now for most places. At least you still get change back from a $2 note.
